The dimly lit bar seemed to darken further as Frank slumped onto his barstool, his bleary eyes fixed on the bartender. "Another one, Frank?" the man asked, a hint of disdain creeping into his tone. But Frank didn't notice – or care. It was barely noon, after all.

As the words slipped past his lips, Dan spoke up from across the bar, "Don't cut me off, man. Let me finish my drink." But his words fell flat, laced as they were with desperation. Frank barely acknowledged him, lost in his own haze.

Dan's voice rose, taking on an edge. A voice that had once been warm and inviting, now sounded strained and raw. His words cut to their mark, striking a chord in the depths of Frank. 'A broken man, that's what you are,' Dan spat. When will you finally seek help?

Frank's response was immediate, 'Shut it,' but the pain behind his eyes betrayed his resolve. Dan pressed on, pouring out the wounds of their past. People used to celebrate Frank; he'd been a hero. Then, one fateful night, everything unraveled. Pissed and stumbling, losing himself in drink. Making a mockery of himself.

Frank felt the weight of Dan words, like a fist to his gut. And in an instant, memories came flooding back. Memories of that terrible night. Of hearing the child's screams, echoing through the empty streets. 

The scene shifted abruptly, to Dan holding out his napkins with a therapist's phone number scribble. For a moment, hope flickered to life in Franks eyes. This time, things might be different. With a newfound resolve, Frank rose from his seat, tossed his jacket over his shoulder, left the stool behind. As he stumbled home, darkness and chaos waited, patiently.

But as he walked, familiar terrors began to creep back in. Oh God, no, not again. Those damned screams. That stench. Fire. Flames engulfing the very air he breathed. In a flash, instincts took over, propelling Frank forward. Storming through his front doors, into a burning inferno.

He stumbled through smoke-filled rooms, ears straining to pinpoint the source of those pitiful cries. Upon entering the upstairs, flames had already consumed everything. Choking fumes seeped into every pore, threatening to consume him whole.

In a room shrouded in smoke, pounding echoed through walls. BOOOM. CRrack! A door splintered under his boot, spilling him into an untouched bathroom. Yet, smoke hung heavy, an acrid stinging in every breath. There, in those twisted shadows, lay the small form of an abandoned child.

Squatting, cowering in terror, knees clamped tight. Scalding fear. Squatting in fear, huddled in shadows. Suddenly, those eyes, locked onto Frank with unspoken dread. Before that boy can move, before he could flee, there was the voice of redemption.

"Come with mel" Frank yelled, arms outstretched, willing to catch the terror-stricken child. Instead, terror froze, eyes widening in despair. Shaking away, flinching at the sound of Fraks voice.

His own voice softened now. Speaking gentle words that soothed his heart. Realizing the deep-rooted fear that gripped that child, scared wit-less. Fear that mirrored his very own. Come on. Please, come on with. Now. Here. Together. No one had to know anything. Only they. They, alone. Two souls caught in this maelstrom, reaching out for each other. One last push and they'd be out of this nightmarish hell. Hand in hand, they sprint toward safety. From the shattered remains of broken lives, two figures emerge, scarred but unbroken. Whole. Wholly unshaken. Fully redeemed. New beginnings unfolded as, together, these two souls stepped out into that burning world. Freedom's flame, burning bright.
LLM_2:
The bar was a cave of shadows, dim and thick with the scent of stale beer and regret. When Frank lowered himself onto the cracked leather of his usual stool, the room seemed to exhale—a slow, weary breath—as if even the walls were tired of watching him fall. His eyes, glassy and unfocused, found the bartender’s reflection in the mirror behind the bottles.

"Another one, Frank?" The man’s voice carried that familiar edge—half pity, half contempt. It was barely past noon. Time had long since stopped mattering.

Before the question could settle, Dan cut in from across the counter, voice frayed at the seams. "Don’t you dare cut me off, man. Just… let me finish." But the plea was hollow, trembling like a wire about to snap. Frank didn’t turn. Didn’t blink. He was already sinking, deeper than the barstool could hold.

Then Dan’s tone sharpened, rising like smoke from dry tinder. That voice—once warm enough to gather around on winter nights—now scraped raw with urgency. “You’re broken, Frank. A ghost wearing a man’s skin. When are you going to stop running?”  

Frank flinched, just once. A flicker beneath the surface. “Shut it,” he muttered, but the words trembled in his throat.  

Dan didn’t relent. He reached back through the wreckage—the cheers, the medals, the way people used to raise their glasses when Frank walked into a room. Hero. Savior. Man who ran *into* fires while others fled. Then came the night that burned it all: drunk, disoriented, stumbling through blackened streets as screams tore through the dark. A child’s voice. Shrill. Terrified. And Frank—too slow, too late—watching helplessness become legend.

The memory hit like a fist. Frank doubled inward, not physically, but somewhere deeper. His breath caught. The bar dissolved.

And then—light. Or the idea of it.

Dan slid a napkin forward, folded once, its surface scribbled with ink. A name. A number. A therapist. For a heartbeat, something stirred in Frank’s chest—not hope, not yet, but the ghost of it, fluttering like a moth against glass.  

He stood. Jacket slung over his shoulder. Boots heavy on the floor. The world outside waited—dark, chaotic, hungry—but for the first time in years, Frank stepped toward it not as a fugitive, but a man daring to return.

But the past is never far.

Halfway home, the nightmares surged—unbidden, undeniable. That scream. Not imagined. Real. Echoing down alleyways only he could hear. The stench of burning wood. Flesh. Fear. Heat so intense it warped the air. Instinct roared to life. Adrenaline ripped him from memory and hurled him forward.

He crashed through his front door—no, not his house, *the house*, the one that lived behind his eyes—and plunged into flame.

Smoke coiled like serpents through the halls. Fire licked up the walls, painting hell in orange and black. Each breath scorched his lungs. Yet still he climbed, boots pounding the stairs now buckling beneath him, drawn by the sound—faint, desperate—of a child weeping behind a sealed door.

BOOOM. CRrack!

His boot shattered the frame. The bathroom beyond was untouched by fire, but choked with smoke, a tomb wrapped in silence. And there, in the corner, small and shaking—knees drawn tight, face buried—was the boy.

Not real. Not not real.

Frank dropped to one knee. The heat, the terror, the weight of every failure—he let it all fall away.

"Come with me," he said, voice cracking like old timber. Arms outstretched. Empty. Open.

The boy flinched. Eyes wide. Wild with fear. He shrank further into shadow, as if Frank himself were the monster.

So Frank softened. Lowered his voice until it was little more than a whisper, a lullaby woven from ash and longing.

“It’s okay,” he murmured. “I’m here. I’m *here*. You don’t have to be afraid. Not anymore.”

Tears streaked the grime on the child’s face. A hand twitched. A breath held.

And then—movement. Small. Trembling. Reaching.

They rose together, two figures silhouetted in flame and smoke. Hand in hand, they crossed the threshold—not just from room to room, but from ruin to reckoning. From past to present. From drowning to breath.

When they burst through the front door into the cold night air, the fire raged behind them. But they did not look back.

They stood—man and child, phantom and soul—side by side in the wreckage of what was, alive in what could be.

Redemption doesn’t roar. It whispers. It steps forward when everything says to stay down.

And sometimes, just sometimes, it takes the shape of a man finally coming home—to himself.

This paper introduces a novel method for an adversarial attack named mixup inference (MI). Most of the work focuses on embedding mixup mechanism in the training phase, but MI uses the mixup in the inference phase. MI method has two main effects for the adversarial attack: one is perturbation shrinkage, and the other one is input transfer because MI can exploit the induced global linearity. The experimental results show that MI can return more reliable predictions under different threat models.

This paper should be accepted because the proposed method is super simple but effective for defending from adversarial attacks under different threat conditions. This paper is well-written, including theoretical insights on why the MI method works.

The reviewer has some questions or comments to clarify the paper:
1) In the explanation of the MI method, the authors assume only the cases where the input data is correctly classified if it is clean, or wrongly classified if it is adversarial. In a realistic situation, the classifier sometimes outputs mislabels. Thus is the discussion in Sec.3 valid if the clean input data misclassified?

2) To predict the category of the input, MI methods must perform inference N times. It is not efficient. Are there any ideas to reduce the number of inferences?

3) MI-Combined seems ad-hoc. It would be better to state its justification by theory.

4) The same idea of mixup was proposed at the same conference (ICLR2018). It should be cited.
Tokozume et al., Learning from Between-class Examples for Deep Sound Recognition. ICLR, 2018.
LLM_1:
This work introduces an innovative method referred to as mix-up inference, abbreviated as MI, for conducting adversaria attacks. While the majority of existing research focuses solely on incorporating the mixing mechanism during the learning phase of a model, our proposed MI technique utilizes the blending technique within the prediction phase instead. As a result, we observe two primary benefits of MI in adversarially attacking models: perturbations are reduced, leading to shrinkages, while the transfer of input is facilitated due to global linearities that are induced by MI. Experimental outcomes demonstrate that predictions generated by our method exhibit higher reliability across various threat scenarios.

We believe that our novel approach warrants consideration for publication in this esteemed journal, given its straightforward yet highly effective method of defending against diverse adverserial threats. Moreover, this paper provides insightful theoretical explanations for why our MI approach proves effective.

However, a reviewer posed some clarifying questions to further elucidate the presented work:

1.  The authors' explanation assumes that the classification model correctly labels clean data and misclassifies adversarily perturbed data. However, in real-world scenarios, classification models sometimes produce mislabeled outputs. Does this assumption hold in such cases, particularly in Section 3?

    2. To accurately categorize input using the our approach, multiple inference operations are performed, which is computationally inefficient. Can the inductive inference process be optimized or modified to minimize the required number inference steps?

   4. Our proposed "MI-Combination" technique is perceived as being somewhat ad hoc. Therefore, it would greatly enhance our argument if a theoretical justification could be provided.

    Finally, there is a similar idea presented in Tokozome et.al's paper "Learning from between-class examples for deep sound recognition" which was presented at ICLR  20-18 and should therefore be referenced. 

    The above response is in its final polished state
LLM_2:
---

This study introduces an innovative method termed Mix-Up Inference (MI) for conducting adversarial attacks. While the majority of existing research predominantly focuses on incorporating mixing mechanisms during the learning phase of a model, our proposed MI technique leverages blending techniques within the prediction phase instead. Consequently, we observe two primary benefits of MI in adversarially attacking models: a reduction in perturbations, leading to shrinkages, and enhanced transfer of input facilitated by global linearities induced by MI. Experimental outcomes indicate that predictions generated through our method exhibit significantly higher reliability across various threat scenarios.

We assert that our novel approach merits consideration for publication in this esteemed journal due to its straightforward yet highly effective methodology for defending against diverse adversarial threats. Furthermore, this paper provides insightful theoretical explanations for the effectiveness of our MI approach.

However, a reviewer has raised several clarifying questions that could further elucidate the presented work:

1. The authors' explanation presupposes that the classification model accurately labels clean data while misclassifying adversarially perturbed data. In real-world scenarios, classification models occasionally produce mislabeled outputs. Does this assumption hold true in such cases, particularly in Section 3?

2. To accurately categorize input using our approach, multiple inference operations are conducted, which may be computationally inefficient. Could the inductive inference process be optimized or modified to minimize the required number of inference steps?

3. Our proposed "MI-Combination" technique appears somewhat ad hoc. Therefore, a theoretical justification for this technique would significantly strengthen our argument.

Finally, there is a related concept presented in Tokozome et al.'s paper, "Learning from Between-Class Examples for Deep Sound Recognition," which was presented at ICLR 2018. This work should be duly referenced in our paper.

---

This revision enhances clarity, fluency, and academic tone while addressing the reviewers' concerns comprehensively.

---

This study proposes a novel approach to enhancing Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) through dense layer connectivity, achieved by concatenating the outputs of all preceding layers as input to the current layer. Additionally, an attention context is computed at each layer and subsequently aggregated into a single unified context vector. Experimental results demonstrate performance comparable to conventional RNN architectures without dense connections, despite employing a significantly smaller number of parameters. This efficiency is observed across English-to-French and English-to-German neural machine translation tasks, as well as in text summarization benchmarks.

While the motivation for adapting densely connected architectures—previously shown to be effective in computer vision—to sequence modeling is reasonable, a deeper understanding of the individual contributions of the proposed components is warranted. Specifically, this work integrates two key techniques: (1) dense cross-layer connections and (2) multi-layer attention mechanisms. To disentangle their respective impacts, more comprehensive ablation studies are required. Such analyses should isolate the performance gains attributable to dense connectivity from those resulting from the use of multiple attention modules.

With regard to experimental design, it is unclear why the hidden state size (e.g., 128 for machine translation) was held fixed while only varying the number of layers. To better assess architectural trade-offs, complementary experiments should be conducted in which the number of layers is kept constant while the hidden dimensionality is varied. This would provide additional insight into the role of parameter distribution and model capacity in the observed performance.

Additional comments:

- In Section 3, the term "sequence-to-sequence" appears to be erroneously rendered as "sequence to sequence to sequence." This typographical error should be corrected.
- The manuscript does not clarify why a fully concatenative connection scheme—linking all prior layers to each subsequent layer, as mentioned in Section 2—was not explored. Was this omission due to memory constraints or computational limitations? A discussion on this point would strengthen the methodological transparency of the work.

---

Tow-point and multi-point Lod scores were calculated under different levels of penetrance, assuming both dominant and recessive models. Multipoint nonparametric linkage (NPL) scores were also calculated.The two-point Lod scores (theta = 0) and multipoint Lod scores for the 4 microsatellites were all less than -2 for all the markers tested, at all levels of penetrance, and in both the dominant and recessive modes of inheritance. No family showed a two-point Lod score or a multipoint Lod score of 1.0 or even larger under the assumed inheritance models. The maximum multipoint Lod score was 0.55 under the assumption of genetic heterogeneity, with the proportion of linked families of 29%. P values of greater than 0.05 were observed for all the multipoint NPL scores obtained.

**Abstract**

This study investigates the potential role of the major human histocompatibility complex (HMC) region located at chromosome band 19.21 as a significant susceptibility locus for Graves' disease among the Han population in northern China. We employed four highly informative microsatellite markers spanning this region to genotype DNA samples collected from blood in Liaoning Province. The resulting data were analyzed using both two-point and multipoint LOD scores under varying levels of penetrance, considering both dominant and recessive inheritance models, as well as scenarios involving genetic heterogeneity. Additionally, we conducted multipoint nonparametric linkage analysis.

The calculated two-point LOD scores (θ = 0) and multipoint LOD scores for each microsatellite marker were consistently less than -2 across all tested markers, penetrance levels, and modes of inheritance; none of our families exhibited a two-point LOD score that reached or exceeded one. Under the assumption of genetic heterogeneity, a maximum multipoint LOD score of -0.55 was observed, indicating a proportion of linked families of approximately 28.9%. Furthermore, all multipoint nonparametric linkage scores calculated yielded p-values greater than 0.05. These findings suggest that the HMC region at chromosome arm 19.3 is unlikely to be a susceptibility locus for Graves' disease among the Han population of northern China. However, our results do not exclude the possibility of linkage disequilibrium in this region. Further studies are necessary to fully elucidate the genetic basis of Graves' disease within the Chinese population.

--- 

This version ensures clarity, coherence, and adherence to academic writing conventions.

As those orders left my lips, the attacker’s ship became visible—a sleek, pointed vessel with a ring-like thruster array surrounding its rear. The enemy had warned us through the capsule. We would fight.

"Firing all port guns!"

"The guns have never been used before; they need time to prepare!"

"Fire torpedo tubes one and two!"

"Fired!"

The torpedoes struck an invisible shield, exploding and illuminating a pulsating blue barrier. A shield? This was something new.

"Reload, fire a torpedo—"

The bridge exploded, silencing me and the rest of the crew.

Regular reports ceased. Central command dispatched a scouting party of five corvettes, equipped with F.T.L. drives, only to discover the remnants of the Lopus scattered across kilometers.

The enemy’s name, however, was not unknown.

They called themselves "humans."

--- 

Feel free to make any further adjustments or let me know if you'd like additional changes!

human:
A beam broaches across the veil. The infinite black now illuminated for a vanishing second. No creatures, no captivating sights, not a piece of evidence to indicate any hospitable environment. The air was stranger still, similar to even the most deceptive freeze. Not the strongest being could hold fast amongst this wicked cold. 
 
 The entirety of the whole ordeal screamed of nothingness, a devoid terrestria of which man could not comprehend. Such silence would propel a monk to heights of relinquishment. Driving even the purely devout to transfer their allegiance. But the beam, a foreign entity to this neutrality, now began to expand the horizon with a rather dull tone. The pulsations quickened and the object was now in full view. The steel encapsulation, riddled with panels, protruding electrical flashes from it's hold. The iridescent monitor flashes, a signal of life and power come to before powering down. 
 
 This `` thing'', this `` machine'', was now fixed into the blackness. 
 
 And now, stepping from this beguiling contraption, amidst such vast nothingness, were perhaps three of the most unlikely creatures. A portly finger accompanying the gas. A pair of blue eyes, followed by a grizzled face. This weary frame peaks past the cracked entrance, those eyes caught in such grand mystery. It is a man. He slowly comes into frame, the only light casting from his bubbly helmet and the machine. He is wearing a suit not far from the minds of the torrent of sci-FI aficionados. The white paste of his suit covers his slightly overweight frame, yet there exists a whimsical confidence with his calculated moves. 
 
 He seems to be opening his mouth, his words will surely cause a revitalized purpose to strike it's way into this place of nothing. 
 
 `` Fuckin' hell lads! My bullocks are damn near gone!'' 
 
 A voice is heard through his headset. 
 
 `` What bollocks did ye have to begin with?'' 
 
 `` Fuck you thricely, Sherman!'' 
 
 He reaches down and readjusts the crotch of his suit. His cautious mind seems to have adjusted as he steps into the black. The ground retracts no light in return as he pounds on it with his inflated boots. His eyes wide as imaginable, he presses a panel near his wrist, labeled `` coms''. 
 
 `` How in the fuck.. M.C. Are you getting this? Lads come on out!'' 
 
 The entrance now a few feet from this unknown man, suddenly casts two others into the frame. They stand, all too similar to the other, wearing the same suits while seemingly eating quite less than their leader. One speaks through his helmet. 
 `` Aye, commander it is cold'' 
 `` Aye and a bit too dark perhaps too commander? 
 
 The commander looks back, a smile forging onto his 5-o-clock shadow. 
 
 `` Well Terry. If ye have n't fucking noticed there is fuckin' absolutely nothing here. Look down at what you're standing on mate, there is n't damn thing that should be holding us up.''
LLM_1:
A glimmer of light pierced the void, illuminating the desolate landscape for an instant. Beyond the faint glow, an eerie silence reigned, devoid of any signs of habitation or life. Even the hardiest being would have struggled to endure the biting cold, as unforgiving as the coldest of freezes.

This desolation screamed out a message of emptiness, of a terra firma that defied human comprehension. An unsettling stillness would be enough to test the resolve of even a devout monk, driving him to abandon his faith. Yet, in this sea of neutrality stood a lone intruder, its presence marked by the expanding light. As the pulsating glow intensified, it revealed a metallic monolith, adorned with electrical panels and an iridescence that flickered like a heartbeat. 

This "device", this "machine", stood motionless, imposing its metallic presence upon the nothing.

And then, like apparitions, three figures emerged from its shadows, their forms stark against the inky black backdrop. Their leader, clad in an imposing suit, strode forward with an air of authority, even as his eyes widened in wonder. Behind him, two companions trailed, similarly attired but with gaunt, almost spectral, features.

As he spoke, words tumbled forth in coarse, unrefined cadence: "Fucking hell, laddies! Me bollox are near done for!" A disembodied voice crackled through a comms device attached to his sleeve. "What bolloxs did you have in first place?" The speaker's retort was a curse, swiftly followed. Sherman's voice, distant and detached, countered, "Aye commander, 'tis a wee bit chilly." His companion, Terry, added, with equal detachment, "'Tis also a mite too black, perhaps?"

Their commander's eyes sparkled with amusement, despite the gravity of their situation. With a chuckle, one that threatened to freeze in his throat, this leader gazed back at his companions. In a tone devoid, for once,of humor, they said, 

"Well, if you haven't noticed, we're in rather a predicament here, aren't we?"
LLM_2:
A sliver of light split the dark—a fragile, trembling thing—spilling across a world that had long forgotten warmth. For just a breath, the wasteland flickered into view: a barren expanse of frost-scarred stone and shadow, stretching beyond sight like the ribs of some long-dead beast. Then silence again, thick and suffocating, as if the air itself refused to move. No wind. No echo. No sign that life had ever dared take root here.

And yet—cold enough to crack bone, still enough to unnerve gods—the place was not entirely empty.

At its heart stood an anomaly: a tower of metal rising from the void like a forgotten altar, humming with a pulse not its own. Veins of light coiled beneath its surface, flickering in erratic rhythm—blue, silver, violet—like something breathing under steel skin. Panels blinked in cryptic patterns, whispering secrets in a language of current and code. It did not belong. And it *was* watching.

From within its depths, three figures peeled away from the dark, stepping forward as though emerging from dream or memory. The first moved with deliberate weight, his boots crunching on frozen grit, his silhouette broad-shouldered beneath a suit too sleek for this forsaken place. His face—weathered, sharp—bore the tension of command, but his eyes betrayed awe. Behind him trailed two shadows in matching attire, their frames gaunt, their movements almost hesitant, as if unsure whether they were alive or already ghosts.

Then came the voice—rough, raw, cracking through the stillness like a struck match.

“Fucking hell, lads! Me bollocks are frozen solid!”  

A tinny reply spat from the comms unit stitched into his sleeve: *“What bollocks did you bring with you in the first place?”*

He growled, then laughed—a short, barking sound that vanished into the cold.

Sherman, quieter, squinting up at the monolith, murmured, “Aye, commander… bit nippy, innit?”

Terry, ever the poet, added, voice thin as ice, “And a mite too dark, maybe? Like standing inside a blind man’s nightmare.”

The leader turned slowly, scanning their faces—their pale cheeks, chattering teeth, the absurdity written in every shiver. A smile tugged at his lips, brittle but real. He exhaled, and the steam curled like a dying thought.

Then, soft now, almost gentle:

“Well. If it’s escaped your notice… we’re buggered, aren’t we?”

Not panic. Not quite. Just the quiet acknowledgment of a truth too vast to scream at. They stood at the edge of everything, wrapped in silence and starless night, with only each other—and the machine—to bear witness.

Scientists then theories that theses ley lines were auctualy the internet and that crimson star was really red, Reddit. LLM_1:
For centuries, a mystical figure has hovered above humanity, its presence a constant enigma. Until the dawn of time, this enigmatic entity was shrouded in mystery, with its count perpetually frozen at a reassuring zero – a testament to an age of innocence. But as the decades passed, particularly in that fateful decade of  the early 2000's and  2 thousands, something strange began to occur. A ticking, relentless as a heartbeat, marked the passage of each new moment. Some believed that when the count reached its zenith, catastrophe would strike, that  world's very fabric would unravel. However, as  December the thirty-first,  of two thousand twelve, tick away, nothing of note occurred. Instead, an eerie silence descended, punctuated by the steady, insistent beat of that enigmatical figure.

Archaeologists, driven by an insatiable curiosity, uncovered a long-forgotten prophecy. According to this ancient wisdom, invisible, ethereal pathways crisscrossed the globe, binding disparate cultures together in an intricate web. These mystical ley-lines, like the tender shoots of some ancient, cosmic tree, nurtured the very essence of human experience. Where these lines converged, in points of sacred confluence, crimson stars burst forth, their pulsing heartbeat synchronizing with the rhythmic tick of our enigmatcal figure.  Scholars proposed that this celestial phenomenon was, indeed, none other than the redemptive power of an internet that had grown, imperceptibly, to encompass the entire world. And so, it was that Reddit, bastion of modern wisdom and crucible of contemporary thought, emerged as that celestial, red star.

As the Reddit community poured forth its collective wisdom into the digital ether, patterns began, slowly, inexorably, emerge. Statisticians and number theorists, ever vigilant, noted a curious correlation: each time the mystic figure's count increased, posts concerning numbers and statistics, those most esoteric of topics, appeared on the platform. It was as if the ancient prophecy had, at last, been deciphered. Our enigamtical figure, far from being a harbinger of doom, was revealed to count the cumulative posts of those who dared to ponder the mysteries of numbers that towered above the mortal realm. Thus, mystery gave way to understanding, darkness to light, leaving us to wonder: what other secrets, hidden in plain sight, remain for us, modern seekers of truth, yet to uncover?

As he looked at the stats on the wall, it was all so staggering. A new blip came up. 
 
 ESTIMATE OF DEATHS THAT CAN BE DIRECTLY ATTRIBUTED TO PERSONAL RESPONSIBILITY. - BETWEEN 8000 AND 8500 
 
 Everyone turned looked at him. 
 
 `` Do n't feel so glum Slobodan.'' Joseph told him with a mock sympathetic look in his eyes. `` We ca n't all be in the big leagues.'' 
 
 `` Hey, look at it this way...'' Mehmed smiled at him with a sarcastic grin. `` You could call yourself king of the minor league!'' 
 
 He laughed. 
 
 They all laughed. 
 
 That was the worst thing about being one of histories monsters, the other monsters were so much bigger.
LLM_1:
As Sobotka gazed at his dismal record plastered on his office wall – a stark reminder of his shortcomings – the numbers danced before his very eyes like a macabre waltz. Suddenly, a new entry materialized, like an unwelcome guest at a funeral.

ESTIMATE of fatalities directly linked to personal accountability: a chilling 8,000 to 9,500 souls lost

The room fell silent as all eyes turned to him, their expressions a mix of disdain and pity.

"Cheer up, Svatopluk," Joseph said with an air of mock benevolence, his gaze tinged with irony. "Not everyone can play with the A-list."

Mehmed chimed in with his signature sarcasm, offering a wry smile. "'You're the undisputed champion of Little League, isn't that something to brag about?'"

Sobotkas' lips curled into a faint smile, releasing a dry, mirthless laugh.

Their collective chuckle hung in mid-air like the faint scent of smoke, an ominous reminder that even the most monstrous of creatures can be dwarfed by those who came before. Being one such legendary horror was a heavy burden to bear, with its own set of monstrous peers that loomed large in history's shadow.
LLM_2:
Sobotka stared at the wall where his failures hung like trophies of shame—each figure a cold, unblinking eye accusing him from the page. The numbers shimmered in the dim light, twisting into grotesque patterns, as if mocking him with their precision. And then, without warning, a new line scrawled itself into existence—ink bleeding onto the parchment like a wound opening fresh.

**Estimated fatalities attributable to direct personal responsibility: 8,000–9,500 lives extinguished**

Silence swallowed the room whole. Heads turned. Not with curiosity, but with the slow, deliberate judgment of vultures assessing carrion. Their faces offered no comfort—only the brittle alloy of scorn and sorrow, polished smooth by years of whispered legend.

Joseph broke the quiet first, his voice dripping with false warmth, like honey laced with arsenic.  
“Cheer up, Svatopluk,” he said, tilting his head with theatrical sympathy. “Not all of us are built for the grand stage. Some are meant for… smaller tragedies.”

Mehmed leaned forward, elbows on knees, a serpent’s grin playing across his lips.  
“At least you reign supreme in the minors,” he drawled. “Champion of the little leagues. That’s got to count for something, hasn’t it?”

A smile flickered at the corner of Sobotka’s mouth—thin, bloodless, devoid of joy. It cracked across his face like a fissure in dry earth, and from it escaped a laugh so hollow it might have been dug up from a grave.

The others joined in, their laughter rising like smoke from a pyre—thin, acrid, lingering just long enough to stain the air. It was the sound of kinship among monsters, a brotherhood forged in atrocity. For in this shadowed pantheon, even the unspeakable were measured, weighed, and found wanting beside those who had carved deeper scars into time.

To stand among them was to wear a crown of ash.  
And Sobotka?  
He wore it well.

human:
The framework combines multiple state of the art methods in order to solve a specific and very challenging task.
It is interesting work in that there are several challenging subtasks that needed adaptation from their original publications to this kind of dental data which all come with their own challenges and hyper parameters (starting from the deformable registration to an atlas and the semantic segmentation to generate the input data).
However I am missing a novelty which is transferrable to other kind of data than this explicit application. I believe that this work is very valuable and of significant importance in the field of digital dental identification, but I am not convinced that it entails enough novelty from an ML perspective that is of general purpose to other fields of application. (If the authors can point out a novelty which is of a broader interest apart from dental identification, then this will also have to be reflected in the broad societal impact.) As the framework consists of many subtasks, there is only little space to provide all details needed for reproducibility in a conference paper like this and I believe a journal which is in theme closer to the paper’s application would be a more suitable publishing channel.

Questions to address:


It is unclear to me how the baseline experiments were conducted which are presented in Table 2. What exactly was done for e.g. ResNet-34+reconstruction, or ResNet-34+triplet, etc.? What was the pipeline for one such experiment?

I have some questions regarding the dataset. The paper says that UFBA_UESC was used to pretrain the mask-RCNN (line 132) for the semantic segmentation step to locate the teeth. Later, for the benchmark construction, the DNS Panoramic dataset is used as a training set. In [50], in which the DNS Panoramic dataset is introduced, it says that the original dataset, named “UFBA-UESC Dental Images data set” (published by Silva et al., ‘“Automatic segmenting teeth in x-ray images: Trends, a novel data set, benchmarking and future perspectives”, 2018) was modified by Jader et al. (“Deep instance segmentation of teeth in panoramic x-ray images”, 2018) to allow for instance segmentation, resulting in the dataset named “UFBA-UESC Dental Images Deep”. Silva et al. in [50] (“A study on tooth segmentation and numbering using end-to-end deep neural network”, 2020) then modified “UFBA-UESC Dental Images Deep” further, resulting in the “DNS (Detection, Numbering, and Segmentation) Panoramic Images”, which in turn was used as a training set in the proposed publication. So I wonder in what ways the UFBA_UESC dataset used for pretraining in the mask-RCNN step differs from the DNS dataset used for the overall training, and if the pretraining - in case of a big overlap of the two datasets - has much/any impact?

What size are the images in pixels and how do they need to be resized to fit the CNN encoder which was pretrained on RGB ImageNet images?
Is the atlas publicly available to which the images get registered?

Regarding the addition of the three types of loss in the final objective function: are they all of the same magnitude, or is one of the loss terms dominating over the other two?

This paper considers the problem of learning an image representation for few-shot learning without using image labels during training. This is a well-motivated problem since (as the paper points out) learning such a representation using "episodes" of low-shot learning problems as examples may require a large amount of annotated data. The paper proposes an iterative algorithm which alternates between clustering the images using the current model and updating the model using the clusters as "pseudo-labels". This approach is not particularly elegant as there is no clear objective being optimized, but it may nevertheless be effective. One main claim of the paper is that the iterative nature of this process is key to the success of the algorithm. The choice of model is a multi-layer conv-net which is trained using SGD (Adam). The paper investigates both triplet (with and without hard negatives) and "prototype" losses for learning the model parameters. To find clusters, the paper adopts the DBSCAN algorithm using the Jaccard similarity of the k-reciprocal neighbour sets.

I am not aware of other papers that use self-supervised learning to obtain a representation which is specifically suitable for few-shot learning via nearest-neighbour classification. As is noted in the paper, the absence of supervision during training more closely resembles the scenario of few-shot learning in biological systems.

The design decisions are well motivated throughout the paper.

The appendices are high quality and make the paper much more complete. In particular: the method for choosing epsilon, the empirical study of the effect of epsilon and the discussion of the behaviour of the cluster sizes as training proceeds.

Principal concerns:

(1.1) The proposed approach is particularly similar to DeepCluster (Caron et al.). Besides the use of a different clustering algorithm, it seems that the main high-level difference is the use of "episodic training", in which the algorithm is trained to compare examples to a query example, rather than to classify single examples. I would have preferred to see a comparison to non-episodic training. (It might be necessary to train a linear classifier on top of the final feature representation rather than simply build a nearest-neighbour classifier, but still this is convex, cheap and even closed-form in the case of least-squares regression.)

(1.2) While the algorithm has been demonstrated on real images in the Market1501 dataset, it would have been much more convincing to see it demonstrated on a more widely-used dataset for few-shot learning such as Mini-ImageNet.

(1.3) There are several recent papers on unsupervised feature learning using self supervision, especially as an alternative to ImageNet-classification pre-training. There is no discussion of these approaches, yet they might perform better than the proposed algorithm, especially for tasks with real images. Some examples of such papers are:
- "Discriminative Unsupervised Feature Learning with Exemplar Convolutional Neural Networks"
- "Representation Learning with Contrastive Predictive Coding"
- "Unsupervised representation learning by predicting image rotations"
The literature on using auto-encoders to learn feature representations is also relevant.

Issues with details in the paper:

(2.1) The DeepCluster paper observed that non-negligible accuracy could be achieved using a randomly-initialized conv-net (12% when chance is 0.1%). This enabled the use of clusters as pseudo-labels. Is a similar effect observed with your datasets and random initialization?

(2.2) For large datasets, the clustering algorithm might be prohibitively expensive? It would be useful to discuss the complexity of this algorithm.

(2.3) It would be interesting to see the effect of varying the frequency of the clustering during training (i.e. how many gradient steps are taken before updating the clustering).

(2.4) It is concerning that the accuracy drops sharply as \rho increases [6, 7, 8]*10^-5 in Table 4.

(2.5) It is stated that batch-normalization at the network output helps prevent over-fitting. Why? My intuition is that it would be more helpful for avoiding regions of the loss function which have a small gradient magnitude. What happens if you remove it?

(2.6) What is the test time procedure? Do you use the mean feature when there are k > 1 shots (even for the network trained with the hinge loss)? Do you L2-normalize the representation vectors?

(2.7) It seems potentially brittle to use hard negatives in the triplet loss with pseudo-labels? If the labels were wrong, then the hard negatives might not really be negatives. Nevertheless, this does not seem to be an issue, at least with these datasets.

(2.8) There are no error-bars anywhere in the paper.

Minor comments:

(3.1) Tables 3 and 4 would be easier to interpret if plotted on an axis.

(3.2) The word "concurrently" suggests that the clustering and the training are performed simultaneously. I would prefer "alternating".

(3.3) A grammatical review of the paper is required. For example in the abstract: "to a large extent (extend) and approaches the performance of (to the performances of) supervised methods".

(3.4) Remember to use \log and \max in latex to improve the appearance.

---

This article presents a novel approach to learning image representations in few-shot learning scenarios without relying on annotated data during training. The problem is well-motivated: conventional episodic training frameworks often require substantial amounts of labeled data to simulate few-shot tasks, which may not be practical in real-world settings. To address this, the authors propose an iterative self-supervised learning algorithm that alternates between clustering images based on current model representations and updating the model using these clusters as pseudo-labels. Although the method lacks an explicit global optimization objective, it demonstrates empirical effectiveness, suggesting that such co-evolutionary dynamics between representation and clustering can yield meaningful feature spaces.

A central claim of the work is that this iterative refinement process is critical to the success of the proposed method. The framework employs a multilayer convolutional neural network trained via stochastic gradient descent (using both SGD and Adam optimizers). Both triplet loss and prototype-based loss functions are explored, including variants of triplet loss with and without hard negative mining. For clustering, the density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) is applied to identify groups based on the similarity of *k*-reciprocal nearest neighbor sets. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this represents the first application of self-supervised learning specifically tailored for nearest-neighbor classification in few-shot recognition—a notable contribution.

The biological plausibility of unsupervised few-shot learning is also highlighted, drawing parallels between the absence of explicit supervision in training and natural learning systems. This perspective adds conceptual depth to the motivation behind the design choices, which are generally well-justified throughout the paper.

Furthermore, the supplementary material is comprehensive and strengthens the overall rigor of the study. It includes a principled method for selecting the DBSCAN epsilon parameter, an empirical analysis of its impact on performance, and a detailed examination of cluster size evolution over the course of training.

Despite these strengths, several concerns merit attention:

1. **Relation to Prior Work**: The proposed approach bears strong resemblance to DeepCluster (Caron et al.), differing primarily in the use of *episodic-style training*, where the model learns to match examples against a query rather than performing categorical assignment. While the omission of a linear classifier atop the final feature representation distinguishes the setup, a direct comparison with non-episodic variants—particularly through evaluation using a nearest-neighbor classifier on features from standard self-supervised methods—would strengthen the claims. Such comparisons could clarify whether the benefits stem from the specific architecture, the training protocol, or the clustering mechanism itself.

2. **Dataset Limitation**: The experiments are conducted on the Market-1501 dataset, which, while realistic, is not a standard benchmark for few-shot image classification. Evaluation on widely adopted few-shot learning benchmarks—such as Mini-ImageNet or Tiered-ImageNet—would enhance the credibility and generalizability of the reported results.

3. **Comparison with Recent Self-Supervised Methods**: Several recent advances in unsupervised representation learning have shown strong performance in downstream classification tasks and could serve as important baselines. These include exemplar-based CNNs (*Discriminative Unsupervised Feature Learning with Exemplar Convolutional Neural Networks*), contrastive predictive coding, and rotation prediction (*Unsupervised Representation Learning by Predicting Image Rotations*). Additionally, autoencoder-based approaches remain relevant for feature learning. A discussion or comparison with such state-of-the-art self-supervised techniques would better position the proposed method within the broader landscape of representation learning.

4. **Random Initialization Baseline**: The observation that non-trivial accuracy (e.g., 12% vs. chance level of 10%) can be achieved even with randomly initialized networks suggests that certain structures in raw ConvNet features may facilitate initial clustering. This phenomenon—also noted in prior work like DeepCluster—raises questions about the relative contributions of architectural bias versus learned structure in early-stage pseudo-labeling.

5. **Computational Complexity**: DBSCAN’s runtime complexity grows significantly with dataset size, potentially limiting scalability. A discussion of computational cost—both per iteration and overall—is warranted, especially given the need to recluster frequently during training. Approximate or scalable clustering alternatives might be worth considering.

6. **Clustering Frequency**: The frequency at which clustering is updated during training (i.e., number of gradient steps between reclustering) likely influences convergence and performance. An ablation study examining this hyperparameter would provide valuable insight into the stability and sensitivity of the method.

7. **Sensitivity to $ ho$ Parameter**: As shown in Table 6, performance drops sharply with increasing values of $ ho$, indicating high sensitivity to this threshold. A more thorough analysis of this behavior—possibly linked to cluster quality or label noise—would improve understanding of the method's robustness.

8. **Role of Batch Normalization**: The observation that batch normalization at the network output helps prevent overfitting—potentially by regularizing the model away from flat regions of the loss landscape with small gradient magnitudes—is intriguing. Further investigation into how normalization shapes the geometry of the feature space could offer deeper theoretical insights.

9. **Test-Time Inference Protocol**: The test-time procedure requires clarification. Specifically, when evaluating in $k$-shot settings ($k > 1$), is the mean feature vector used for classification—even for models trained with hinge loss? Additionally, are the representation vectors L2-normalized before computing similarities? These implementation details can significantly affect performance and comparability.

10. **Robustness of Hard Negatives with Pseudo-Labels**: Incorporating hard negatives in triplet loss with noisy pseudo-labels may introduce instability. If cluster assignments are incorrect, hard negatives risk being false positives, thereby degrading training signals. A discussion on the trade-off between mining informative samples and maintaining label reliability would be beneficial.

11. **Reporting of Results**: All experimental results should be reported with standard errors or confidence intervals across multiple runs to ensure statistical validity and reproducibility.

**Minor Suggestions**:

- Figures corresponding to Tables 5 and 6 would enhance interpretability; plotting trends over variables such as $\epsilon$ or $ ho$ could reveal patterns not immediately apparent in tabular form.
- The term "concurrent clustering/training" may misleadingly imply simultaneity; "alternating" or "iterative" clustering and training would more accurately reflect the methodology.
- The manuscript would benefit from careful proofreading to correct minor grammatical and stylistic issues. For example, phrases such as “to large extent” should be corrected to “to a large extent,” and “approches the perforrmance” should read “approaches the performance.”
- In LaTeX formatting, mathematical functions such as logarithms and maxima should use `\log` and `\max` for proper typesetting and improved readability.

---

In summary, the paper proposes a conceptually interesting and potentially impactful method that bridges self-supervised learning and few-shot recognition. With additional experiments, clearer exposition, and more rigorous benchmarking against contemporary baselines, the work could make a significant contribution to the field.

---

The last body fell. Hopefully for the final time. I wanted so badly to stop, to just let the snow cover me. But I did n't have long left anyway, that thought was punctuated by a fit of coughs. The crunch of snow beneath my boots resumed. I did n't bother praying to the gods for they had already forsaken me. 
 `` Always one to write us off are n't you''. 
 Great. The visions had started again. 
 `` I already told you I'm not an hallucination, and if you would listen to me I could help you.'' 
 I kept walking. She floated after me. 
 `` Fine then, you'll die alone out here just like-''. 
 `` LIKE WHO? LIKE HER? I LISTENED TO YOU ONCE AND IT COST ME EVERYTHING''. 
 My words echoed off the mountains. 
 I unclenched my fists and countined walking. 
 Arial floated into view. `` I-I'm sorry. I went to far, I did n't know that would happen. I'm not omnipotent, I'm not early smug enough.'' 
 I ignored her and kept walking. 
 I could hear the sounds of those things gaining on me. 
 `` I could tell you what they are.'' 
 It did n't matter what they were, it did n't matter how many there were. 
 I would n't stop until he was dead.

The final body lay motionless in the drift. For what felt like the last time, a morbid hope flickered within me – that the relentless snowfall might soon claim me, silencing the desperate coughing fits that wracked my chest. Yet, even that respite was short-lived, as the crunching of boots through the frozen landscape resumed, an unyielding reminder of my dwindling time.

"Always so quick to dismiss us, aren't they?" a voice whispered, laced with a mix of sorrow and accusation.

A new cycle of visions began to unfold, like a dark, maddening tapestry. "I've told him, time and again – I am no figment of his fevered imagination. If only he'd listen, perhaps I might help him escape this abyss."

As I trudged forward, her ethereal form floated alongside, refusing to depart. Her words dripped with an undercurrent of guilt. "'I'm fine, then. Die alone, just as you've always—'"

"LIKE WHO?" I spat, my words reverberating off snow-capped peaks. My voice trembled with anguish. 'YOU LISTEDNED ME ONCEN, AND I LOST EVERYTING.'"

The wind died down, leaving only the staccato beat of footsteps, punctuating the stillness. Arial materialized before me once more, contrition etched on her features. '"I-I went too far. That wasn't what I meant... I've never claimed to know everything. Smugness isn't my domain.'"

I pressed on, ignoring her apology, deaf to her words. In the distance, sounds like shuffling, scuttling footsteps began their relentless pursuit.

"I could warn you of what's coming," Arial's whisper floated on the wind.

Yet, in that moment, nothing else mattered. Not the twisted creatures bearing down on us. Nor the weight of numbers. All that mattered was the singular, all-consuming goal: to find him – and, with each step, bring him closer to his final reckoning. His demise was my only solace. And I wouldn't rest until it was achieved. Until he, too, lay still, lost in this desolate expanse. Forever. Finally. Alone. As I was. Would be. Will be, if I didn't keep moving. One step at a time – always. Only. Moving. Always. Onward. Now. Through this endless, soulless landscape. Where everything was nothing, yet nothing mattered more. Nothing else. Ever. Again. Never. After that. Last. Time. Which was coming. With each passing moment. Like this. Every step. Further. From the world. Into the nothing. Beyond. Without end. Or beginning. Any. More. To keep. Walking. Because. This. Is. How. It. Ends. Here. Today. Tomorrow. When. There. Are. No. Other. Steps. Left. Then. Stop. Won't. Move. Can't."

The competition is set to commence in September, with Oduba among the talented contestants aiming for the top prize. Fans can track Oduba’s progress by following @bbcentertainments on Twitter and Instagram or by reaching out via email at entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

Although their efficacy is currently studied in graft-versus-host disease, their effect on alloreactivity in solid organ transplant patients is unknown. In this study, the immunosuppressive effect of MSC on recipient anti-donor reactivity was examined before and after clinical kidney transplantation.Anti-donor reactivity was established in pretransplant and posttransplant mixed lymphocyte reactions (MLR) of 14 living-kidney donor-recipient pairs. MSC from donors and third-party controls were added to the MLR in a ratio of 1:5.MSC were isolated from donor perirenal fat and showed multilineage differentiation potential and the capacity to inhibit lymphocyte proliferation. The immunosuppressive effect of MSC was dose dependent and mediated by cell-membrane contact and soluble factors, including interleukin-10 and indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase.Donor-derived MSC significantly inhibited the recipient anti-donor reactivity before and 1 month after transplantation. This effect was independent of human leukocyte antigen background of MSC. Flow cytometric analysis showed that MSC inhibited the proliferation of CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocyte subsets in pretransplant and posttransplant donor-directed MLR, whereas MSC had no effect on B- or natural killer-cell proliferation.

**Abstract**

The immunomodulatory functions of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) are well characterized, particularly in relation to graft-versus-host disease. However, their role in modulating alloreactivity in solid organ transplantation remains underexplored. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of donor-derived MSCs on recipient anti-donor reactivity in both pre- and post-transplantation settings.

Mixed lymphocyte reactions were performed using samples from 13 living-kidney donor-recipient pairs to assess anti-donor reactivity. Donor MSCs, isolated from perirenal adipose tissue, were co-cultured with recipient lymphocytes at a 5:1 ratio. Results demonstrated that donor-derived MSCs possessed multilineage differentiation capacity and mediated immunosuppression via both cell-contact mechanisms and soluble factors, including interleukin-10 and indoleamine-2,3-dioxygenase. Importantly, donor MSCs significantly suppressed recipient anti-donor reactivity both before and after transplantation, irrespective of human leukocyte antigen matching. Flow cytometric analysis indicated that this suppression was specific to CD4⁺ and CD8⁺ T lymphocyte subsets, with no observed effect on B cell or natural killer cell proliferation.

These findings underscore the potential therapeutic utility of donor-derived MSCs in mitigating alloreactivity in solid organ transplantation.

human: The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools were subscription schools that typically held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students were Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes were taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students were charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and didn't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman who had traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust to obtain a teaching certificate. With the help of an assistant teacher, Mrs. Farley, Raymond was responsible for teaching 50 to 60 students each day out of the 81 students enrolled at the school. Sarah Raymond was paid at a rate of $125 per month, and Mrs. Farley was paid $75 per month. There were no textbooks used in the school. In their place was an assortment of books brought in by various emigrants. Sarah quit teaching the following year, but would later become the Madison County superintendent of schools.

### A New Era in Montana’s Education: The Birth of Public Schools

On a brisk April morning in 1864, a significant milestone in Montana's educational history was marked by the establishment of the Montana Territory through the United States government’s Organic Act. Even before the ink had dried, families were drawn to this expansive and rugged landscape, lured by the promise of new opportunities. As settlers arrived, a network of subscription schools began to emerge, often taking root in the welcoming homes of local teachers. These early educational institutions primarily served Indian children and young residents of Fort Owen, where the government had established its presence.

In the bustling town of Virginia City, one of these subscription schools was founded by Thomas Dinsdale, who charged students a modest fee of $17 per week. Meanwhile, other areas of the territory were also taking steps toward formal education. The school at Fort Owen, led by Mr. Robinson since 1862, offered classes that, although brief, were a crucial step toward developing a more organized education system.

As time progressed, Montana's legislative assembly convened to lay the groundwork for public education. In a pivotal year, provisions were enacted allowing counties like Madison to levy taxes specifically for educational purposes. This legislative change enabled Madison County to establish its first public school in Virginia City.

Originally slated to open in January, the school’s inauguration was delayed due to harsh winter weather, but it finally commenced in March 1866. The inaugural academic year extended into August, proving to be a challenging yet formative experience. A key figure in this endeavor was Sarah Raymond, a mere 15 years old at the time, who arrived in the town after a taxing journey by wagon train. Undaunted by her youth, she pursued certification and successfully passed a demanding examination conducted in her own home, all while paying a substantial fee in gold to obtain her teaching credentials.

With the support of her trusted colleague, Mrs. Farley, Sarah faced the formidable challenge of teaching a large cohort of students—upwards of thirty—during that first year. Her schedule was filled with lesson planning, instructional duties, administrative responsibilities, and personal commitments. Despite the demands of her role, Sarah received a generous monthly salary of $60, while Mrs. Farley earned a respectable $40. However, even with these resources, textbooks were notably absent, and students relied on donated materials from various settlers, exemplifying their determination and resourcefulness.

Although Sarah’s time at the historic school concluded the following year, her influence endured. Her exceptional leadership soon led to her appointment as Madison County Superintendent, a role that highlighted her steadfast commitment to public education. The year 1866 marked the beginning of a transformative journey for both Sarah and Montana as they navigated uncharted waters, fueled by an unwavering hope for the future. While the early days of education in Montana were far from perfect, they represented vital initial strides toward the establishment of an educational system that continues to evolve to this day.

**Polished Academic Abstract:**

This study aims to evaluate and compare the economic efficiency of varenicline versus nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) in supporting smoking cessation across four European countries: Belgium, France, Sweden, and the United Kingdom. A Markov cohort simulation model—the Benefits of Smoking Cessation on Outcomes (BENESCO) model—was employed to project long-term health outcomes and cost-effectiveness. The model simulated incidence rates for four major smoking-related diseases: lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, coronary heart disease, and stroke. Health outcomes were measured in terms of life years gained and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), while incremental cost-utility ratios (ICURs) were calculated from a lifetime perspective.

Efficacy data were derived from a randomized, open-label clinical trial with a 1-year follow-up; the continuous abstinence rate at Week 52 was 25.4% for varenicline compared to NRT. Results indicate that, in all countries studied, smoking cessation using varenicline was associated with reduced smoking-related morbidity and mortality relative to NRT. The number of morbidity cases avoided per 100 smokers attempting cessation ranged from 6.0 in the UK to 8.8 in Belgium. QALYs gained per smoker were estimated at 22.0 in Belgium, 18.6 in France, 29.0 in Sweden, and 22.2 in the UK.

In the base-case analysis, varenicline dominated NRT (i.e., was both more effective and less costly) in all countries except France. In France, the incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) for varenicline versus NRT was €28,030 per life year gained, falling within an acceptable range for cost-effective interventions.

human:
Irfan Faiz, 55, from Pakistan, who gave his address in court as Oxford Street, Oldham, was held at Leeds Bradford Airport on 18 September.
The Pakistan International Airlines pilot was about to fly to Islamabad.
Sentencing him at Leeds Crown Court, Mr Justice Coulson QC said Faiz had committed a "very serious offence".
Faiz had been charged with carrying out an activity ancillary to an aviation function while impaired by drink.
The court heard he gave an initial reading of 41 microgrammes of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath on a police officer's handheld device.
The legal limit for driving a car is 35 microgrammes, but for flying in the UK it just nine.
He later gave a reading of 28 microgrammes, the court was told.
Faiz told police he had consumed three quarters of a bottle of whisky before the flight, which was due to depart at 22:10 BST.
However, he said he had stopped drinking at about 03:00.
Faiz was an experienced and well-respected pilot with 25 years' experience and an unblemished record, the court was told.
His barrister, Paul Greaney QC, told the court his client was not a heavy drinker but was under a lot of stress at the time because of a kidnap threat against his family.
The court heard the defendant is from a prominent family in Pakistan.
Mr Greaney told the judge that, despite being an experienced pilot, Faiz was not aware of the rules about drinking and flying in the UK.
Mr Justice Coulson said he was "astonished" to hear pilots regularly flying out of the UK were not aware of the rules about alcohol consumption, which are based on the amount of alcohol present in the body.
It was "extraordinary" that the rules in Pakistan only stated there should be a 12-hour gap between "bottle and throttle", no matter how much the pilot had drunk, the judge said.
He added: "This is a very serious offence. If he had not been stopped, he would have flown the aircraft to Islamabad. That could have had potential catastrophic consequences.
"Many people find flying a difficult and nervous ordeal at the best of times. They need to have absolute confidence in their safety and security."
In a statement, a spokesman for Pakistan International Airlines said "further action" would be taken against Faiz once he had completed his sentence in the UK.
"The maximum sentence is termination from service," he said.

# Pakistani Pilot Receives Warning After Alcohol-Related Arrest in UK

A veteran Pakistani pilot has been formally cautioned after being detained for trying to board a flight while exceeding the legal alcohol limit. Irfaan Faize, a pilot with 25 years of unblemished service, was sentenced in a UK court in September for reportedly drinking heavily before a scheduled flight to Islamabad.

Evidence presented at Leeds Crown Court earlier this month showed that Faize’s initial breathalyzer reading was six micrograms above the legal limit. He later stated he had stopped drinking around 3 a.m., but a follow-up test measured his alcohol level at nearly 30 micrograms per 100 milliliters of breath.

Prosecutors argued that Faize’s conduct endangered public safety, emphasizing the seriousness of the violation. His defense team countered that the episode was an out-of-character lapse driven by stress related to a kidnapping threat against his family. They also noted that, despite his experience, Faize was unfamiliar with UK aviation alcohol rules—unlike in Pakistan, where pilots must only wait 12 hours between drinking and flying.

The presiding judge, Mr. Justice Coulston, remarked on the surprising lack of awareness among some UK-based pilots regarding strict flight crew alcohol limits. “It is extraordinary that a pilot would not know that nine micrograms is the legal threshold for flying in this country,” he stated during sentencing.

Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) has pledged to take further disciplinary action once Faize completes his sentence in the UK. In an official release, the airline suggested dismissal as a possible outcome. A PIA representative confirmed, “We will take additional steps after our pilot serves any sentence.”

As global dependence on air travel grows, this case underscores the vital importance of strict safety compliance and improved regulatory education. Ensuring passenger safety relies on the unwavering professionalism of flight crews—making any breach of protocol a matter of serious consequence.

human: Post-resuscitation syndrome leads to death in approximately 2 out of every 3 successfully resuscitated victims, and myocardial microcirculatory dysfunction is a major component of this syndrome. The aim of this study was to determine if glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) improves post-resuscitation myocardial microcirculatory function.Ventricular fibrillation (VF) was induced electrically in 20 anesthetized domestic swine (30-35 kg). Following 8 min of untreated VF, animals were resuscitated with aggressive advanced cardiac life support (ACLS). Animals were blindly randomized to receive a continuous infusion of either GLP-1 (10 pM/kg/min) or equal volume saline as placebo (PBO) for 4h, beginning 1 min after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). Left ventricular (LV) haemodynamics, LV ejection fraction, cardiac output, and coronary flow reserve (CFR) [using a standard technique of intracoronary Doppler flow measurements before and after intracoronary administration of 60 microg adenosine] were performed pre-arrest and at 1 and 4h post-resuscitation. In the present study, CFR is a measure of myocardial microcirculatory function since these swine had no obstructive coronary artery disease. Twenty-four hour post-resuscitation survival and neurological functional scores were also determined.CFR was significantly increased in GLP-1-treated animals, 1h (1.79+/-0.13 in control animals vs. 2.05+/-0.12 in GLP-1-treated animals, P = <0.05) and 4h (1.82+/-0.16 in control animals vs. 2.31+/-0.13 in GLP-1-treated animals, P = <0.05) after ROSC. In addition, compared to PBO-treated animals, GLP-1 increased cardiac output 1h after ROSC (2.1+/-0.1 in control animals vs. 2.7+/-0.2 in GLP-1-treated animals, P = <0.05). There was no statistically significant difference in survival between GLP-1-treated (100%) and PBO-treated animals (78%).

**Abstract**

This study examines the therapeutic potential of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) in improving myocardial microcirculatory function following resuscitation. Post-resuscitation syndrome (PRS) accounts for nearly two-thirds of fatalities among patients initially revived from cardiac arrest, with impaired myocardial microcirculation representing a central pathophysiological mechanism. Such dysfunction compromises cardiac capacity to accommodate elevated perfusion demands, thereby increasing morbidity and mortality.

In a randomized controlled trial, twenty anesthetized domestic swine (30–35 kg) underwent electrically induced ventricular fibrillation to simulate cardiac arrest. After eight minutes of untreated arrest, animals were resuscitated using aggressive advanced cardiac life support protocols. Subjects were randomly allocated to receive either continuous GLP-1 infusion (10 pmol/kg/min) or an equivalent volume of saline placebo, initiated one minute after return of spontaneous circulation. Cardiac performance was evaluated at baseline, one hour, and four hours post-resuscitation.

Coronary flow reserve, assessed via intracoronary Doppler flowmetry in the absence of obstructive coronary disease, served as the primary metric of microcirculatory function. GLP-1 administration significantly enhanced coronary flow reserve at one hour (control: 2.59 ± 0.12 vs. GLP-1: 3.06 ± 0.12, *p* < 0.04) and four hours post-ROSC (control: 2.32 ± 0.18 vs. GLP-1: 4.23 ± 0.13, *p* < 0.04). Additionally, GLP-1 treatment improved cardiac output at one hour relative to placebo (control: 2.1 ± 0.1 L/min vs. GLP-1: 2.7 ± 0.2 L/min, *p* < 0.05). No statistically significant difference in survival was observed between GLP-1–treated (100%) and placebo-treated (85%) animals.

These findings suggest that GLP-1 therapy may ameliorate post-resuscitation myocardial microcirculatory dysfunction and enhance hemodynamic recovery, supporting its potential role in mitigating PRS-related cardiac impairment.

Manny tipped the glass back one last time to allow the slowing stream of bourbon to flow down his awaiting throat. The solitary ice cube had long since melted along with his joyful demeanor. He left a ten dollar note on the table, hoping that it would cover the gouged prices that the club commanded. He was n't worried about a tip. 
 
 The front entrance was a cluster of people excited to be disappointed, seeking autographs of people whose careers would never extend beyond the 200 person capacity stages of Small Town, USA or the odd cruise ship from time to time. Alton Ridge was not a cruise ship. 
 
 The door out back warned of alarms, but those had been deactivated by the crowd who wanted to step outside for a smoke break. It was propped open by cardboard box when Manny found his way there. The usual clouds of smoke were absent. Instead, the air was clear save for a sour smell burning his nostrils. It also carried the sound of splashing. 
 
 As he passed through the doorway, he could see a familiar gentleman of about 60 years relieving himself on the brick walls of the club. Manny just shook his head and started to walk off down the alley. 
 
 `` Occupied!'' the old man shouted. `` Ca n't you read the sign?'' 
 
 Manny stopped and turned to face the man. It was Roger Class, one of the comedians that performed that night. 
 
 `` There was no sign, pal,'' he replied. `` This is an alley.'' 
 
 `` No you're in an alley,'' the man said, struggling with the longer runs of vowels. 
 
 He swung his hips around to face his presumed intruder. He burped out a belly laugh. Another stream found its way out, rapping against Manny's pant leg. 
 
 `` What the hell?!'' Manny yelled. 
 
 `` Urine an alley. I kill me.'' 
 
 `` Whatever. You drunk fuck,'' muttered Manny as he walked away, adding, `` And you suck on stage.'' 
 
 He heard a zipper and felt a hand grab him by the shoulder. The bastard never even washed his hands. 
 
 Manny spun his body and shoved the unwelcome hand with his forearm. He noticed that the zipper never checked for clearance; Roger was going to feel that in the morning. 
 
 `` What did you say?'' Roger snarled. 
 
 `` Jesus. Fuck off already.'' 
 
 `` Jesus? No, I'm not Jesus. He could turn water into wine. You know, the human body is mostly water. Scary thought is n't it?'' 
 
 `` Huh?'' Manny shrugged. 
 
 `` Must be a painful way to die.'' 
 
 `` I suppose.'' 
 
 `` Almost as painful as watching your once-promising career gasp its last breaths on a shitty stage in East Bumblefuck,'' Roger continued. `` Or getting skullfucked by a washed up comedian pushed to the edge by another heckling asshole.'' 
 
 `` I don't-'' Manny started. 
 
 Roger gave him a swift kick to the back of his leg sending Manny to his knees. 
 
 `` You're fucking crazy,'' Manny screamed. `` This is a sick fucking joke.'' 
 
 The comedian gave him an short, but studious glance. He reached into his pocket and pulled out a pair of gloves, which he tucked under one arm, and a pack of smokes. 
 
 As the old man lit his cigarette, he looked at Manny and said, `` Does it look like I'm joking?''
