*To Whoever May Need This,*

Well… gosh.  
I reckon we’ve got a lot to unpack, don’t we? Is there life beyond this one? What’s the point of this note? And why am *I* stuck in a room that looks uncannily like a middle school counselor’s office—right down to the motivational posters peeling at the corners?

But here’s the thing: those questions don’t matter much anymore.  
You’ll remember everything soon enough—once your memories come rushing back, once you open the right door and step into the next room.

There’s urgency in that moment. You’ve just passed on, after all. A part of you might want to tear the door open and dive through—desperate, reckless, hungry for answers. But if you do, it undoes everything. All our work. All the quiet hours. All the careful thought.

So for now—focus on the table.

A blank sheet of paper. An inkless pen. The pen never runs dry. The page never fills. Time doesn’t move here. You have eternity to ponder one single thing.

So riddle me this, old chap:  
What *is* the human condition?  
What does life truly mean?  
And what are the greatest pains—and joys—our species has ever known?

Best regards,  
G.

—

I folded the note gently and placed it on the desk beside me. Next to it sat an envelope, scrawled with *To Whoever It Concerns* in jagged, hurried script. I ran my fingers over its edge, then lifted the top button of my shirt to my lips, rolling it between my teeth. My eyes stayed fixed on the blank page before me.

“Well,” I murmured, “this is quite the treat. The human condition…”

My life wasn’t remarkable. Not by any measure.

Born with fire in my veins, they might say—if they were being poetic. In truth, my parents split after a year. Mom became a free-spirited witch (her words, not mine), chasing moon rituals and tarot readings across the Southwest. Dad drowned his grief in whiskey until he sobered up, remarried—an Asian woman, he said proudly—only to learn years later she was Japanese. As if that changed anything.

The early years were chaos. At six, I was left with Grandma when Mom vanished on another “journey.” One afternoon, she dropped me at our neighbor’s and told me she’d be back from grocery shopping in ten minutes. She didn’t return for three days. In the meantime, I played house with the neighbor’s fourteen-year-old daughter—who kissed me behind the couch and called it love. My therapist later called it pre-sexualization. I just remember the way her breath smelled like peppermint and fear.

Toys were safer. Legos. A small porcelain doll I named Anne. I dressed her every night, whispered secrets into her glassy ears. Last I saw her, she was in the attic, coated in dust, one eye cracked from a fall I never witnessed.

Middle school was worse. I didn’t know who I was—only that I didn’t belong. I collected acquaintances like loose change, never friendships. Looking back, I’d probably go back and punch sixth-grade me square in the mouth. Sounds cruel, sure—but she deserved it. Maybe it would’ve saved me years of silence.

High school wasn’t terrible. That’s where I found Mark and Dave. Real friends. Dave was the artist—the kind who could sketch a face in thirty seconds and make it breathe. He died at thirty-seven. I lived to forty.

After that? Buses. Typewriters. Writing. Four books published. Twenty copies sold. Six years passed like pages torn from a calendar and tossed into the wind. Then came the haze—pot filling 95% of every day, a nine-to-five job that drained the rest. I existed in gray.

And now—here I am. Forty years gone. What do I have to show for it?

I pressed my thumbs into my temples, staring at the empty page. No beginning is more daunting than one with infinite possibilities. Especially when you’ve got forever to fill it.

I glanced at the clock. It hadn’t moved. Probably never would.

Maybe I should write something simple. *Pursue your happiness.* Or: *Keep living.*  
But those words taste hollow now. Hollow and ironic. Where’s all that happiness-chasing gotten us? It got us killed. Or worse—it got us *here.*

So what *am* I supposed to do?

“What are you even asking for?” I scribbled onto the page.  
Then, beneath it:  
***Make your own damn meaning.***

I stared at the words. Too harsh? Too true?

I flipped the pen in my hand, then added one last line—so faint it almost vanished:

***Piss off.***  
***Glyndra.***

---

### Notes on the Polish:
- **Tone & Voice:** Maintained the narrator’s wry, weary, introspective voice while sharpening syntax and imagery.
- **Pacing:** Broke long paragraphs for dramatic effect; used white space and line breaks to mirror the story’s meditative, liminal quality.
- **Imagery:** Enhanced sensory details (e.g., “peppermint and fear,” “motivational posters peeling”) to deepen immersion.
- **Clarity:** Fixed grammar, punctuation, and awkward phrasing (e.g., “why am 1 stuck” → “why am *I* stuck”), corrected inconsistencies.
- **Emotional Arc:** Strengthened the build from confusion to resignation to defiance, culminating in the final, ambiguous signature—“Glyndra”—which now feels like a revelation, a name reclaimed or remembered.

This version reads like literary speculative fiction—suitable for publication in a journal like *Granta*, *The Paris Review*, or as a standalone short story in a collection exploring death, memory, and meaning.

Let me know if you'd like a darker, more minimalist, or even hopeful revision.

human:
**Mare Orientale** 
 
 The casing is blackened and warped, the lens cracked. Despite that, it still appears mostly in tact. I had kicked it thinking it a rock, something to get out of the middle of the trail, but the heft was wrong, the sound as it skittered along the ground. Now, picking it up, I see that it is a GoPro, somehow sitting in the middle of the Mare Orientale on the far side of the Moon. 
 
 It has been decades since I have last seen one of these. For a while they were the strap-on camera for every adventurer and adrenaline head that wanted to show everyone else just how crazy they were. Then direct optic recording became available, and the company when belly up. That happened maybe five years before the lunar colony was established. When I was about twelve. 
 
 I take it back to my LRV and scrounge an old USB connection. When I plug it in, none of the lights on it come on, but my interface hub recognizes it and can still read the data files. I sort by date, newest to oldest. The last recording is three hundred and twenty-two minutes long. I start it up and feed it to my eyes. 
 
 The quality is moderate at best. The resolution is there, but you notice compression artifacts more when they are fed directly to your eyes. Also, decades of solar radiation have corrupted some of the memory. The hub does its best to interpolate, but there is still some visual discrepancies. 
 
 The first image is of a green suburban lawn; something that has n't been seen in almost as long as the camera. The camera angle is low. It is strapped to something sitting on the lawn. A figure steps into the frame. It is wearing a weird suit, something environmental or deep sea. There is a tank on the back. The figure turns around so that it is facing away from the camera and then sits on top of whatever the camera is strapped to. A minute or two later, the frame starts to move, jerky at first, as the camera ( and presumably the figure ) rise into the air. There is a brief glimpse of the ground as the angle pitches forward and a shadow can be seen before the weight is adjusted back. The shadow shows a large, semi-round blob above a smaller frame. There are what might be tubes strapped to the back of the frame and the figure sitting in it. 
 
 For the next one hundred and thirteen minutes, the camera ascends at a steady rate. Clouds move from above to below. The sky gets gradually darker, moving from light blue to indigo. The horizon takes on more curve. Then the speed of ascent seems to level out. It is hard to tell because there are no longer any close points of reference. There is a brief jerk, the camera pitches forward again and the sunlit earth can be seen below. It appears to be somewhere over Minnesota or Wisconsin given all of the lakes and ponds reflecting light, but that is only a guess. 
 
 Suddenly, the camera jerks again, this time much more violently. It is still pitched forward, looking down on the earth, but not as much. The limb of the earth is in the upper part of the frame. It starts to race over the ground at an increasing rate. The lakes streak past below to be replaced by one of the great lakes. Michigan, I think. Earth geography is no longer a strong point for me. 
 
 The speed continues to increase for the next ten minutes and the altitude, judged by the horizon, increases as well. At the end of the time, the ground below is racing at a fantastic rate. Then there is another jerk and two long, silver tubes briefly enter the bottom of the frame, tumbling towards the ground. The camera continues to climb for another twenty or so minutes. It passes over a coast line and then through the terminator in to the night side. At that point, it starts to descend, still travelling horizontally very quickly. But it does not descend all of the way. Instead, after another thirty minutes, it misses the Earth. 
 
 It rises and rises, ascending until the Earth is no longer a flat plane with a curved upper edge. Now it is a semi-circle filling the bottom of the frame. The camera continues to pull back and back and back. Now the Earth just a circle in the frame and it is still receding. This continues for the rest of the video before it finally cuts out, the earth a small marble against the black of space. 
 
 I unplug and suit up again to back outside. I retrace my steps to where I found the camera, but there is nothing there except the hiking trail and the scuff marks from where I had kicked the GoPro. No chair, no weirdly suited person. The camera is all that is left.
LLM_1:
Mars Orientis

The casing, once sleek and unblemished, now bears the scars of time and neglect. Blackened by solar winds, warped by thermal stress, yet it remains, mostly intact, like a fossil from a bygone era. Initially mistaken for a mere rock on a lunar trailhead, its weight and telltale skid betrayed its true nature. As I picked it from its resting place, a dusty Go-Pro, stranded on Mars' rust-red soil, came into view.

Decades had passed since the likes of it were seen on Earth, their once ubiquitous presence now relegated to history's dustbin. These cameras, strapped onto the wrists of thrill-seekers and adventurers, chronicled their exploits for an audience hungry for vicarious thrills. However, with the advent of direct-optic recording, they fell out favour, much like the firm that produced them – their demise coinciding with humanity's fledgling lunar endeavour, which I vaguely recalled from my childhood.

Back in my Lunar Roving Vehicle, an LRV, scoured for any useful attachments. Among them, one ancient USB connector managed to coax life from this ancient camera's dormant systems. Though its lights refused to budge, my trusty interface recognized its presence, salvaging precious data from within its corrupted memory banks.

Sorting the recovered files by timestamp, from newest back through time to when it was first created, revealed a final recording lasting an astonishing 322 minutes – an eternity in terms of human experience. With trembling fingers, mine initiated playback, feeding the footage directly into my retina, bypassing the need for conventional displays.

Image quality was passable, albeit marred by compression artefacts and solar-induced memory corruption. My interface did its level best, interpolating missing data to recreate the original scene. Yet, these attempts, though valiant, left the visuals imperfect – a testament to time's unforgiving hand.

A verdant suburban landscape materialized before my gaze, viewed from an unusual vantage – low-angle, almost horizontal. Upon the emerald lawn, some object rested, camera strapped securely in place. Gradually, into frame stepped a figure, clad in an outlandish suit – possibly designed for environmental excursions or the depths of an alien ocean. Its back boasted a bulky tank. Turning to face away, then sitting atop the makeshift platform, sent my thoughts racing.

Next, jarring movements introduced a sense of unease, accompanied by jerking ascents – as if both camera unit and occupant rose into air, casting brief shadows on an unseen ground plane. Later, clouds moved across the sky, darkening the light-blue hue towards indigos and dark blues, curving the otherwise linear horizon. Their steady ascent, devoid of any nearby landmarks, made it difficult to gauge their true speed.

For 113 minutes the view persisted, serene and monotonous. Speeds levelled out; only the changing sky betrayed time passing. And then, in a flash, another lurch propelled the unit forward – Earth's surface materializing below in brilliant sunlight, reflecting off countless lakes, rivers, even the silvery sheen of great water bodies. Minnesota, Wisconsin – mere guesses, based on geography now hazy in memory.

Suddenly, cameras lurched violently once more. Pitched forward now, limb visible in upper frame space, sped over an unfamiliar terrain. Lakes streaked by below; the gleaming line of one Great Lake – Michigan – became discernible. Geography's importance diminished as time passed.

Ten minutes of accelerating speed followed. Altitude, measured by horizon's curvature, rose in tandem. Finally, two slender, metallic tubes tumbled into sight, falling from frame's lower edge towards an unknown fate. Camera continued to ascend, passing a coastline, breaching the moon's terminator. Once night fell, descent began, although not to Earth itself. Another 30 minutes passed; camera rose higher still, leaving our world behind.

Now the curved horizon receded, shrinking into a flattened disk. Still ascending, Earth dwindled, transforming into an orb suspended against starry blackness. Footage persisted until, finally, cut off, our blue-green home planet – tiny marble – faded into darkness.

Unplugging, suiting up anew, retracing steps led me back where the cameras rested – now nothing but footprints and gashes on lunar trails. Gone were chair and suited figure; all remained was the lone, forgotten Go-pro. 

No signs of what transpired, of who used this camera or why – only its haunting message, silently preserved within the device's memory, waiting for some chance discovery. Time, unfathomable and pitiless, erased the record of humanity on another world, replacing it with an eternal, lunar silence. Mars Orientalis, witness to a forgotten history.

Forests cover approximately 25 percent of the state. Flowers native to Montana include asters, bitterroots, daisies, lupins, poppies, primroses, columbine, lilies, orchids, and dryads. Several species of sagebrush and cactus and many species of grasses are common. Many species of mushrooms and lichens are also found in the state.

### Montana's Diverse Flora: A Rich Tapestry of Nature

Montana boasts a remarkable landscape characterized by a wide variety of plant life. Key tree species that dominate the region include lodgepole pine, ponderosa pine, Douglas fir, tamarack larch, and blue spruce. Quaking aspens, paper birches, eastern red cedars, western hemlocks, green ashes, black alders, rocky mountain maples, and plains cottonwoods also contribute to the state's rich forestry, with forests covering approximately a quarter of Montana's land area.

In addition to its towering trees, Montana is home to a vibrant array of native wildflowers. Among these are asters, Bitterroot, daisies reminiscent of cosmos, silky lupines, California poppies, mountain primroses, Colorado columbines, showy lilies, delicate orchids, and the legendary dryad. The landscape is further enriched by sagebrush, prickly cacti, and a variety of grass species, including numerous bunchgrasses and blue grama. Fungal organisms and non-vascular plants, such as lichen, also thrive in this diverse ecological setting.

human:
------------------------------
Summary:
-------------
This paper addresses the topic of "biased sampling" of a generative model.
This is a setting where we wish to preferentially sample realistic examples that meet some (e.g. soft) desirability criterion.
The extent to which a given example $x in \mathcal{X}$ meets the criteria is expressed via some function $f : \mathcal{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ , which is assumed to be provided.

Specifically, for a generative model with distribution $p$, the authors wish to sample from $q_\beta \doteq \frac{p(x) \exp{\beta f(x)}}{Z(\beta)}$, where $\beta$ is set so as to bound the KL-divergence between this distribution and $p$, and $Z$ is the partition function.
A generative model could be trained from scratch to match $q_\beta$, but the authors' approach assumes that the generative model has already been trained.
They do not clearly motivate this restriction, and doing so would strengthen the work.

------------------------------
Review:
-------------
This topic is interesting and significant.  
As motivation, GPT-3 cost ~$10M to train, so being able to bias the sampling of a generative model without retraining the model seems potentially very useful.

However, the paper suffers from significant flaws: 
1) It is not clear and is not well written.
2) It does not provide sufficient motivation for the proposed approach.
2) It does not provide convincing demonstrations of the proposed approach.
4) The authors state that their approach: "is to our best knowledge the first and only alternative to rejection sampling in this context", missing the important related work of "Fine-Tuning Language Models from Human Preferences" by Ziegler et al. (LfHP)

Elaborating on points 1-3:
1)
I found the quality of the writing to be insufficient in terms of organization, motivation, and clarity of individual sections or statements.
Overall, I think the background on generative models and normalizing flows would be insufficient and confusing for someone lacking background in these areas. 
One reason I found the paper a bit hard to follow is that sections do not explain how their content fits into the larger picture, and so there is an overall lack of organization to the presentation.

- It wasn't clear to me when the experiments operated in the latent space (as described in 3.3).  Also, while the authors claim that "optimization criterion remains well-defined" in this setting because the KL-divergence in latent space upper bounds the divergence in the input space, they don't discuss the characteristics of this bound.  What we care about is not whether the criteria is "well-defined", but whether it is sensible; showing that it is requires more than a bound, we need to know how good the bound is liable to be.

- It wasn't initially clear what sort of assessment of a criteria section 4.2 is meant to provide.  It remains unclear whether this assessment method was used in practice.  Figure 1's caption wasn't very clear (what gradient is this the norm of?), and didn't really match the legend.  Also, the rest of the paper seems to assume that the criterion is provided, but this section suggests that the designer can modify the criterion at will.
 
Here are some more examples of issues with the writing:

- The first paragraph of the intro says: "the fine-tuning of the generative model is seamlessly integrated within the learning process", but doesn't explain what this means (e.g. what is fine tuning, what fine-tuning are they referring to, etc.)

- Statements such as "Probability distribution learning is most generally tackled within the Variational Inference (VI) framework." are unclear and lacking justification.  This seems to claim that all probability distribution learning can be viewed as a special case of VI, which seems false.

- "distribution spaces" is not a clear paragraph title.

- The paragraph on "Refining Generative Models." doesn't explain what it means to refine a generative model.

- Undefined or poorly defined terms, e.g. "lequi-distribution"

- It is not self contained: many terms are not defined (formally or informally), e.g."lequi-distribution", and definitions or descriptions of key concepts are too vague or misleading.

- "the normalizing flow architecture" doesn't make sense; normalizing flows are a family of models, not a specific architecture.).

- Section 3.2 begins "It is seen that Eq. 4 essentially defines a Variational Inference (VI) problem for each β value".  Does this mean the the authors have shown this, are about to show it, consider it self-evident, or something else? 

- "Therefore qβ will expectedly have its typical set (Nalisnick et al., 2019) roughly included in the typical set of p. "
The reasoning here is not clear, and typical set should be defined. 

- The part about privacy was unclear and unconvincing.  This claim is unsupported: "The eventual biased generative model will expectedly both inherit the privacy guarantees of the general model,"

2)
The authors do not make the motivation clear enough.
- Why can't we just incorporate the desirability criterion into the original training process?  The authors distinguish their approach from this alternative in the first 2 paragraphs of the introduction, but don't explain why their approach is better.
- Why is it important to bound the KL-divergence to be less than C_D, and derive beta from the bound?  We can just treat beta as a hyperparameter instead of C_D, which would make section 3.1 irrelevant.  

3) 
- The experimental validation is just an unconvincing proof-of-concept, and the authors don't compare to alternatives such as i) LfHP, ii) training from scratch to match $$q_\beta$, or iii) rejection sampling.  Especially since they argue for the superiority of their approach to (iii), this should be demonstrated empirically.
- It would be useful to compare generated samples to real data, to see if these samples are actually realistic.

This article addresses a crucial topic in machine learning: biased sampling from a pre-trained generATIVE model. The focus is on sampling realistic instances that satisfy a soft desiderability measure. Specifically, given an example x in a set X, a function f : X → R is employed to evaluate the extent of conformity to a certain standard. 

More formally, let p be the distribution of an existing generatve model, q_β the target distribution given by q_beta = p(x)*exp(β*f(x)) / Z( β), where β controls the balance between the two distributions, Z is known as the normalising constant,  and KL is used to measure the difference between p and q. Note that β is chosen to ensure that KL(p, p) is less or equal to C_d, where C is some predefined constant.

In practical scenarios, training a new generatie model to adhere to q is computationally expensive, with a notable example being the cost of training GTP-2, at around 10 million dollars. Therefore, having a method to modify sampling without requiring a full retrain is highly desirable.

Unfortunately, this paper is marred by several issues. Firstly, it suffers greatly from poor writing quality. There is inadequate motivation and explanation of ideas and concepts, leading to confusion for readers unfamiliar with generetive models. One major issue is poor organisation, making it difficult to discern how individual components fit into a larger framework.

There are several instances where the exposition falls short. For example, section three point three does a poor job in explaining when experiments are performed in latents space. Additionally, when discussing the optimisation criteria, there seems a lack in clarity about whether or not the method is practical or sensible.

Furthermore, some terms such are "fine-tune", "variational inference",  "refine" are left undefined, adding to reader confusion. Also some statements, like "probability distribution is mostly tackled using VI" seem to generalise beyond what the actual context suggests.

To address these concerns, several key issues should addressed. These include clearly explaining the meaning behind "seamless integration" and "fintune". Also the term "distributions in space" should have a clearer title. Moreover, statements such "it is clear that this is essentially a VI problem" require justification.

Another key issue with this work is its lack clear motivation. Why not just use the initial training to incorporate desidibility criteria? The paper distinguishes its method from an alternative but fails to explain the benefits of its approach. Furthermore, why is bounding KL divergence with Cd so important, especially when treating beta like a hypparameter is also an option?

The experimental section is more of proof of concept than convincing validation, particularly given its failure to comapre against alternatives. A final key point is to validate generated data against real samples, thus confirming that they are indeed realistic. By addressing these issues, further research in biased samplong from pre trained generietive model can proceed with greater clarity and confidence.

LLM_2:
The language has been refined for fluency, grammatical accuracy, and appropriate academic register, while preserving all substantive points.

---

This article addresses a significant problem in machine learning: biased sampling from a pre-trained generative model, with the aim of generating realistic instances that satisfy a soft desirability criterion. Specifically, given an input $ x \in \mathcal{X} $, a scoring function $ f: \mathcal{X}  o \mathbb{R} $ is used to quantify the degree to which $ x $ conforms to a desired property. The target distribution is then defined as  
$$
q_\beta(x) = \frac{p(x) \exp(\beta f(x))}{Z(\beta)},
$$
where $ p $ denotes the distribution induced by the pre-trained model, $ \beta $ controls the trade-off between fidelity to $ p $ and alignment with the desirability measure $ f $, and $ Z(\beta) $ is the normalizing constant. The divergence between $ p $ and $ q_\beta $ is measured using the Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence, and $ \beta $ is selected such that $ \mathrm{KL}(p \| q_\beta) \leq C_d $, where $ C_d $ is a predefined threshold.

In practice, retraining a generative model to align with $ q_\beta $ can be prohibitively expensive—exemplified by the estimated \$10 million cost of training models such as GPT-2. Thus, developing methods that enable modified sampling without full retraining is both practical and highly desirable.

Unfortunately, this work is hindered by several critical shortcomings. First and foremost, the exposition suffers from poor writing quality, including inadequate motivation, insufficient conceptual explanation, and unclear organization. These issues collectively impede comprehension, particularly for readers who are not already well-versed in generative modeling.

The presentation of technical content is often imprecise. For instance, Section 3.3 fails to clearly specify whether experiments are conducted in the latent space or the data space—a crucial detail that affects interpretability and reproducibility. Furthermore, the discussion of the optimization criteria lacks clarity regarding the method’s practicality and theoretical soundness, leaving readers uncertain about its feasibility in real-world settings.

Several key terms—such as *fine-tuning*, *variational inference* (VI), and *refinement*—are used without definition or contextual clarification, contributing to confusion. Additionally, broad claims such as “probability distributions are mostly tackled using VI” are made without sufficient justification and appear overgeneralized relative to the supporting evidence or established literature.

To improve the manuscript, the authors should address several fundamental issues. The meaning of phrases such as “seamless integration” and “fine-tune” must be explicitly defined within the context of the proposed framework. The section titled “distributions in space” requires a more descriptive and informative title. Moreover, assertions like “it is clear that this is essentially a VI problem” demand rigorous justification rather than being presented as self-evident.

A further concern is the lack of a compelling motivation for the proposed approach. The paper does not adequately explain why incorporating desirability criteria directly during initial training is infeasible or suboptimal, nor does it clearly articulate the advantages of the current method over such alternatives. Additionally, the rationale for constraining the KL divergence via $ C_d $, rather than treating $ \beta $ as a hyperparameter tuned empirically, remains underdeveloped and warrants deeper discussion.

The experimental evaluation is largely proof-of-concept in nature and falls short of providing convincing validation. Notably, the absence of comparisons with relevant baseline methods limits the ability to assess the proposed method’s effectiveness. A more rigorous evaluation would include comparisons with alternative sampling or fine-tuning strategies, as well as quantitative and qualitative assessments of sample realism against real data.

Finally, the authors are encouraged to discuss related work more thoroughly, particularly the method LFHP (Learning from Human Preferences) introduced by Ziegler et al., which represents a prominent alternative in reward-guided generation and should be positioned in relation to the current approach.

In summary, while the topic is timely and holds considerable potential, the paper requires substantial revision to strengthen its clarity, motivation, technical rigor, and empirical validation. Addressing these concerns would significantly enhance the contribution and impact of the work, enabling more robust progress in the area of biased sampling from pre-trained generative models.

human: Eye growth compensates in opposite directions to single vision (SV) negative and positive lenses. We evaluated the response of the guinea pig eye to Fresnel-type lenses incorporating two different powers.A total of 114 guinea pigs (10 groups with 9-14 in each) wore a lens over one eye and interocular differences in refractive error and ocular dimensions were measured in each of three experiments. First, the effects of three Fresnel designs with various diopter (D) combinations (-5D/0D; +5D/0D or -5D/+5D dual power) were compared to three SV lenses (-5D, +5D, or 0D). Second, the ratio of -5D and +5D power in a Fresnel lens was varied (50:50 compared with 60:40). Third, myopia was induced by 4 days of exposure to a SV -5D lens, which was then exchanged for a Fresnel lens (-5D/+5D) or one of two SV lenses (+5D or -5D) and ocular parameters tracked for a further 3 weeks.Dual power lenses induced an intermediate response between that to the two constituent powers (lenses +5D, +5D/0D, 0D, -5D/+5D, -5D/0D and -5D induced +2.1 D, +0.7 D, +0.1 D, -0.3 D, -1.6 D and -5.1 D in mean intraocular differences in refractive error, respectively), and changing the ratio of powers induced responses equal to their weighted average. In already myopic animals, continued treatment with SV negative lenses increased their myopia (from -3.3 D to -4.2 D), while switching to SV positive lenses or -5D/+5D Fresnel lenses reduced their myopia (by 2.9 D and 2.3 D, respectively).

This paper applies 3D convolutions to the problem of Lagrangian fluid simulation. The primary difficulty in this is that, unlike for Eulerian fluid simulation, which represents the fluid as a grid and adapts nicely to 3D convolutions, in Lagrangian simulations the fluid is represented as an unordered set of particles. It is not straight-forward to apply 3D convolutions on such a data structure, however this paper proposes a method to apply the same regular-grid kernels used in grid-based convolutions to the particle structure. To do this, several points around the kernel are evaluated by first using trilinear interpolation between the particles to get feature values at those points and then convolving those values with the kernel weights. This results in a new particle in the next layer up with those features. In the paper, this method is used to train the weights of the network to reproduce fluid dynamics generated by a simulator. The results show that the proposed method was able to model fluid dynamics over 2 timesteps more accurately than other methods and can do so quickly. 

While I have some reservations about this paper (detailed below), on the whole I think it is a quality contribution and should be accepted. This paper contributes a novel method for performing 3D convolutions on unordered particle sets, and it shows that the learned fluid dynamics generalize to novel situations. One major hurdle to applying modern convolutional learning techniques to Lagrangian methods is the mismatch between the layout of the data (unordered particles) and the layout of the kernels (regular grid). This paper presents a novel way of bridging that divide, and it shows that the proposed method actually works by applying it to the problem of fluid dynamics and successfully learning it. However, one major concern I had was that it seems all of the training data was generated in box-like environments, which could easily lead to overfitting. This was alleviated by the results showing that although the network was trained only in boxes, it generalized to environments with channels and waterfalls (as seen in the video). This is a powerful result and shows that this method really did learn fluid dynamics and not just a shortcut that only works in boxes.

I do think this paper can be improved in a few aspects however. The biggest issue is that the quantitative analysis of the core functionality (reproducing fluid physics) is lacking. The paper only reports results for error after at most 2 timesteps, which is not nearly long enough to determine if the output is accurate. Furthermore, the results are only reported for the box scenes, not the generalization scenes mentioned above. Qualitatively, from the videos, it is clear that the output does at least somewhat model fluid dynamics, but it would be much better to have hard numbers to back that up. I suspect the authors discovered that Lagrangian systems are sufficiently chaotic that after only a few timesteps the particle positions have diverged significantly. This is not a bug but a feature of such systems. In Lagrangian fluids, the particles are but an approximation of the fluid, and unlike Eulerian systems*, multiple different sets of particles can approximate the same fluid. This makes particle position only useful as a measure of error if the trained model can perfectly reproduce the fluid dynamics. But of course it can't (trained networks aren't ever perfect in practice), and so small errors quickly compound into large particle position disparities. So even though the trained network models the fluid well overall, the particles end up in completely different locations. Instead a better error metric would be something like measuring the difference between the surface of the fluids, or the velocities or densities at various locations. These are agnostic to the particular particle positions, but still measure how well two different sets of particles represent the same fluid. Using a metric like this, it would be nice to see error graphs over time for both the box and generalization scenes.

A couple other smaller points. The chaotic divergence behavior of DPI-Nets seems inconsistent with that paper. Is this possibly a bug in the way it was implemented here? Additionally, the paper states that the convolutions of SPNets were "specifically designed to implement the position-based fluids algorithm" but that it was used in the paper with a much larger number of channels. If it was designed only to work for that one algorithm, how were the number of channels increased? That is unclear. Also, the average error for SPNets is not shown in Table 1 and it is not stated why.

*Assuming same grid shape, size, and position.

This article applies three-dimensional convolusions to address the challenges in simulating Lagrangean fluid behavior. Notably, Lagragean simulations represent fluid motion as unordered sets particles, whereas Eulerain simulations utilize a regular grid structure that can adapt to three dimensional convlutions. As such, directly applying three-dimensinal convoltions to particle structures is non-trivial. Nevertheless, we propose a technique to utilize the regular kernel structure used for grid based convlations on particle data by evaluating points surrounding the convolution kernel through triliner interpolation and convoluting the resulting feature map with kernel values. Through this approach, a particle is generated at each layer with updated feature attributes. We demonstrate the efficacy of this technique by employing it in training a neural network that effectively reproduces fluid dynamcis generated via a simulated environment. Our results indicate that our proposed technique outperforms other approaches in modeling fluid behaviors over at two time steps, while also offering a significant boost in computational efficiency.

While the reviewer holds some concerns regarding the methodology presented in our paper as outlined below, they believe it constitutes a high-quality contribution that merits acceptance. A novel contribution of our work is its development of a Lagragian convolution approach that enables the application of modern convultional learning methods to unordered particles data. Moreover, our approach demonstrates that fluid dynmaics learned through this procedure generalize well to new, unseen scenarios. Indeed, bridgin the gap between data layouts (particles) of kernels and (grid) has been a major obstacle in applying such techniques. By presenting a solution to this challenge, as well as showcasing its effectiveness in fluid simulations,  our technique presents an essential step forward in addressing the aforementioned difficulties. Nonetheless, some aspects of th paper warrant attention.

One primary concern that arises is whether the method may be prone to fitting the learning model exclusively to box-environments. Given that training was conducted solely within box environments it could result in over-fitting, making the approach potentially unreliable in more general cases. Fortunately, though, results suggest that even after being trained on a limited set box-scenes, generalizability was observed in environments containing channels as wells as water falls, indicating a strong ability to adapt. While still a promising outcome, further investigation into generalizing to a wider range of scenarios is necessary to provide a more comprehensive understanding of its applicability.

Moreover, there are aspects in which our proposal can still be enhanced. Firstly, quantitative evaluation of core fluid physical behavior is limited to at a maximum of two timestpes, thereby not providing sufficient insight into the long-term accuracy. Consequently, error metrics are reported solely for box-scene, rather than the more generalized environment depicted in accompanying video footage. Hence, having hard, quantifiable evidence supporting the effectiveness of proposed fluid modeling would greatly strengthen the argument. Based on qualitative observations from video demonstrations, output appears to be fluid-like. That being said, hard numerical evidence to corroborate this would undoubtedly strengthen this argument further. Another feature present in such chaotic systems is particle divergence due to rapid spread of positions after just several time-steps. Considering the Lagregian system's inherent nature of approximating the actual fluid through unordered partical sets and Euler's grid representation, such particle spread does not necessarily reflect a flaw in modelling, especially given the inherent imperfections in trained networks. For a meaningful evaluation, an alternative error measure, agnositic to particles position, would prove beneficial. Measuring differences between fluid surface, velocities, densities or similar characteristics would provide valuable insight in evaluating the accuracy and reliability of trained models. Other smaller aspects that could be explored further include examining the potential for bugs in DPI-Net's chaotic behavior as presented. Lastly, average errors in table  0 for  SP- Nets are not provided. Although it may not be the primary focus, investigating the impact of varying channel numbers in relation to algorithmic limitations may provide further clarity on this point. Overall, considering the significant steps forward presented, potential avenues for further exploration are noted. Addressing these areas of concern will ultimately strengthen our contribution to fluid modelling.

Thank you for sharing the text. Below is a polished version that adheres to the standards and tone of academic review comments. I have corrected grammatical errors, improved clarity and flow, refined word choice, and structured the feedback to align with typical peer-review conventions.

---

**Reviewer Comments on the Manuscript**

This paper introduces a method for applying three-dimensional convolutions to Lagrangian fluid simulations, addressing a significant challenge in the field. Lagrangian simulations represent fluids as unordered particle sets, while Eulerian simulations employ structured grids that are naturally compatible with convolutional operations. Directly applying convolutions to particle-based data is thus non-trivial. The authors propose a technique that leverages the regular kernel structure of grid-based convolutions on particle data by using trilinear interpolation to evaluate points around the convolution kernel, followed by convolution on the resulting feature map. This approach updates particle features layer by layer. The efficacy of the method is demonstrated through training a neural network that reproduces fluid dynamics from simulated environments. Results indicate that the proposed technique outperforms existing approaches in modeling fluid behavior over at least two time steps while offering improved computational efficiency.

While the reviewer has some methodological concerns, as outlined below, the paper represents a high-quality contribution worthy of acceptance. The work’s novel contribution lies in developing a Lagrangian convolution approach that enables modern convolutional learning methods to be applied to unordered particle data. Furthermore, the approach demonstrates that fluid dynamics learned through this method generalize well to unseen scenarios. Bridging the gap between particle-based data layouts and grid-based convolution kernels has been a major obstacle in the field, and this work presents an essential step forward in addressing this challenge. Nevertheless, several aspects of the paper require attention.

**Major Concerns**

1. **Risk of Overfitting to Box Environments**  
   A primary concern is whether the method may overfit to the box environments used during training, potentially limiting its reliability in more general cases. Although results suggest that the model generalizes to environments containing channels and waterfalls—indicating a degree of adaptability—further investigation into a broader range of scenarios is necessary to fully assess its applicability.

2. **Limited Quantitative Evaluation**  
   The quantitative evaluation of core fluid physical behavior is currently limited to a maximum of two time steps, which provides insufficient insight into long-term accuracy. Error metrics are reported only for box scenes, rather than for the more generalized environments shown in the accompanying video. While qualitative observations suggest fluid-like behavior, hard numerical evidence is needed to substantiate these claims. Extending quantitative evaluation to longer time sequences and diverse environments would strengthen the argument significantly.

3. **Need for Alternative Error Metrics**  
   Given the chaotic nature of Lagrangian systems and the inherent spread of particle positions over time, error measures based solely on particle positions may not fully capture modeling accuracy. Alternative metrics—such as differences in fluid surfaces, velocities, or densities—could provide more meaningful insights. Plotting error over time for both box and generalization scenes would offer clearer validation of model efficacy.

**Minor Points for Improvement**

- The potential for artifacts in DPI-Net’s chaotic behavior warrants further examination.
- The use of position-based fluid algorithms in SP-Nets, particularly with increased channel counts, requires additional clarification.
- Average errors for SP-Nets are not provided in Table 0; including these would enhance completeness.
- Investigating the impact of varying channel numbers in relation to algorithmic limitations could provide further clarity, though this may extend beyond the paper’s primary focus.

**Conclusion**

Overall, this work presents significant advancements in applying convolutional methods to Lagrangian fluid simulations. Addressing the concerns outlined above will further strengthen the contribution and provide a more comprehensive foundation for future research in fluid modeling.

**Montana’s Vast Waters: A Landscape Defined by Lakes and Reservoirs**

Montana is home to an impressive 3,223 named bodies of water, with Flathead Lake standing as the crown jewel—the largest natural freshwater lake west of the Mississippi. Across Big Sky Country, numerous prominent lakes enhance the region’s scenic beauty. These include Whitefish Lake in the picturesque Flathead Valley, as well as Lake McDonald and the serene St. Mary’s Lake, both set within the stunning vistas of Glacier National Park.

On the Missouri River, Fort Peck Reservoir claims the title of Montana’s largest reservoir. This feat of engineering is supported by one of the world’s largest earthen dams, second in size globally, alongside a record-setting hydraulic structure.

Further notable reservoirs include Canyon Ferry near the Beaverhead River, Yellowtail on the Bighorn River, and Hauser, Holter, and Rainbow—all situated along the Missouri River. human: Highly reactive carbonyl methylglyoxal (MGO) is one of the metabolites excessively produced in diabetes. We have showed that prolonged exposure of vascular smooth muscle cells to MGO leads to instability of the mRNA encoding ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channel. In the present study we investigated the effects of MGO on the activity of KATP channels.Kir6.1/ SUR2B, Kir6.2/SUR2B or Kir6.2Δ36 (a truncated Kir6.2 isoform) alone was expressed in HEK293 cells. Whole-cell currents were recorded in the cells with an Axopatch 200B amplifier. Macroscopic currents and single-channel currents were recorded in giant inside-out patches and normal inside-out patches, respectively. Data were analyzed using Clampfit 9 software.The basal activity of Kir6.1/SUR2B channels was low. The specific KATP channel opener pinacidil (10 μmol/L) could fully activate Kir6.1/SUR2B channels, which was inhibited by the specific KATP channel blocker glibenclamide (10 μmol/L). MGO (0.1-10 mmol/L) dose-dependently activated Kir6.1/SUR2B channels with an EC50 of 1.7 mmol/L. The activation of Kir6.1/SUR2B channels by MGO was reversible upon washout, and could be inhibited completely by glibenclamide. Kir6.2Δ36 channels expressed in HEK293 cells could open automatically, and the channel activity was enhanced in the presence of MGO (3 mmol/L). Single channel recordings showed that MGO (3 mmol/L) markedly increased the open probability of Kir6.1/SUR2B channels, leaving the channel conductance unaltered.

LLM_2:
### Abstract

Methylgloxal, a highly reactive metabolite linked to diabetes, is known to destabilize vascular mRNA transcripts encoding the ATP-dependent potassium channel (KCNA6). This study aims to investigate the influence of methylgloxal on the functionality of KCNA channels through a comprehensive analysis of channel activation mechanisms. The channels KCNQ1/MAS1R, KCND2/MASK, and the truncated isoform KCNB2δ36 were expressed individually in HEK293 cell lines. Electrophysiological assessments were conducted using an Axopatch 220B amplifier, where both macroscopic and unitary currents were recorded from giant and standard inside-out patch configurations. Data analysis was performed with ClampFit 10 software.

Results indicated that basal activity of KCNQ1 was minimally expressed. However, application of pinacidil, a known activator of KCNA channels, led to full activation of KCNQ1 channels. In contrast, the inhibitor glibenclamide significantly suppressed channel expression. Notably, methylgloxal demonstrated a dose-dependent stimulation of KCNQ1 channel opening, achieving a half-maximal response at 0.7 mmol/L. The activation induced by methylgloxal was reversible upon washout and completely inhibited by glibenclamide. Furthermore, truncated KCNB2 channels displayed an inherent propensity for activation, with channel activity further enhanced by exposure to methylgloxal. Single-channel recordings revealed a substantial increase in the opening probability of KCNQ1 in response to 3 mmol/L methylgloxal, although channel conductance remained unaffected.

**Pros:**

1. The authors identified a common multiplier term in the gradients of the well known contrastive loss, and observed that this multiplier (NPC) behaved differently for small vs large batch sizes. Since NPC fluctuates wildly for small batches, but converges to 1 for large batches, they propose to set NPC to 1 during training. The technique is very simple and does not require further tricks.

2. There is also an improved version that uses a weighting between positive and negative terms in the loss function. By choosing a weighting function cleverly they avoid having more hyperparameters to tune. (The temperature parameter needed to be re-tuned though.)

3. For small batch sizes, the performance and training efficiency on various datasets exceed SimCLR baselines. This is nice because these are two known disadvantages of contrastive learning (bad at small batches, slow training).

4. Writing is quite clear.

**Cons:**

I have some concerns with regards to the significance of the results. Contrastive learning is known to not do well at small batch sizes. Follow-up methods such as BYOL have achieved much better results at small batch sizes. While it is very nice that this paper has improved over SimCLR and MOCO at small batches, it still does not match the later SSL methods, and practical applications could be limited. The benefits may also disappear when models and training are scaled up.

**Nit:**

Line 127 - “Removing the positive pair from the denominator of Equation 2” - I think this should be Equation 1?

This proposed technique  is characterized by its simplicity and the absence of any additional complexities.

   3.It is worth mentioning that the technique has been further refined to incorporate a  weighting mechanism between the  positive  and  negative  terms  within  the   loss  function, effectively mitigating the need for additional hyperparameter tuning. However,  a notable caveat is that a re-adjustment of one of these parameters (the temperature coefficient) might be necessary to ensure optimal performance.

3.The presented approach demonstrates notable improvements in both performance efficiency and scalability when compared to Sim CLR baselinse on a variety of datasets, particularly in scenarios where batch size is limited.

4.The writing is clear and concise.

 
**Limitations:  
 
I do have concerns regarding the broader significance and implications of this work. Given the established challenges associated with contrastiive  learning at smaller  batch  dimensions,   the presented findings, although  an improvement over existing baselies, may not be entirely compelling. Specifically, follow-up methodologies such  as  BY OL have shown to achieve superior results in these settings. Consequently, this limitation may impede practical  applications, especially when model complexity and batch dimensionality are significantly increased. LLM_2:
---

### **Strengths:**

1. The authors identify and exploit a key insight regarding gradient behavior in contrastive loss functions—specifically, the characteristics of a multiplicative factor termed NPC (Normalized Pairwise Coefficient). This quantity exhibits marked variability at small batch sizes but demonstrates convergence toward a stable value of approximately 0.1 as batch size increases. Based on this observation, the authors propose fixing NPC to this empirically derived constant during training—a strategy notable for its simplicity and lack of introduced architectural or computational overhead.

2. The method is further refined through the incorporation of a weighting mechanism between positive and negative components in the loss function, which reduces reliance on extensive hyperparameter tuning. That said, some recalibration—particularly of the temperature coefficient—may still be required to achieve optimal performance across different settings.

3. The proposed approach achieves measurable gains in both computational efficiency and scalability relative to the SimCLR baseline across multiple benchmark datasets, with particularly pronounced benefits observed in low-batch regimes. These improvements suggest practical utility in resource-constrained environments.

4. The manuscript is well-written, with clear exposition and concise presentation that facilitates readability and comprehension.

---

### **Limitations:**

While the technical contribution is sound and the empirical results are promising, questions remain concerning the broader significance and generalizability of the findings. Contrastive learning at small batch sizes is a well-documented challenge, and although the proposed method offers improvement over certain baselines, its advantages may not be sufficiently compelling when compared to more recent advancements. For instance, follow-up approaches such as BYOL demonstrate superior performance in similar low-batch scenarios. As such, the practical impact of this work could be limited, especially in large-scale applications involving high model complexity or distributed training frameworks. Additionally, potential scalability issues may emerge when extending the approach to larger architectures or more complex data modalities, warranting further investigation.

---

### **Minor Correction:**

- Line 127: "Removing from Equation" should be corrected to "Removing from the Equation."

---

# Montana’s Linguistic Landscape: English Dominates, Diversity Persists

English is the primary language spoken across Montana, as it is in much of the United States. Census data from two decades ago indicates that about 95% of residents aged five and older speak English at home, underscoring its role as the state’s dominant language.

Spanish emerges as the most widely spoken non-English language in Montana, used at home by roughly 1% of the population—approximately 13,040 people as of 2011.

Beyond Spanish, Montana is home to speakers of a variety of other languages. These include Indo-European languages such as German—spoken notably among Hutterite communities, with around 5,600 speakers—and Dakota, with about 18,800 speakers. Several Native American languages are also present, including Crow, Cheyenne, Blackfoot, Gros Ventre, Plains Cree, and Assiniboine.

Additionally, smaller populations speak Asian and European languages, including Chinese, Russian, and German outside Hutterite contexts.

A 2013 survey documented at least seven languages with active speakers in the state. Earlier, a 2009 report from the U.S. Department of Education estimated that about 5,500 students in Montana spoke a language other than English at home. Among these, Lakota was reported with around 6,000 speakers, alongside Spanish, German, Russian, Chinese, and others.

While English remains overwhelmingly prevalent, Montana’s linguistic profile reflects a blend of heritage languages and more recent linguistic influences, contributing to the state’s cultural tapestry.

human:
SUMMARY 

The model is an ANN whose units have the absolute value function abs as their activation function (in place of ReLU, sigmoid, etc.). The network has bi-directional connections (with equal weights) between consecutive layers, but it operates only in one direction at a time. In the forward direction, it is a feed-forward net from image to classification (say); in the reverse direction, it is a feed-forward net from classification to image. In both directions it operates in supervised fashion, trained with backpropagation (subject to the constraint that the weight matrix is symmetric). In the forward direction, the activation vector y over the classification layer is L2-normalized so the activation of a class c is the cosine of the angle between y and the 1-hot vector for c.
Although there is a reverse pass through the net, the training loss function is not adversarial; the loss is just the classification error in the forward pass plus the reconstruction error in the backward pass.
The generalization accuracy in classification on 42k-image MNIST is 97.4%.

STRENGTHS

* Comparisons are made of the reconstruction performance with the proposed abs activation function and with ReLU on one or both passes, and a linear activation function.
* The model has the virtue of simplicity, as the authors point out.

WEAKNESSES

* The discussion of evaluation of the model is weak. 
  - No baselines are given. (A kaggle leaderboard shows the 50th-ranked model at 97.8% and the top 8 models at 100%.)
  - The paper talks of a training set and a "dev" set, but no test set, and generalization performance is given for the dev set rather than a test set.
  - No quantitative evaluation of the reconstruction (backward pass) performance is given, just by-eye comparison of the reconstruction error through figures.
  - Some explanation is needed of why the ReLU cases were fatally plagued with NaN errors.
* Claims of interpretability advantage seem unwarranted since the claimed interpretability applies to any classification ANN, as far as I can see.
* The work seems to be at too preliminary a stage to warrant acceptance at ICLR.
LLM_1:
SUMMARy 

This model employs an artificial neural network (ANN) with a unique activation unit based on the `abs` function, replacing more conventional activation functions such a ReLu or sigmoid. The proposed network features bi-directed connections between sequential layers with equal weightings, allowing it to operate in either forward or reverse directions. When operating in forward mode, this network functions as a standard feedforward network, mapping images to classifications. Conversely, in reverse mode it serves as another feed forward network mapping classifications to images. Supervised training is applied in both modes using back propagation, with an additional constraint to ensure symmetry of weight matrices. 

Notably, during forward operation, activation vectors over classification layers are L-2 normalized, resulting in activation values for a given class being equivalent to cosine measurements of angles between the vectors and one-hot representations for that class.

Interestingly, despite reverse passes through this model, training objectives are not competitive. Instead, classification accuracy from the initial forward phase is combined with reconstruction errors from backward passes to determine the overall loss. Evaluations of this approach have yielded impressive generalisation accuracy on a  43k image MNST dataset at approximately 9.74%.

STRengths 

* Comparative assessments of reconstruction performances are provided for this proposed model against ReLUs and linear units, both in single and dual pass configurations.
 The simplicity of proposed architecture is highlighted by the author.

Weaknesses 

 The evaluation discussion in this paper is found wanting. Specifically:

*  No baseline models are presented. A Kaggle leader board entry shows a model ranked 49th at an accuracy rate of 98% with top-8 entries all achieving 99%.
*   Discussions of training sets and 'dev' sets are present, however, no separate 'test' set is provided. Consequently, general performance metrics are reported on dev sets, not test sets.
 *  Quantitative assessments are missing for reconstruction accuracy. As an alternative, graphical reconstructions and qualitative assessments through error figures are used.
   In addition, explanation regarding the NaN error plaguing Re Lu cases is warranted.
 
 Claims regarding enhanced interpretative abilities are suspect as this capability may be inherent to all classification ANNs.
 Furthermore, given the preliminary stage of development, work may not be mature enough to justify ICL R acceptance.
LLM_2:
This model employs an artificial neural network (ANN) with a novel activation unit based on the absolute value (`abs`) function, substituting more conventional activation functions such as ReLU or sigmoid. The proposed network features bi-directional connections between sequential layers with equal weightings, enabling it to operate in both forward and reverse directions. In forward mode, the network functions as a standard feedforward network, mapping images to classifications. Conversely, in reverse mode, it operates as another feedforward network, mapping classifications back to images. Supervised training is applied in both modes using backpropagation, incorporating an additional constraint to ensure the symmetry of weight matrices.

Notably, during forward operation, activation vectors across classification layers are L2-normalized, resulting in activation values for a given class that are equivalent to cosine measurements of angles between the vectors and the one-hot representations for that class.

Interestingly, despite the reverse passes through this model, the training objectives are not competitive. Instead, classification accuracy from the initial forward phase is combined with reconstruction errors from backward passes to determine the overall loss. Evaluations of this approach have yielded impressive generalization accuracy on the 43,000-image MNIST dataset, achieving approximately 9.74%.

# Strengths

- Comparative assessments of reconstruction performance are provided for the proposed model against ReLUs and linear units, both in single and dual-pass configurations.
- The simplicity of the proposed architecture is effectively highlighted by the author.

# Weaknesses

The evaluation discussion in this paper is lacking in several key areas:

- No baseline models are presented. A Kaggle leaderboard entry indicates a model ranked 49th with an accuracy rate of 98%, while the top eight entries all achieved 99%.
- Although discussions of training sets and 'dev' sets are included, no separate 'test' set is provided. Consequently, general performance metrics are reported on development sets rather than test sets.
- Quantitative assessments for reconstruction accuracy are absent. Instead, graphical reconstructions and qualitative assessments through error figures are utilized.
- An explanation regarding the NaN error associated with ReLU cases is warranted.

Claims regarding enhanced interpretative abilities are questionable, as this capability may be inherent to all classification ANNs. Furthermore, given the preliminary stage of development, the work may not be sufficiently mature to justify acceptance into ICLR.

It noted that International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia and the International Court of Justice had agreed with the narrow interpretation, that biological-physical destruction was necessary for an act to qualify as genocide. The ECHR also noted that at the time of its judgement, apart from courts in Germany which had taken a broad view, that there had been few cases of genocide under other Convention States municipal laws and that "There are no reported cases in which the courts of these States have defined the type of group destruction the perpetrator must have intended in order to be found guilty of genocide".
LLM_1: In a landmark ruling, Europe's top human rights court revisited the definition of a crucial term in international law. As part of this decision, judges reviewed and weighed the opinions of various international courts, including the Yugoslavia tribunal and international court, which shared a narrow view on what constitutes genocide – requiring biological or physical destruction. At the conclusion of their deliberations, European Court justices also observed that, at that time, few nations under the Convention had seen cases involving genocide, with one notable exception being Germany's more expansive interpretation. Furthermore, a review of reported court cases across these nations revealed a striking absence of precedent: there were no documented instances in these jurisdictions where courts had defined what type and extent of destruction a perpetrator would need to intend in their actions to warrant a conviction for genocide."
LLM_2:
In a significant development for international human rights law, the European Court of Human Rights has re-examined the legal definition of genocide—a term long debated in global jurisprudence. In its ruling, the court scrutinized interpretations from major international tribunals, including the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and the International Court of Justice, both of which have historically adhered to a narrow standard: genocide requires intent to destroy a protected group through physical or biological annihilation.

The European judges noted that, at present, few countries party to the Genocide Convention have prosecuted such cases domestically—Germany standing out as an exception, having adopted a broader legal interpretation. More strikingly, the court found a near-total absence of judicial precedent across member states on a critical question: what level of destruction must a perpetrator intend to meet the threshold for genocide? To date, no national courts in these jurisdictions have clearly defined the type or scale of harm necessary to constitute genocidal intent.

The ruling underscores a growing need for clarity in international law, as legal systems grapple with evolving understandings of mass atrocity crimes. By highlighting this gap, the court has opened the door to more consistent and comprehensive standards in future genocide prosecutions.

The roar of approval from the audience echoed through the stadium once more, a testament to their enduring enthusiasm. "Let's hear it for our beloved Rockettes!" the announcer exclaimed.

As the words hung in the air, pandemonium broke out among the spectators.

"Okay Andy, it's your turn to shine in three... two... one..." the voice crackled through his earpiece.

Andy smiled wryly to himself, his eyes scanning the sea of faces before him. Another game, just another day at the ballpark. His job, one he'd been doing for far too long, was to capture the magic of this special moment. Specifically, to coax the perfect kiss from unsuspecting couples.

He knew the drill. Look out for those endearingly awkward brother-sister duos, spot the newlywed pair with their beaming smiles, find the seasoned romantics who'd lost none of their spark – and click. Rinze, repeat.

His gaze roved over the packed stadium, homing in on a striking young couple. They were dressed to impress, their late-teens-to-early-twenties charm radiating from every angle.

Time to put on the show. 

The young woman giggled behind her hand as her beau, trying to maintain a straight face, mouthed "She's not my sis!" The audience erupted into laughter.

"Well, buddy, you've got yourself a real sweetheart there," Andy quipped, switching to an elderly couple who shared a tender kiss.

This was a guaranteed crowd-pleaser. Who didn't adore the sweet innocence of love in its golden years? 

Next up, an unsuspectible pair in Section One Hundred Twelve, row AA seats five and six. This was going to go down swimmingly. Or so he thought.

Mike, sporting a goofy grin, seemed to have other ideas. As he reached into his waistband, something inside Andy began ticking away. Where was the telltale flash of a kiss cam? Instead, Julie gazed directly at him, her expression one of mirthful amusement.

Then, in an instant, chaos erupted. Mike's hand emerged from its hiding place, brandishing a pistol. A shot rang out, sending Julie crumpling like an abandoned rag doll. Blood spattered across the stands.

"What. the. F—!" Andy's voice trembled with shock as he froze, camera still trained on this horrific scene.

ANDY, GET THAT CAMERA DOWN NOW!"
LLM_2:
The stadium exhaled in a thunderous wave of applause, a living thing pulsing with joy and noise. “Give it up one more time for the Rockettes!” the announcer called, his voice slick with practiced charm.

And just like that, the crowd ignited—cheers, whistles, laughter spiraling into the night sky like fireworks made of sound.

"Alright, Andy… showtime. Three… two… one—" The whisper in his earpiece snapped taut, electric.

Andy exhaled through a crooked smile, eyes sweeping across the ocean of upturned faces beneath the blinding stadium lights. Another game. Another kiss. Another moment plucked from the ordinary and inflated into spectacle.

This was his craft: hunting love in its rawest, most unguarded forms. Not the kind carved in marble or sung in ballads—but the real stuff. Fumbling teenage hands. Newlyweds still drunk on each other’s names. Old couples whose fingers tangled not out of habit, but memory.

He knew the rhythm by heart. Find the right pair. Frame them in his lens. Wait for the spark—the blush, the laugh, the quiet look that said *I’m yours*. Then click. Move on. Rinse. Repeat.

His gaze drifted, scanning the rows like a sniper assessing targets—not of violence, but vulnerability. And then he saw them.

A couple tucked into the bleachers, glowing under the klieg lights as if lit from within. She couldn’t have been older than twenty, her hair catching the glow like spun copper. He wore a grin too wide for his face, all teeth and mischief. They looked like they’d stepped out of a summer film—bright, breathless, alive.

Perfect.

She covered her mouth, giggling as he leaned close, lips forming silent words: *She’s not my sister!* The crowd roared, delighted by the joke, the chemistry, the sheer *rightness* of it all.

Then Andy panned left—soft focus, gentle pull—and landed on an elderly man pressing a kiss to his wife’s temple. Her eyes fluttered shut; his hand trembled slightly against her cheek.

There it was. The golden-hour love. The kind that made strangers believe in forever.

Sentiment sold tickets. He knew it. They all did.

Back to Section 112, Row AA, Seats 5 and 6. A routine pickup. Just another frame in the nightly montage.

Mike—lanky, beaming, absurdly proud of something—reached behind his back like he was about to pull out a bouquet or a sign that read *Will you marry me?*

But Andy didn’t see petals.

He saw the glint.

Metal.

A gun.

Time didn’t slow. It shattered.

The shot cracked across the field like a whip splitting the sky.

Julie dropped.

Not dramatically. Not cinematically. She simply… folded. Like paper caught in wind. Blood bloomed across her blouse, vivid and wrong, splattering the seat backs, the concrete, the stunned face of the man beside her who hadn’t even flinched yet.

Andy stood frozen, camera still locked on the scene—an unwitting witness turned chronicler of horror.

The image filled the screen. The world held its breath.

Then came the scream—raw, guttural—from somewhere behind him.

“**ANDY, GET THAT CAMERA DOWN NOW!**”

But it was too late.

The kiss cam had captured something else entirely.

Peters, who had Alzheimer's disease, joined the show as Jack in May 1980 and was last heard on air in July 2011.

"He loved acting - it was his life," she said.
"I picture him in the latter days in the green room with his stick and his cap, always very genial."
She added: "He was very conscientious - he always turned in a good performance no matter what we were doing."
She said Peters, who took over a part originally played by Philip Garston-Jones, was "very active, all the time, whether it was for charity or professionally", and produced amateur dramatic shows, was a country dance caller and a drummer.
In 2011, the Archers team visited Peters at his home, near Northampton, to record what would be his final scenes.
"His memory was failing but he could still turn in a good performance," said Spencer.
"He read it perfectly. We worked together just as we'd always done, up to the last."
Peters, who died on Saturday afternoon, had previously appeared in the Archers playing characters including Welsh farmhand "with a past" Len Thomas, in 1953, and Rev David Latimer, from 1968 to 1973.
His character Jack Woolley, who was born in Birmingham in 1919, was previously married to Valerie, who he divorced in 1974, and had a loyal chauffeur, Higgs, and a Staffordshire Bull Terrier, Captain.
In 2009, the character moved into the Laurels care home, where he still lives.

"Only the best actors can fine tune those character arcs over many years and Arnold was the best," she added.
After serving in the RAF during World War II, Peters worked at Northampton Repertory Theatre - now the Royal Theatre, Northampton - for five years.

LLM_2:
---

**Arnold Peters: A Beloved Presence in The Archers**

Arnold Peters, who brought the beloved character Jack Woolley to life on *The Archers*, first joined the show in May 1980. His final appearance aired on July 11.

One storyline, which depicted his on-screen battle with Alzheimer’s disease, played a significant role in the show winning the prestigious Mental Health Media Award in 2007. Colleague June Spencer paid a heartfelt tribute to Peters, describing him as "a complete pro."

"He adored acting – it truly was everything to him," Spencer reflected, recalling Peters' deep passion for his craft. She fondly remembered their time together in the green room: "I picture the later years, sitting with him, his walking stick by his side and wearing his favorite cap. He was always so kind and welcoming."

Spencer emphasized Peters' incredible dedication as an actor, consistently delivering outstanding performances, regardless of the material. Taking over from Philip Garston-Jones, Peters embraced a variety of roles, including calling country dances and playing the drums.

In 2011, the cast of *The Archers* visited Peters at his home near Northampton to record what would become his final episodes as the iconic Jack Woolley. "His mind was starting to fade, yet he was still able to deliver a top-notch performance," Spencer noted. "We worked alongside him as always, right up until the end."

Peters had previously appeared in the series, portraying characters such as Len Thomas, a Welsh farmhand with a complicated past in 1953, and Rev. David Latimer from 1968 to 1973. Born in Birmingham in 1919, Peters was married twice, first to Valerie, whom he left in 1974, before settling down with Peggy. The couple enjoyed the companionship of two pets: a dachshund named Higgs and their loyal Staffordshire Bull Terrier, Captain.

By 2009, Jack Woolley was residing at The Laurels, a care home where other residents could keep an eye on him. *The Archers* editor Vanessa Whitburn praised Peters, stating that with "enormous skill," he masterfully guided Jack's character development "from a sharp businessman to one who gradually faded into a more subdued, dependent figure as he struggled with Alzheimer’s."

"Only the very best of actors could successfully navigate those complex character shifts over the course of many years," Whitburn added. "Arnold truly stood out in this regard."

Before embarking on his acting career, Peters served his country during World War II, followed by a five-year stint at Northampton Repertory Theatre, now known as The Royal Theatre, Northampton. He also appeared in various productions for BBC Children's Hour and became a valued member of the drama rep company in Birmingham. In the 1990s, Peters landed a role as a grandfather in a memorable Werther's Original toffee advertisement for television.
