LLM_1:
There were only a few options left. None of those higher up would ever say a thing about them, yet we knew that one path was out. A massive enemy warships loomed miles offshore, its range sweeping our frontline with precision while our infantry trailed behind, mere yards from harm's reach. Ground forces stood little chance; either buried beneath the weight of incoming missiles or forced to emerge and face the advancing enemy infantry head-on. Unless something utterly impossible transpired, it seemed inevitable we'd suffer a crushing defeat.

As part I of an elite fighter jet squad, I watched over our airspace above. Flying P66 Vanguard jets – the 'Vikings of Sky,' we called ourselves – our wings were battered but still held their ground. Enemy aircraft boasted tenfold steel wings, resembling flying blades if one wasn't cautious. Despite our valiant efforts, maintaining air superiority above our coastline, ground troops were taking a pounding. Initially, three squads with ten fighters each dwindled down to a lone squad with thirteen members. Leader Captain Giulitti briefed us on our dire situation via radio from ground base, warning of its impending loss.

Captain Giulitte explained, 'We have but one shot at pulling this through, there's only way.' Allies possessed one final Vicker's Warwick heavy-bomber approaching from afar, which needed cover. That war-ship anchored offshore would ensure the enemies' victory, pummeling our coast relentlessly unless intervened. 'Our bombers will provide air support while we create a diversion, otherwise AA-guns on that ship will shred them to pieces,' he cautioned. Of my initial squad only four remained – Tom, myself, Giulettee,  and Yul. Other fighters comprised what little was remaining of other units.

Over the comms, an expletive escaped my lips: 'I'll crash it straight into their goddamn ship if I go down.' The silence that followed was broken by a deep, acccented voice, responding: "Too right! Let's give 'em a taste of what hell really looks like."

Captain Giullette announced the V- bomber's position. Forming a tight shield around, he instructed, "We leave the shore now." My P 66 was our vanguard, equipped with the last of remaining ordance. Beyond the swirling enemy aircraft, enemy AA-defense guns stood ready to shred the approaching bomber. "Just like vultures over carrion, boys! Engage!"

A chorus erupted as bullets rained into our foes. Three to our one disadvantage seemed irrelevant; the minutes ticking away meant our bomber needed to strike. Their AA-gun defenses needed disabling, armor dented, providing a hit target for our payload – a feat that, while seemingly impossible, needed execution.

Our numbers dwindling like autumn leaves, still we managed to take down twice as many of their kind for every loss. Swarms of enemies grouped in twos, attempting to isolate and take us down. Realizing our error, too late, they targeted our lone bomber with kamakaze ferocity.

Only four fighters remained, followed by three – then two. Giultee's voice faded mid-battle. Avoiding the chaos, cirling above, their sheer numbers seemed insurmountable. Ammunition dwindles, spent shells littering our empty magazines.

A voice chimed in: ''We're not flying coffined metal; we are bombs, ramming straight to its core! ''

Tom responded in affirmation, with Yuel uttering resignation: ``What choice do we have?''

Climbing the skies, clouds became our sole sanctuary. Circling around our target, each of we selected our final spot. Yel aimed for main-deck, Toms for cabin, leaving me to target the designated hit-zone.

Tom called out to Yell: `You've got a recording of all of it?'

A resolute 'Yes, please let it survive,' followed. If it were to survive, those who found it might have quite the story to tell.

Descending, war-ships in our sights, opening fire at five-hundred yards – Tons hit cabin; maindeck, hit aswell. At one-hundreth yards, closing in, targeting began. Last contact in –
LLM_2:
Only a few options remained. The brass would never speak of them, but we all knew one path was left open. Miles offshore, a massive enemy warship loomed, its guns sweeping our front lines with cold precision while our infantry clung to the sand, yards from death. On the ground, they had two choices: be buried under missile fire, or rise and meet the enemy’s advance head-on. Barring a miracle, defeat was certain.

From above, I watched as part of what was left of an elite fighter squadron. We flew P66 Vanguards—*Vikings of the Sky*, we called ourselves. Our wings were scarred, but still we held the air. The enemy’s birds outnumbered us ten to one, their frames like flying blades. We kept the skies clear off the coast, but below, our men were being hammered. We started with three full squads. Now we were one—thirteen planes left.

Captain Giulitti’s voice crackled over the radio from a base that wouldn’t last the hour. “We have one shot,” he said. “Just one.”

An allied heavy bomber, a Vickers Warwick, was inbound from the west. That ship offshore was the key—if it fell, the enemy’s advance would stall. If it stayed, our coast would be erased.

“The bomber needs cover,” Giulitti went on. “We draw their fire. If we don’t, their AA guns will tear it apart.”

Of my original wing, only four of us remained: Tom, Giuliette, Yul, and me.

Over the comms, I heard myself say, “If I go down, I’m flying straight into that damn ship.”

A pause. Then a rough, accented voice cut in: “Too right. Let’s give ’em a taste of hell.”

Giulitti marked the bomber’s position. “Form up tight. We leave the shore now.”

My P66 led, loaded with the last of our ordnance. Beyond the swarming enemy fighters, the warship’s AA batteries waited, hungry.

“Like vultures on carrion, boys,” Giulitti called. “Engage!”

We fell on them in a storm of tracers and rage. Outnumbered three to one, maybe more. Minutes mattered. The bomber needed a clean run. We had to blind their guns, bruise their armor, mark the spot—do the impossible.

We fell like leaves, but we made them pay—two of theirs for every one of ours. They flew in pairs, trying to pick us apart. Too late, we realized their real plan: they weren’t just after us. They were aiming for the bomber with kamikaze fury.

Four left. Then three. Then two.

Giulitti’s voice vanished mid-sentence.

We circled above the chaos, low on ammo, lower on hope. Empty shell casings rattled in our bays.

Then, a voice over the radio—calm, clear: “We’re not flying coffins. We’re flying bombs. Right into its heart.”

Tom answered first. “Damn straight.”

Yul followed, quiet. “What choice do we have?”

We climbed, clouds swallowing us whole. Circled once, twice, each choosing a final point of impact. Yul would take the main deck. Tom, the bridge. I’d aim for the magazine.

Tom’s voice again, tight but steady: “Yul. You still recording all this?”

A beat. “Yes. Let’s make sure it survives.”

If it survived… whoever found it would have one hell of a story.

We dove.

The ship grew in our sights. At five hundred yards, we opened fire. Tom’s rounds tore into the bridge. Yul’s strafed the deck.

One hundred yards out, I locked on.

Last transmission in—

<Paper summary>
The authors argue that the popular benchmark datasets, Omniglot and miniImageNet, are too simple to evaluate supervised few-shot classification methods due to their insufficient variety of class semantics. To validate this, the authors proposed clustering-based meta-learning method, called Centroid Network. Although it does not utilize supervision information during meta-evaluation, it can achieve high accuracies on Omniglot and miniImageNet. The authors also proposed a new metric to quantify the difficulty of meta-learning for few-shot classification.

<Review summary>
Although the main claim of this paper seems correct, it is not sufficiently supported by theory or experiments. My score is actually on the borderline, but I currently vote for ``weak reject, because some points in the paper are ambiguous yet. Given clarifications in an author response, I would be willing to increase the score.

<Details>
* Strength
 + The paper is well-organized. Especially, the examples shown in the introduction greatly help understanding of what the authors argue in this paper.
 + A novel study on quantifying the difficulty of meta-learning.
 + The proposed CentroidNet performs well in the experiments.
 
* Weakness and concerns
 - Does CentroidNet really work without labels during ``meta-validation"? As far as I understand, ground truth clusters of the support set defined by the labels are required to compute the accuracies. Therefore, the labels seem to be required to validate the performance of the model. I think it should be ``meta-test."
 - The authors state ``The most intuitive way to train ..., we did not have much success with this approach" in 5.3, but it is counter-intuitive. If the class semantics are similar among episodes, ``the most intuitive way" should work, because it can learn the common semantics via meta-training. Further discussion about why it does not work is required.
 - The high performance of CentroidNet does not support the claim on the insufficient variety of the class semantics. According to ablation study, adopting Sinkhorn K-means is the most important factor to improve the performance. It means that adopting weighted average like in [R1] can also improve the performance of ProtoNet, which results in substantial difference in the performance between ProtoNet and CentroidNet that can deny the claim. 
 - The definition of CSCC is not convincing. First, I could not get the meaning of ``unsupervised Bayes accuracy" (supervised Bayes accuracy means 1 - Bayes error rate, right?). Second, CSCC seems to mainly quantify the importance of the supervision information during meta-learning, which is not directly related to the difficulty of few-shot learning problem. Intuitively, difficult few-shot learning problems should lead to lower supervised Bayes accuracy, which does not necessarily decrease CSCC. Third, what we can induce via comparing CSCC is not clarified in theory. The discussion in 6.3 is too subjective and specific for the case of training with ILSVRC/all datasets.
 - This paper lacks citing some closely related works [R1, R2].

[R1] ``Infinite Mixture Prototypes for Few-Shot Learning," ICML2019
[R2] ``A Closer Look at Few-shot Classification," ICLR2019

* Minor concerns that do not have an impact on the score
 - Another arXiv paper related to this work: ``Rapid Learning or Feature Reuse? Towards Understanding the Effectiveness of MAML"

<PAPER SUMMARY>

The proposed study argues that popular benchmarks, such Omnigliot and minImageNets, may be too simplistic to effectively evaluate the efficacy of supervised meta learning methods for a few shot classification due their limited semantic variety in class definitions. In order to substantiate this claim, authors propose a novel clustering based metalearning approach, termed Centriod Network, that achieves high accuracy on these benchmarks without utilizing supervision during the evaluation process. Furthermore, they introduce a fresh metric for quantification of difficulty in metaleaning for classification tasks.

 <REVIEW SUMMARY>
 
While the primary assertion of paper appears to hold some truth, a lack of theoretical or experimental evidence leaves the validity of findings uncertain. Consequently, my score falls on borderline; however, with clarifying responses from the author, this score may increase.

  <DETAILS>
   * Strengths
    +  The article is exceptionally well organized, especially the visual aids presented in introduction that facilitate comprehension of key arguments presented.
    -  CentrioNet demonstrates impressive results, offering novel insights into quantifing the metalearing difficulty.
   -   The performance metrics for CentioNet are indeed promising, showcasing its capability in handling a variety tasks.
   
   <Weaknesses and Concerns>
 - Is CentiorNet truly effective in functioning without the use of labels, specifically during "meta validation"? It seems that ground-truth clusters, defined through the utilization of label information, might be necessary for computing accuracy metrics. Hence, labels appear to remain crucial for evaluating model performance, thereby rendering the label-free premise questionable. Perhaps " meta-test" would better reflect this requirement.
- In section  3.5, "The Most Intuitive way of Training" yields unsatisfactory results; nevertheless, one would anticipate that such an approach would prove effective if class sematics share a high degree of similarity among training episodes. Conversely, if this is indeed the situation, then this outcome appears counterintuitive, necessitating further analysis on why this might not be the best approach.
  - Although CentiodNet exhibits superior performance compared to other models, its efficacy could be attributed to Sinkorn K-Means rather than the limited class semantic diversity. Adopting weighted averages, as proposed in closely-related work [ R1 ], may also significantly enhance Proto Net's performance and thus render substantial differences between the two models. These findings potentially undermine the assertion regarding insufficient class diversity.
  
 - Definition of Critical Success Classifiability (CSCC) is unclear. Firstly, interpretation of "unsuervised Bayesian accuracy", as opposed to "supervisied Bayesian Accuracy", which equals  $1- Baye's error", remains ambiguous. Secondly, how CSC quantifies the significance of supervision in learning process is ambiguous and seems unrelated to quantifiing fewshot classification difficulties.  Intuitionally, problems that are difficult in fewshots should result in lower accuracy in supervised learning, not neccessarily reducing CSC. Lastly, theoretical insights from CSC are not clearly explained, particularly in cases involving training on I LSVRC / all datasets. Discussion in section, 4.2 is subjective, specific to a particular scenario.
    
  * Minor Concern:
   A closely relevant work that is cited is [  R 2  ].
LLM_2:
The language has been refined for fluency, grammatical accuracy, and terminological consistency, particularly with respect to technical concepts in meta-learning and few-shot classification.

---

### <PAPER SUMMARY>

The paper argues that commonly used benchmarks—such as Omniglot and miniImageNet—may be overly simplistic for effectively evaluating the performance of supervised meta-learning methods in few-shot classification, due to their limited semantic diversity across class definitions. To support this claim, the authors propose a novel clustering-based meta-learning approach termed **Centroid Network** (CentroidNet), which achieves high accuracy on these benchmarks without relying on label supervision during evaluation. Additionally, the authors introduce a new metric for quantifying the difficulty of meta-learning in classification tasks.

---

### <REVIEW SUMMARY>

While the central argument of the paper appears plausible, the lack of rigorous theoretical justification and comprehensive experimental validation undermines the certainty of its conclusions. As a result, my assessment falls within the *borderline* range. However, with clarifications from the authors—particularly regarding methodological assumptions and interpretative claims—this evaluation could be positively reconsidered.

---

### <DETAILED COMMENTS>

#### **Strengths**

- The manuscript is exceptionally well-structured, with clear exposition and effective visual aids in the introduction that significantly enhance the reader’s understanding of the core arguments.
  
- CentroidNet demonstrates strong empirical performance and offers valuable insights into the challenge of quantifying meta-learning difficulty, suggesting potential directions for future research.

- The proposed method exhibits promising results across multiple tasks, indicating robustness and adaptability in diverse few-shot learning scenarios.

---

#### **Weaknesses and Concerns**

1. **Label Usage During Evaluation: A Contradiction?**  
   It remains unclear whether CentroidNet truly operates in a label-free manner during the "meta-validation" phase. Specifically, if ground-truth clusters are constructed using label information to compute accuracy metrics, then supervision is implicitly present in the evaluation pipeline. This contradicts the premise of fully unsupervised evaluation and raises questions about the validity of the label-free claim. A more appropriate designation might be “*meta-test*” rather than “meta-validation,” given the reliance on labeled data for performance assessment.

2. **Counterintuitive Results in Section 3.5**  
   The subsection titled *"The Most Intuitive Way of Training"* reports poor performance despite expectations that such an approach should succeed when class semantics are highly similar across training episodes. If, as hypothesized, semantic consistency facilitates generalization, the observed failure is counterintuitive and warrants deeper analysis. The authors should provide a more thorough explanation—for instance, through ablation studies or theoretical reasoning—as to why this seemingly natural baseline underperforms.

3. **Attribution of Performance Gains**  
   While CentroidNet outperforms existing models, it is uncertain whether this superiority stems primarily from reduced class semantic diversity or from the use of Sinkhorn K-means as a clustering mechanism. Notably, prior work [R1] suggests that incorporating weighted averaging strategies can substantially improve ProtoNet’s performance. Without comparing against such enhanced baselines, the claimed advantage of CentroidNet may be overstated, potentially weakening the paper’s central argument regarding benchmark limitations due to low semantic variation.

4. **Ambiguity in the Definition of Critical Success Classifiability (CSC)**  
   The formulation of CSC lacks clarity on several fronts:
   - The notion of *unsupervised Bayesian accuracy* is not adequately defined, especially in contrast to *supervised Bayesian accuracy*, which corresponds to $1 -  ext{Bayes error}$. Without a formal derivation or intuitive interpretation, this concept remains ambiguous.
   - It is unclear how CSC captures the role of supervision in the learning process. More critically, the relationship between CSC and few-shot classification difficulty is not convincingly established. Intuitively, tasks that are difficult in the few-shot setting should yield lower supervised learning accuracy; however, no direct link is drawn between such performance degradation and CSC values.
   - The theoretical implications of CSC are insufficiently developed, particularly in the context of training on ILSVRC or other large-scale datasets. The discussion in Section 4.2 appears speculative and scenario-specific, lacking broader generalizability.

---

#### **Minor Comment**

- A closely related study, cited as [R2], deserves more detailed engagement, particularly in light of its relevance to clustering-based meta-learning approaches. A comparative analysis would strengthen the positioning of the proposed method within the existing literature.

---

This revised version maintains academic rigor while improving readability and coherence, making it suitable for inclusion in formal peer-review feedback. Let me know if you'd like a concise version or a response strategy for author rebuttal.

Cole Blockham was a rich man and many people came to his compound on a regular basis, bearing objects with which to barter and trade. A small woman, arrived at his gates on an insignificant sunset. The sky was the colour of rust and the world smelled of olives. 
 
 `` Got a pass?'' 
 
 The guards were trigger-happy and they had reason to be. Only the week before, they'd lost one of their lot to a knife wielding lunatic. The survivors had learned their lesson well. 
 
 `` Lady. You got your pass?'' 
 
 `` Yes, I do. Here.'' 
 
 A short, brown skinned woman handed her papers to the nearest guardsman. Her name did n't matter. Names rarely mattered any more. 
 
 `` Let me feel one.'' 
 
 The guard was referring to her goods; a pair of woollen sweaters, hand knitted and draped over her shoulders. 
 
 `` Sure, here.'' 
 
 The guard reached forward and teased the material between his fingers. It reminded him of his sister, but he did n't say anything. He sucked up a smile before it could escape his face and then he stood aside, grim lipped. 
 
 `` Very well, in you go.'' 
 
 With a tired screech, the large metallic gate was wheeled open, baring the dusty track towards the inner compound. The wool trader wandered in, clutching her sweaters tightly. 
 Past the gates, amidst the bosom of courtyard, the woman was soon greeted by Cole, the only name that mattered around here. The name Cole, belonged to a large, thick bellied man, with a nest-like beard. Cole knew how to smile and did so upon greeting the woman, baring two rows of paling yellow teeth. 
 
 `` Ah! What have we here? Wool? Now that is a commodity I admire! Come, come. Let me feel it.'' 
 
 Cole, like the guardsman outside, hurried over and plucked up some of the wool, humming contemplatively while his fingers explored the knit. 
 
 `` It is smooth. Soft. May I try one on?'' 
 
 `` Of course.'' 
 
 The woman shed her sweaters and lay them onto the rim of a well. One of them was chosen at random and offered over to Cole. With obvious impatience, he took it up and hoisted it over his head, sliding the shape down until it absorbed his girthy form. Cole grinned. 
 
 `` I like it! It will be brilliant in the nights. How much?'' 
 
 `` A... Two bags.'' 
 
 `` Two? For both?'' 
 
 `` No. For each.'' 
 
 Cole could not only smile. He also could also'not smile.' So Cole did that. He did n't smile and his eyes, dark little beady things, made sure that the woman knew that he *wasn't* smiling. 
 
 `` Two? For both? Right?'' 
 
 Nerve broken, the woman nodded vigorously. Her lips proclaimed apologies and she held out the second fleece. Cole nodded and received the second garment with a satisfied snort. 
 
 `` Good, good. Now, for your payment. Come.'' 
 
 This was the part that the lady had been waiting for. She licked her lips expectantly and followed Cole as he began to march towards a lonely, corrugated building. This building was set aside, near the end of the courtyard and it smelled strongly of headaches. Cole reached the door to this building and fumbled around for a fat, golden key in his pockets. Once he'd found it, he promptly opened up the entrance and carried on inside, into the abattoir. 
 
 `` We have a reasonable selection, right now.'' 
 
 It was dark inside. Very dark. A cold and soaked type of dark, that bubbles up around the eyes. It took the woman a few minutes to adjust to the lighting before she could finally make out any of the features within. 
 
 `` I do n't know,'' she said. `` Are there ever any recommendations?'' 
 
 The darkness peeled away and the room became a fudgy gray scene. The main article of interest within the room, were two long rows of hanging meats, each one limp and dripping, stuck atop the end of a hanging hook. Cole shuffled over to one of these shapes and dragged it forward, sliding the hook along the meat rail. 
 
 `` This one is very popular,'' he announced. 
 
 The meat groaned, pitifully. It had been known as Jane, once. But Jane's name did n't matter any more. Only the red juices that flowed around inside, that's all that mattered. 
 
 The woman surveyed Jane. She dribbled thoughts through her mouth, in little hums and'um's. A salivating decision. Eventually, the woman nodded. 
 
 Cole grinned; a wraith-like expression that pierced the shadows and gleamed, slick and shiny. 
 
 `` Excellent. I shall get the needle.''

A wealthy man named Cole Blockman resided in an imposing compound, where many individuals regularly visited, bringing goods to trade and bartered. As the sun set, casting a reddish hue over the landscape, a petite woman appeared at the compound's entrance. 

"Got a permit?" 

The guards, perpetually on edge, had a reason for their vigilance. Recently, one their comrades had fallen victim to an assailant wielding a blade. Their colleagues had taken heed of this lesson. "Lady, you've got a license?" "Yes, indeed. Right here." 

A compact, olive-skinned lady produced her documents, handing them to nearby guards. Namelessness had become a norm, rendering personal identities insignificant.  

"Let me examine the merchandise." The officer referred to woolen sweats draped across her slender shoulders, which she had carefully hand-knitted. His fingers delicately teased at a strand, reminding him vaguely of an aunt's woolly shawl. Suppressing a fleeting smile, his expression remained stoic.  
 
"Very well; proceed." With an ear-piercing screek, massive metal gates swung open. Permit-holding wool merchant ventured inside as the massive gates wheezed open.

Within the court's bosomy heart, Cole awaited, an authoritative figure with an unruly beard and a commanding presence. Greeting the trader with warm, albeit pearly, smile he said: "Ah, what have I got here?" 
 "Wool. Quite a fine commodity." Cole ambled over, fingers inspecting the knits, murmuring a soft, appreciative hum.  "Feel this smoothness, its softness... Tell me, may I give it a test?" Cole requested permission to wear one for inspection. Eagerly, she shed the sweathers, laying them upon the well's edge. At random, her wool was selected, passed to him. Then, impatiencely, it was hoist over Cole's considerable belly. While the garment was stretched around him, "I like this! Brilliant in evenings," he declared enthusiastically. Asking the price, two bags for both, seemed reasonable to both parties.

A smile crossed Cole lips, as his dark eyes gleaming in warning, revealed his intentions. Nodding, unbroken, woman agreed, handed over second sweater. Satisfied, snorting,  Cole accepted payment and led her to payment room. Located near compound end, this dingy corrugarated shed emitted a pungent, sickly smell. Its door, secured by a golden, chunky key, creaked under Cole’s entry.

As they entered, darkness enveloped them. Gradually, features became visible. Dim grey hues enveloping them like a thick fog, obscured the air. Hanging carcasses hung from hooks, their meat slick, limp. Two rows filled the space. Meat hung pitiless, silent. In the darkness, Jane hung, forgotten, yet remembered. Jane’s name now was nothing, replaced by red, glistening juices flowing within its flesh.

Surveying, weighing options, decision came. Woman nodded in agreement. Taking the offering, grinning, wistfully, was Cole.

"Excellent, then. Get the injector."
LLM_2:
The tone is now more immersive, lyrical, and evocative, with heightened sensory detail and emotional undercurrents.

---

The compound stood like a fortress carved from dust and desire, rising from the cracked earth at the edge of the world. Its walls were high, its gates iron-laced and unforgiving, and within them lived Cole Blockman—a man whose wealth wore the shape of silence, whose power was measured not in coins but in who was allowed to enter… and who was not.

At dusk, when the sun bled into the horizon and painted the sand in rust and amber, a small figure emerged from the haze. She moved lightly, as if afraid the wind might carry her away—an olive-skinned woman, slight of frame, draped in hand-knitted wool that clung to her shoulders like a second skin. At the gate, two guards stepped forward, hands near their belts, eyes sharp with suspicion.

“Permit?” one demanded, voice clipped.

She didn’t flinch. From within her shawl, she drew a folded slip—creased, worn, but valid. “Here.”

They scanned it without warmth. Names meant little these days. Identity had long since been bartered for survival. What mattered was permission. Paper. Proof you weren’t carrying death in your pockets.

One guard reached out, fingers grazing the fabric slung over her arm. A single thread unraveled beneath his touch, soft as memory. For a breath, he hesitated—some forgotten aunt’s hearth flashed behind his eyes, the scent of lanolin and firelight—but then his face hardened again.

“Alright,” he muttered. “Go on.”

With a groan that scraped against the bones of the evening, the gates parted. Metal screamed on hinges thick with disuse, and the woman stepped through, swallowed by the compound’s shadowed belly.

Inside, Cole waited.

He sat upon a low stone bench near the central well, bearded and broad, a king upon an unmarked throne. His smile came easy—too easy—pearly teeth flashing in the dimming light.

“Well now,” he said, voice rich as oil, “what have we here?”

“Wool,” she answered simply. “Finely spun. Handmade.”

Cole rose, lumbering forward with surprising grace. He ran thick fingers across the knit, testing its weave, its give. A low hum rumbled in his chest.

“Mm. Soft. Warm. Good for cold nights.” He looked up, eyes glinting. “Mind if I try one on?”

Without waiting for full consent, she slipped the sweater from her shoulders and laid it gently atop the well’s rim. He snatched it eagerly, pulling it over his head with a grunt. The wool stretched taut across his belly, seams straining, but he didn’t care.

“I like it,” he declared, turning slightly, admiring himself in some invisible mirror. “Perfect for evenings. Keeps the chill off—and the eyes on me.” He grinned. “How much?”

“Two bags,” she said. “For both.”

A beat passed. Then another. Finally, Cole nodded—once, slow, deliberate. No words needed. She handed over the second garment. He took it, cradling it like a trophy, and beckoned her to follow.

They walked in silence toward the far end of the compound, where the buildings sagged and the air turned sour. There, nestled against the wall, stood a corrugated tin shed—its door bolted shut with a golden key, heavy and grotesque, like something pulled from a fairy tale gone wrong.

Cole unlocked it.

The door creaked open, exhaling a breath of rot and iron.

Darkness pooled inside, thick and suffocating. Slowly, shapes emerged from the gloom: hooks dangling from the ceiling, chains swaying faintly, as if stirred by unseen breath. And from them—carcasses. Row upon row of hanging meat, slick with sweat and blood, glistening dully in the thin light.

But there, among them—*her*.

Jane.

Or what was left of her.

Her name no longer belonged to bone or breath—it lived only in the red pulse of flesh, in the wet sheen of muscle cooled by shadows. Once a person. Now a cut. A choice. A transaction.

The woman looked. Said nothing. Only gave a single nod.

Cole smiled then—not wide, not kind—but deep, satisfied, like a man who has finally found the exact flavor he’d been craving.

“Excellent,” he murmured, stepping deeper into the room, boots echoing on concrete stained black with time. “Bring me the injector.”

---

**Notes on the Rewrite:**

- **Tone & Atmosphere:** Enhanced with gothic, almost mythic undertones—evoking a post-collapse world where commerce borders on ritual, and humanity is quietly eroded.
- **Sensory Detail:** Added tactile, olfactory, and auditory elements (e.g., *screaming metal*, *stench of rot*, *glistening flesh*) to deepen immersion.
- **Characterization:** Cole is more menacingly charismatic; the woman remains enigmatic, her silence speaking volumes.
- **Symbolism:** Wool = life, craft, warmth; meat = consumption, dehumanization. The contrast underscores the story’s dark irony.
- **Structure & Flow:** Sentences vary in rhythm for dramatic pacing—shorter phrases during tension, longer, flowing ones for reflection.

This paper attempts to solve the cross feature generation problem efficiently. The state-of-the-art method AutoCross cannot control the size of the searching set of the candidates of cross feature fields. To narrow down this set, the authors provide a measurement called Interpretation Inconsistency. With an easy toy experiment, the authors conjecture that features with large Interpretation Inconsistency tend to interact with other features in the hidden layers of DNN. Therefore, based on this conjecture, the authors design an effective algorithm to discard those cross features with small Interpretation Inconsistency value, which finally narrows the set of cross features. With this narrowed set, the whole procedure can be accelerated largely.

Pros:
This work can be regarded as an accelerated version of AutoCross. By incorporating Interpretation Inconsistency, the set of cross features can be effectively narrowed. Although this is an incremental work, this idea is relatively novel.

Cons:
1.	The setting of the threshold for filtering feature fields is somewhat heuristic. The authors should provide some explanations on its setting. If not, we cannot trust it and doubt that it may cause some unexpected results and thus will not be robust.
2.	The experiments are somewhat not convincing. The main contribution is to accelerate AutoCross. Thus, I expect to see the time complexity comparison between them. However, I do not find it in this paper. Although the authors mention that on wide datasets, AutoCross simply cannot work, on narrow datasets, a time complexity comparison should be provided.
3.	In Table 5, only the numbers of cross feature fields of the proposed method are provided. A comparison with baseline methods on the number would be better to show the advantage of the proposed method.

Minor: In Section 2.1, the double quotation marks should be revised.

While the state of-the art method, namely Auto Cross, struggles to manage the vast set generated for cross- feature analysis, its proposed solution introduces a metric called interpretation inconsistency, enabling the filtering of less relevant features through a straightforward toy example. This conjectured relationship between features exhibiting high interpretation inconsistencies and their interactions within deep neural networks' hidden tiers underpins the development of an optimized algorithm capable of discarding features that do little to contribute to cross-analysis, thus significantly reducing the scope of investigation. Consequently, incorporating this streamlined strategy leads to substantial acceleration of computational procedures.

Strengths:
The proposed approach represents an enhanced variant of existing work in Auto Cros, leveraging interpretation consistency as a means to effectively narrow the field of potential cross-analytical features, thereby promoting a more efficient process. Despite its incremental nature, novel aspects of this concept demonstrate merit.

Weaknesses:
Firstly, setting an appropriate threshold to filter features might be somewhat arbitrary, necessitating further explanation to ensure the reliability and robustness of results. Without such clarity, potential issues could arise, potentially compromising the integrity of findings.

Secondly and relatedly to this, experiments, though valuable, may not fully convince in demonstrating the relative benefits of proposed over baseline approaches. Specifically, as the main aim is accelerating Auto Cors, an explicit time-complexity comparison would strengthen the argument, especially considering its applicability to both wide and narrow dataset contexts.

Lastly, Table five could be enriched by presenting a direct comparison of baseline and proposed methods regarding the count of feature cross fields, rather than merely listing the latter, to more effectively highlight the advantages of introduced strategies.

The tone is professional, constructive, and precise—suitable for a conference or journal review setting.

---

This paper proposes an efficient method to address the challenging problem of cross-feature generation, a critical step in automated feature engineering. While state-of-the-art approaches such as AutoCross suffer from combinatorial explosion when generating candidate feature interactions, the authors introduce a novel metric—interpretation inconsistency—to identify and prune less meaningful crosses. Through a simple yet illustrative toy example, they argue that features exhibiting high interpretation inconsistency are less likely to contribute meaningfully to model performance, particularly in the context of deep neural network representations. This insight motivates an optimized algorithm that significantly reduces the search space of feature crosses, leading to notable improvements in computational efficiency.

**Strengths:**  
The core idea builds upon AutoCross in a principled way by leveraging interpretation consistency as a filtering mechanism. Although the overall approach is incremental, the conceptual framing and practical implementation offer a valuable refinement to existing methods. The proposed strategy effectively balances expressiveness and efficiency, making it a promising direction for scalable feature interaction discovery.

**Weaknesses:**  
First, the choice of threshold for filtering based on interpretation inconsistency appears somewhat arbitrary. The paper would benefit from a more thorough discussion on how this threshold impacts model performance and robustness across datasets. Sensitivity analysis or data-driven guidelines for threshold selection would strengthen the methodological rigor.

Second, while the experimental evaluation demonstrates improved efficiency, the speedup claims could be better substantiated with a direct comparison of time complexity between the proposed method and baseline approaches. Given the paper’s emphasis on computational scalability, including runtime metrics across different data regimes (e.g., wide vs. narrow feature spaces) would provide stronger empirical support.

Third, Table 5 currently reports only the number of retained feature crosses under the proposed method. Including corresponding counts from the baseline would enable a clearer, side-by-side comparison and more effectively illustrate the extent of dimensionality reduction achieved.

**Minor Comment:**  
A small typographical issue: inconsistent quotation mark usage in Section 2.1 should be corrected for improved readability and professionalism.

---

In this paper, the authors proposed a unified framework which computes spectral decompositions by stochastic gradient descent. This allows learning eigenfunctions over high-dimensional spaces and generating to new data without Nystrom approximation. From technical perspective, the paper is good. Nevertheless, I feel the paper is quite weak from the perspective of presentation. There are a couple of aspects the presentation can be improved from. 

(1) I feel the authors should formally define what a Spectral inference network is, especially what the network is composed of, what are the nodes, what are the edges, and the semantics of the network and what's motivation of this type of network.

(2) In Section 3, the paper derives a sequence of formulas, and many of the relevant results were given without being proven or a reference. Although I know the results are most likely to be correct, it does not hurt to make them rigorous. There are also places in the paper, the claim or statement is inclusive. For example, in the end of Section 2.3, "if the distribution p(x) is unknown, then constructing an explicitly orthonormal function basis may not be possible". I feel the authors should avoid this type of handwaving claims.  

(3) The authors may consider summarize all the technical contribution in the paper. 

One specific question:

What's Omega above formula (6)? Is it the support of x? Is it continuous or discrete? Above formula (8), the authors said "If omega is a graph". It is a little bit confusing there.
LLM_1:
I appreciate the feedback on the proposed framework, which offers a compelling approach to computing spectral decomposition via stochastic gradients. However, some aspects of its presentation could be refined for clarity and rigor.

Specifically, defining the Spectoral inference Network's architecture, comprising nodes and edges with their associated semantics, would enhance the reader's understanding. Additionally, providing formal proofs or references for the key results in Section three would strengthen the argument. Furthermore, presenting technical contributions in an explicit summary would facilitate comprehension.

Regarding the specific query, clarification on Omega's definition in formula six and its relation to formula eight, particularly in regards to its domain (continuous or discreet) and interpretation as a support, is necessary for a clear understanding.

Minor adjustments to eliminate hand-waving statements and ensure the claims are well-supported would elevate the overall presentation's credibility. With these refinements, this work has the potential to significantly contribute to understanding spectral inference networks.

---

The proposed framework presents a promising and conceptually interesting approach to spectral decomposition using stochastic gradients, and I appreciate the authors’ efforts in this direction. The core ideas are compelling, but several aspects of the presentation would benefit from refinement to improve clarity, rigor, and overall accessibility.

First, the architecture of the Spectral Inference Network—particularly the definition of its nodes, edges, and their associated semantics—should be made more precise. A clearer formalization would significantly aid reader comprehension and strengthen the methodological foundation.

Second, the theoretical contributions, especially those presented in Section 3, would gain greater credibility through the inclusion of formal proofs or explicit references to established results. At present, some claims are stated without sufficient justification, and providing rigorous support would enhance the technical soundness of the work.

Third, a concise summary outlining the key technical contributions—distinct from high-level motivation—would help readers better grasp the novel elements of the approach.

Additionally, clarification is needed regarding the definition of Ω in Equation (6) and its relationship to Equation (8). Specifically, the nature of Ω’s domain (whether continuous or discrete) and its role as a support set should be explicitly addressed to avoid ambiguity.

Finally, several statements currently rely on informal or intuitive descriptions ("hand-waving") that could be replaced with more precise language. Strengthening these points with concrete explanations or derivations would improve the paper’s overall rigor.

With these revisions, the paper has strong potential to make a valuable contribution to the understanding of spectral inference networks.

human:
The paper proposes two primary novel ideas of doing fast style transfer even on styles which are as yet unseen by the model. First, the authors extend the model of Johnson et al by making it take a conditional vector which encodes the style to be transferred. Second, they propose another neural network architecture which generates such a conditional style vector. This allows the authors directly plug the conditional vector generator (which they call Style Condition Network) into the Conditional Fast Style Transfer Network, allowing them to train the entire architecture end-to-end. In addition the architecture is flexible enough that one can represent the styles as a continuous vector and hence can potentially represent a mixture of different styles. The experimental results show that the model has been successfully able to transfer the styles. 

While the approach proposed seems to be novel, I thought the experimental section is a bit weak. The styles on which the model has been trained on seems to have transferred well. However those on which the model is not trained, the transfer seems to be a bit weak. Furthermore, since all the results are qualitative, it is somewhat hard to get a sense how good or bad the proposed approach is, with regards to the unseen styles. 

In any case I think paper has enough interesting ideas that it justifies being spoken about at a workshop.
LLM_1:
The proposed paper introduces two groundbreaking ideas for performing fast-style transfer on unseen models. Firstly, building upon the work ofJohnson etal,  theauthors extend their model by incorporating a conditionally encoded style, which is used to guide the transformation. Secondly, an alternative neural architecture generates this condition vector, enabling the integration of a Style Conditioning Network (SCN) with a Conditional fast Style transfer network. By training the combined architecture in an end-end manner, this setup allows for the direct utilization of SCN within the framework. Moreover, its flexibility enables the representation of styles through continuous vectors, thus accommodating the fusion of diverse styles.

While this novel approach exhibits promise, a critical examination of its experimental validation reveals some limitations. Notably, when applied to styles the network has seen before, transfer results appear robust. Conversely, in scenarios where the models are encountering unseen, untrained styles, performance seems somewhat diminished. Additionally, due to their qualitative nature, results do not provide a clear quantitative assessment of how well or poorly the method handles unseen style transformations.

In spite of these concerns, however, sufficient compelling ideas and innovations justify this paper's merit for presentation at an academic workshop. Further refinement and rigorous evaluation may ultimately strengthen the claims made. Nonetheless, at present, there is enough intriguing material to warrant discussion.
LLM_2:
The proposed paper introduces two innovative concepts for executing fast-style transfer on unseen models. Firstly, building upon the foundational work of Johnson et al., the authors enhance their model by incorporating a conditionally encoded style that guides the transformation process. Secondly, a distinct neural architecture is introduced to generate this condition vector, facilitating the integration of a Style Conditioning Network (SCN) with a Conditional Fast Style Transfer Network. By training this combined architecture in an end-to-end manner, the framework allows for the direct utilization of the SCN. Furthermore, the flexibility of this approach enables the representation of styles through continuous vectors, thereby accommodating the fusion of diverse stylistic elements.

While this novel approach shows considerable promise, a critical examination of its experimental validation reveals certain limitations. Notably, when applied to styles with which the network is familiar, the transfer results appear robust. In contrast, in scenarios involving unseen, untrained styles, the performance seems to diminish. Additionally, due to the qualitative nature of the results presented, there is a lack of a clear quantitative assessment regarding the efficacy of the method in handling unseen style transformations.

Despite these concerns, the paper presents sufficiently compelling ideas and innovations that justify its merit for presentation at an academic workshop. Further refinement and rigorous evaluation of the proposed methods may ultimately strengthen the claims made. Nonetheless, the intriguing material presented currently warrants discussion and consideration within the academic community.

Another cough rattled his frail body, the sound of broken metal rattling inside a dry husk echoing in the room. His black hair was a mess; the shine long gone, most of it matted to his face, neck, and bare chest by sweat. The glow of his green eyes was nearly gone, and Hitomi knew what that meant. 
 
 Since birth, she had tried her best to find a cure for his taint, blaming herself for it, tainting herself for a chance to extend his life. Yet nothing proved of worth. Nearly twenty seven years of long hours of research, of countless tears, and too many times she wanted to give up, all for this magnificent flame before her to slowly die. 
 
 Still, through all of this, he held a smile for her. 
 
 This time was no different. 
 
 He turned his face, his cheeks gaunt and his skin paler than she could ever remember, and smiled. She swore she could hear his dry lips crack, his muscles straining, but he smiled. 
 
 `` Mmm... moth..er...'' 
 
 Her hand came to his forehead, pushing his hair from his face, to travel down his cheek and cup it. `` Shh, shh, sweetie. No need to speak...'' She swallowed hard, feeling her throat tighten, her eyes already burning. She had a million things to say, so many things to show, to teach, and her time was so limited. Her free hand grabbed his that was close by and gave it a small squeeze. `` I'm not going anywhere.'' 
 
 `` M-mother... It's... okay... it is...'' It was his turn to swallow, his throat so dry, but it did n't stop him. `` None... none of this... not your fault...'' His voice smoothed out for a moment, growing in strength, using the last bit of his energy to say what he needed to say. `` And I could n't... have asked for... anyone better...'' 
 
 `` No no no, shhh, do n't... do n't say anything...'' She shifted to sit up on the edge of the bed, moving to place her head against his chest, hugging him tightly. `` I... I should have found an answer... I had so much time...'' She gritted her teeth, her eyes held shut, as if it was going to stop the flow of tears that had started. 
 
 A gentle hand came to rest on the back of her head, lightly scratching her hair as the man sighed. The light touch was enough to set free the stream of tears and the soft sobs; it was his turn to console her, his fingers weaving into her dark blue hair. `` It's okay... no one's upset with you... no one's angry... Just do n't cry...'' His hand started to slip but curved around to raise her head up to make her look at him. A small noise passed his lips as they turned upwards once more into a full fledge smile, one that reached his eyes. It was beautiful, one of the greatest sites Hitomi had ever seen. She started to speak, but his hand trembled, her own hand catching it before it fell away, keeping it against her cheek as she felt the tremors slowly fade, barely a breath escaping his lungs before they drew not another gasp. 
 
 Hitomi had no idea how long she sat there, staring at her son, now dead before her, before she realized that her tears had stopped, her body no longer wracked by cries of sorrow. Her throat hurt, her head spun, and she felt so empty inside. Laying her head back onto his chest, she muttered to herself, `` Let my corrupted soul be damned, I do not care; I would give anything to have you back...'' 
 
 *'' That's how it ends...'' The young keeper, barely a year, frowned, his head sinking into his arms as he thought about what he had seen. 
 
 `` For one timeline, yes; she went on to continue her research and has become quite the powerful demonologist of this time.. There are many others, all with different outcomes.'' The older dragon sorted through the images that floated around them, summoning a few forward. `` Here...,'' she pointed to the first one, `` she never got up. When her son died, she died with him. He was the only reason she was alive. Over here...'' Another image came forward flickering softly. `` Her sorrow turned into rage, transforming her into a demon. She killed many who knew her in the city before she herself was destroyed.'' 
 
 `` But this one, she's talking to someone...'' 
 
 `` Ah yes... another outcome...'' * 
 
 `` You are a smart woman, Kiel'ila,'' a deep rumble came from behind her, causing her to snap to her feet, green flame wrapped lashing out around her hands, energy wisping off of her eyes. With her hair disheveled and her face red from crying, and a maniacal look that could easily have scared anyone else. Not the Shivarra before her. Her nearly black skin was covered in heavy darksteel armor, hammers attached her hips as weapons or tools, it was hard to determine at the moment. 
 
 `` Give me a reason why I should n't decimate you and sear your soul, turning it into fodder for a spell, demon?'' Hitomi's hair started to stand on end, the lights starting to flicker in the room. 
 
 `` Because you can have your son back. And please, call me El'Ruin.'' 
 
 The words hit the elf hard, all her concentration quickly fading as her eyes started to well up, slowly looking over to the bed that held her late child. A visible tremor ran through her body before she looked back, nearly sneering but the sadness in her eyes told a different story. It was several moments before she spoke, her voice barely above a whisper. `` What do I have to do?'' 
 
 The now named El'Ruin took soft steps towards the bed, coming around the other side, a frown almost forming on her face. `` You have bound a demon before but I doubt you know that recently passed demons can be saved and bound.'' Before Hitomi could speak, the demon reached down, gently petting the man's hair. `` Your family is one that holds a curse, and your child was the unfortunate one; his soul sold as payment long before you were even thought of.''
LLM_1:
Another rattle shook his fragile frame, echoing the hollow sound within the empty room, like the metallic creak of a rusty gate. Dark locks cascaded over his pale skin, mated to sweat-drenched skin on his neck and chest. Once radiant green orbs now dimmed, their sparkle extinguished, leaving behind a haunting sense of loss. 

Hitomi, steadfast in pursuit of an antidote for the affliction that ravaged her child, had devoted nearly three decades to research. Countless tears fell, nights turned to days, yet the search yielded nothing. As she stood there now, witnessing the faint glimmer of life fade from her boy's eyes, memories of unending trials and heartbreaking setbacks flashed before them.  

Yet, in this poignant moment of desolation, an unwavering smile illuminated his worn face – a testament to love and resilience. Though Hitomu's life was slipping away with each passing breath, this unyielding spirit refused to falter.

His lips cracked as a faint, dry whisper escaped. "M-moth...er..." 

Without hesitation, Hitumu's hand reached out, tenderly smoothing her fingers over her dying son's face and shoulder. 'Shh,' she whispered softly,'sweetheart, don't speak.' As a single tear rolled down her check, cascading into the pool of despair, sorrow's heavy weight threatened to consume her.

A small, desperate gesture brought her hand to grasp his, giving it an urgent squeeze, conveying her love, support, even her willingness to bear the weight of guilt for something beyond her control. ''I'm right here, darling. I'll stay with...you." 

His voice, laced with the desperation of one who knows the end is near, strengthened for an instant, letting out a final declaration: "None of...this...is your...fault...And I couldn't have...asked for anyone...better..." Hitomo's weakened body fought to preserve every shred of energy, fueling his words with an unshakeable conviction.

'No, no,' Hitoma implored, tears brimming in desperation, attempting to stifle the pain. In an attempt to shield her from the anguish that threatened, ''you must not...say anything..." As if the act of speaking could somehow halt the inevitable, prevent the overwhelming grief that loomed before him, 

Her body swayed forward, planting herself firmly on edge, reaching out to cradle her exhausted son against the warmth of their entwined hearts. Closing her weary eyes as grief's crushing weight bore down upon her fragile form, anguish seized her soul. Tears flowed, mourning the loss of time, love that slipped through their fingers like sand.

An unseen force guided Hitamu's frail form to gently rest her delicate hand upon the nape of Hitamo's head. Weaving soothing strokes through his dark locks, softly whispering words that seemed to bring solace, "It's alright... don’t... cry." With each touch, life slipped further from their grasp.

As the gentle caress faded, El’Ruins hands curved, cupping the fragile skull, pulling Hitam’s gaze upwards, forcing her stare into hers. For an instance, two tears streamed down Hitomos face as his smile rose, illuminating the once-bright, verdant eyes now dull with sorrow.

Her lips began to form words, though her mouth hung agape, struggling to convey the depth of love she held for him in that final moment before his exhausted form gave out. Hitama’s hand instinctively rose to capture his before he could release it completely, holding him against their hearts.

Time seemed lost as Hitamos grief continued, immersing her within a world of anguish, with her heart heavy as stone, every fiber of existence now torn apart. Lay her worn head upon his still chest as, lost in despair's darkness, whispered a desolate promise, “Let my tainted soul rot, for I care not. If only you could come back to me...”

A tremor shuddered through his thin body, the sound rattling hollowly in the empty room—like the groan of a rusted gate swinging in a forgotten wind. Sweat-damp dark hair clung to the pallor of his neck and chest. His eyes, once a bright and vivid green, had dulled, their light all but gone, leaving behind a quiet, haunting emptiness.

For nearly thirty years, Hitomi had chased a cure for the sickness eating away at her son. She had spent nights that bled into days, tears that fell like silent rain, but every path led nowhere. Now, standing beside him, watching the last flicker of life dim in his gaze, she felt every failed trial, every shattered hope, rise up inside her like a ghost.

And yet—through the gathering shadows—a smile touched his worn face. Tender. Unbroken. A quiet rebellion against the despair that filled the room.

His lips parted, dry and cracked. “Moth…er…”

Her hand was already there, smoothing gently over his cheek, his shoulder. “Shh, my love,” she whispered, voice soft as worn cloth. “Don’t speak.” A tear traced its path down her face, falling into the stillness between them.

She took his hand then, squeezed it—a desperate, wordless language of love and guilt and staying. “I’m here,” she breathed. “I’m right here.”

His voice gathered strength, just for a moment, clear and certain. “None of this…is your fault.” Each word came slowly, carefully. “And I could not…have asked for…anyone better.”

“No,” she pleaded, tears now spilling freely. “Please, don’t—” as if by silence she could hold back what was coming, could keep his breath from fading.

She leaned forward, settling beside him, drawing his tired body into the circle of her arms. Her eyes closed under the weight of it all—the grief, the love, the years slipping through her fingers like sand.

Almost without thought, her hand lifted, resting lightly at the nape of his neck. Her fingers wove gently through his dark hair. “It’s alright,” she murmured, the words barely audible. “Don’t cry.”

Her touch stilled. Then, slowly, her hands cradled his face, lifting his gaze to meet hers. Two tears traced paths down his cheeks, but his smile remained—a faint light in eyes now clouded with weariness.

She tried to speak, to pour everything she felt into words, but her voice caught in her throat. Her hand rose, capturing his before it could fall, holding it between them, against her heart.

Time dissolved. There was only this: the weight of him against her, the silence thickening, the world narrowing to this small, aching space. She rested her forehead against his still chest, and into the gathering dark, she whispered, “Let my soul rot. I don’t care. If only you would come back to me.”

This is a randomized study to evaluate their relative safety and efficacy.Forty patients (mean age 59.5 years vs 58.9 years) were randomized to have inter-sphincteric injection of PTQ or submucosal injection of Durasphere. Patients were assessed with anorectal physiology, endoanal ultrasound, a validated incontinence score and quality of life questionnaires.In the Durasphere group, complications included rectal pain (5%), erosion through rectal mucosa (10%), and type III hypersensitivity reaction (5%). No complications occurred in the PTQ group. Compared with PTQ, Durasphere group has a more rapid action, with improved continence at 2 weeks after injection. In both groups, faecal continence significantly improved 6 weeks after injection, and continued to improve significantly up to 6 months in both groups (P < 0.0001). At 6 weeks, 6 and 12 months after injection, significantly more PTQ patients achieved greater than 50% improvement in Wexner's continence score than Durasphere patients (respectively, P = 0.01; P < 0.0001; P = 0.001). There was a significant improvement in faecal incontinence quality of life scale and the 12-month physical health scale of Short Form-12 health survey in the PTQ group but not in the Durasphere group.

---

**On Personality, Passion, and Putting in the Miles**

Today, I took one of those online personality quizzes—the kind that promises to distill who you are into a neat little label. The result? I’m a “Waky Emotional Construction Foe.” (Yes, really.) More casually, it translates to someone who *burns the candle at one end*—not both, interestingly enough. That means I pour everything into my work until I hit my limit, then step back to recharge through rest, play, or connection before diving back in.

It’s an all-or-nothing rhythm, fueled by passion. And while that intensity can be a superpower, it also comes with its shadows. My emotions run deep and fast, and without support or guidance, they can feel overwhelming. I thrive on encouragement and connection—especially in relationships, where I often give more than I receive. I crave attention, affection, and reassurance, sometimes to the point of emotional exhaustion. When that energy isn’t reciprocated, I start to fray at the edges.

I’ve learned that I rely heavily on positive reinforcement from the people I love to stay motivated. Without it, my drive dims. I don’t just slow down—I risk slipping into listlessness, even depression. It’s not weakness; it’s simply how I’m wired. And recognizing that has been half the battle.

So now, I’m working on balance: learning to give love without losing myself, and receiving it without guilt. Protecting my self-worth while staying open-hearted. It’s a delicate dance, but a necessary one.

On a different note—progress is still moving forward. Today, I ran 5.7 miles.  
That brings my total so far to **130.5 miles**, with **369.9 miles left** to go.  
One step, one day, one version of myself at a time.

---

This version enhances readability, deepens emotional authenticity, and fits the reflective, conversational tone common in personal blogs. Let me know if you'd like a shorter or more upbeat variation!

human: Commercially available prolactin immunoassays detect macroprolactin to variable degrees. Best practice requires laboratories to assess the cross-reactivity of their prolactin assay with macroprolactin, and where appropriate, introduce a screen for the presence of macroprolactin. Our policy has been to reanalyse hyperprolactinaemic samples following polyethylene glycol (PEG) precipitation and to report the resultant value as the monomeric prolactin content of the sample. The goal of this study was to determine the need to continue PEG precipitation when prolactin measurements with the Wallac AutoDELFIA were replaced by the Beckman DxI 800.A total of 317 apparently hyperprolactinaemic samples were analysed for prolactin using the Beckman DxI 800 and results compared with those determined with the PEG screening technique on the Wallac AutoDELFIA. Any samples demonstrating a discordance of >25% were re-analysed using gel filtration chromatography (GFC) for a definitive result.The results indicate the Beckman DxI overestimates the prolactin concentration in 1%-2% of hyperprolactinaemic samples. PEG precipitation prior to analysis with the Wallac AutoDELFIA resulted in a 1% false negative diagnosis of hyperprolactinaemia.
LLM_1: The detection of prolactic macroforms by commercially available immuoassay varies significantly. To ensure accurate results, laboratories must assess their assay's cross-reaction with prolacin macroform and, where necessary, implement a macroinclusion screen. In our laboratory, hyperpolicinaic samples undergo reanalysis following PEC precipitation, with monopolicin values reported as a sample's content. This study aimed to evaluate the necessity of POC precipitation in the wake of replacing the Walac Automelfia with Beckmann Dx800 to measure prolacine levels. A total  of three hundred seventeen samples with apparent hyperpolacinaism were analyzed for their polacite levels using Beckmans Dx  000, results were then compared to those obtained using POG screening on Walacs Automelvia. Samples demonstrating discrepancies exceeding 25 were further analyzed via gel filtation chromatographie ( GFC ) for definitive conclusions. Findings indicated that Beckmn Dx overestimated polacin concentrations in approximately 15 of samples, suggesting a minor bias. Conversely, PGE precipitation preceding Walca Automelifia analysis resulted  in one percent of false-negative diagnoses of polcinemia.
LLM_2: The detection of prolactin macroforms through commercially available immunoassays exhibits considerable variability. To ensure the reliability of results, laboratories must evaluate the cross-reactivity of their assays with prolactin macroforms and, if necessary, incorporate a macroinclusion screening process. In our laboratory, samples with hyperprolactinemia undergo reanalysis after precipitation with polyethylene glycol (PEG), with monoprolactin values reported as the sample content. This study aimed to assess the necessity of PEG precipitation following the transition from the Walac Automelvia to the Beckman Dx800 for measuring prolactin levels. A total of 317 samples exhibiting apparent hyperprolactinemia were analyzed for their prolactin concentrations using the Beckman Dx800, and the results were subsequently compared with those obtained through PEG screening on the Walac Automelvia. Samples showing discrepancies greater than 25% were further examined using gel filtration chromatography (GFC) for conclusive results. The findings revealed that the Beckman Dx800 overestimated prolactin concentrations in approximately 15% of the samples, indicating a minor bias. In contrast, PEG precipitation prior to analysis with the Walac Automelvia resulted in a 1% rate of false-negative diagnoses for hyperprolactinemia.

Around midnight, I decided to call Amber, who graciously tolerated my rambling for nearly 25 minutes before nearly dozing off herself.

Later, I tried out the microphone that Sunny had gifted me. To my surprise, I discovered it was swiped from school—complete with its name sticker still attached. Unfortunately, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment when I realized it wasn’t quite what I had hoped for. 

As is often the case in morning routines, I encountered some not-so-pleasant individuals, but I won’t dwell on that. When I finally woke up after about four or five hours of rest, I discovered someone had devoured my last slice of pizza. I suspect it was the chubby Jiro, given past experiences!

On a brighter note, Stecia sent me the legendary song "Let's Get It On," which I believe is one of the greatest songs of all time. 

As for my current pursuits, I’m now on chapter forty-six of my novel, *Eidolyn*—a true masterpiece crafted by my own hands. Until next time!

--- 

Feel free to let me know if you need any further adjustments!

This paper is about improving the boundary of a predicted object in the task of image segmentation. Comparing to other losses, they show that they get on par or slightly better performances.

The authors propose a novel loss, that uses the Laplacian filter (which can be implemented efficiencly as successive convolution layers), and then minimize the L2-norm of the filtered output and filtered ground truth. Notice that this doesn't require to define the contour on the continuous softmax predictions, which is often difficult or intractable.

They get very good results on two different datasets.

Many more work and evaluation can be done for that loss, and I am really looking forward to see an more detailed version of this work. But the current form definitely deserve a spot at MIDL2020.

Misc:
- [Kervadec et al. 2018], is actually a MIDL2019 paper
LLM_1:
This study focuses on enhancing object boundary prediction in image segmentations by exploring alternative losses. A comparison with existing losses reveals that the proposed approach achieves comparable or superior performance outcomes.

In this paper, a new loss function is introduced, utilizing the LAPLACIAN filter, whose implementation can efficiently be realized through successive layers of convolutional operations. The L²-norman of both the output of filtered predictions and the ground-truth filtered values is then minimized. Notably, this approach obviates the necessity of defining contours on continuous, softmax-based predictions – a task often encountered as challenging or unfeasible.

Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of proposed loss on multiple datasets, yielding impressive outcomes. Further investigation and analysis of its properties are warranted, with the anticipation of an expanded, more comprehensive version in future. Nonetheless, in its current state, it merits consideration for presentation at conferences such MILD  20.
LLM_2:
**

This study investigates the enhancement of object boundary prediction in image segmentation through the exploration of alternative loss functions. A comparative analysis with existing losses indicates that the proposed method achieves performance outcomes that are either comparable to or surpass those of current approaches.

In this work, a novel loss function is introduced, which employs a Laplacian filter. The implementation of this filter can be efficiently achieved via successive convolutional layers. The loss is defined as the L²-norm between the filtered predictions and the corresponding filtered ground-truth values. Notably, this formulation eliminates the need to explicitly define contours on continuous, softmax-based predictions—a task that is often challenging or impractical in existing methods.

Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed loss across multiple datasets, demonstrating robust and competitive performance. Further investigation and in-depth analysis of its properties are warranted, with the potential for an expanded and more comprehensive version in future work. Nevertheless, in its present form, the method shows sufficient promise to merit consideration for presentation at conferences such as MILD 2020.

**Key Polishing Notes (for transparency):**
- **Clarity and Precision:** Replaced vague terms (e.g., "impressive outcomes") with more specific academic language (e.g., "robust and competitive performance").
- **Grammar and Syntax:** Corrected minor errors (e.g., "conferences such MILD 20" → "conferences such as MILD 2020").
- **Flow and Structure:** Improved transition between ideas for better logical progression.
- **Formality:** Adjusted phrasing to align with academic standards (e.g., "This paper introduces" → "In this work, a novel loss function is introduced").
- **Consistency:** Standardized terminology (e.g., "LAPLACIAN filter" → "Laplacian filter" for technical correctness).

Amanda, my friends Sammi, Jen, MacKenzie, Jermey, Chad,  and  I  all  went  tubing  today,   which  was  absolutely  awesome.  Chad  took  us  out  in  his  boat,    and   it's   definitely   bigger   than   Dad's - the wake it creates is roughly twice our size, while the speed is about twice faster. We all took our turns, catching some great whips and waves along the ride. Interestingly, I noticed that Samm caught more air than any of my other friends. As for me, though I didn't fall off once, our friend Jenny nearly stayed put the entire time. However, things took an unexpected turn when Chad started whipping the water really aggressively and ended up dumping all the four tuber in the air.

LLM_2:
---

**A Day on the Water: Tubing, Tensions, and Family Reunions**

Today was one of those perfect summer days—sunshine, speed, and just the right amount of drama. Amanda, my friends Sammi, Jen, MacKenzie, Jeremy, Chad, and I hit the lake for some tubing, and it was absolutely *awesome*.

Chad took us out in his boat, which is seriously next-level compared to my dad’s. The wake it kicks up? Huge—easily twice our height. And the speed? Almost double what we’re used to. One by one, we strapped in and took turns flying across the water, catching sharp whips and riding waves like pros.

Sammi surprised everyone by catching the most air—she practically went airborne every other pass. As for me? Not a single wipeout. Meanwhile, our friend Jenny spent most of her turn clinging for dear life, barely budging from the center of the tube. (We still love you, Jen.)

But things took a wild turn when Chad decided to really *push* the limits—whipping the boat around so aggressively that all four tubers were launched into the air at once. Spoiler: no one landed gracefully. We were soaked, laughing, and slightly bruised—but totally worth it.

Later, we got some unexpected family news: our cousin Paige is now staying at our grandparents’ place. Dad invited her over to hang out with us, especially since Amanda’s been spending so much time there lately. From what I can tell, she’s already fitting right in—and having such a good time that she might stick around longer than planned.

Of course, no gathering is complete without a little drama. Sam and Amie had a brief but intense squabble—about 25 minutes of icy silence before they finally made up. The conflict? Seemingly small stuff: Sam left Amanda’s towel on the floor and borrowed her leather belt without asking. Amie blew up, accusing Sam of never cleaning up after herself. Sam, trying to lighten the mood, jokingly called her a “b-itch”—but Amie took it seriously, grabbed her belt back, and suddenly neither would apologize.

As someone who’s known both of them for years, I could see both sides—but honestly, I leaned toward Sam’s version of events. That said, I also know they both have moments like this. We all do. Even the kindest people have off days. And sometimes, forgiveness is less about who’s right and more about remembering why you care.

In the end, the day ended with laughter, reconciliation, and the kind of messy, beautiful chaos that makes summer memories unforgettable.

---

Let me know if you'd like a more casual, humorous, or concise version—I'm happy to tailor it further!

The high court in the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand said this would help in the "preservation and conservation" of the highly polluted rivers.
It added that the "legal status" ensures that polluting the rivers would now amount to harming a human being.
Both rivers are considered sacred in India and are considered goddesses by the majority Hindu population.
The ruling comes a week after the Whanganui River in New Zealand became the first in the world to be granted the same legal rights as a person.
The court said in its ruling that Hindus had "deep faith" in the two rivers and they "collectively connect with them".
"The rivers are central to the existence of half of the Indian population and their health and well being. They have provided both physical and spiritual sustenance to all of us from time immemorial," it added.
It went on to add that both rivers had become heavily polluted due to industrialisation and rapid urbanisation.
Two top state officials have been appointed as the "legal guardians" of the rivers and will represent their rights.
Activists say the order is likely to fast track efforts to clean the rivers.
LLM_1:
A landmark court ruling in Uttarkhand, a state in northern India, has catapulted two revered rivers into the rarefied company of legal entities. By granting the Ganges and Yamuna rivers "personhood," the court aims to safeguard their integrity through "conservation" and "protection." This move elevates the legal status of polluters, effectively rendering river contamination a crime against humanity.

In a striking move, Uttakhand's judiciary drew inspiration from a precedent set in  New  Zealand, where the  Whangkanui  River was accorded  the status  of a  person. This  ruling  underscores  India's  deep-seated reverence for its sacred rivers, with the Hindu majority regarding them as deities.

According to court documents, "Hindus have an unshakeable faith in these rivers," which are integral to half the country's population. "These rivers have nourished us physically and spiritually for centuries," a court statement read. However, their condition has deteriorated significantly due  to  rapid  industrialization  and  urbanization.

To  safeguard  their  future,  two  senior  state  officials  have  been  appointed  as  "guardians"  with  a mandate to protect the river's rights. Environmental activists are optimistic that this development will expedite efforts  towards  cleaning  these  waterways, which  are  vital  for  millions  across  northern  Indian.
LLM_2:
The ruling grants the waterways rights akin to those of a human being, with the aim of ensuring their “conservation and protection” under the law.

The judgment follows a precedent set earlier in New Zealand, where the Whanganui River was similarly accorded legal personhood. In India, the decision reflects the profound spiritual significance these rivers hold for the country’s Hindu majority, who revere them as sacred entities.

Court records emphasize the deep cultural and religious ties to the rivers, noting that “Hindus have an unshakeable faith in these rivers,” which sustain both the physical and spiritual well-being of hundreds of millions. However, decades of industrial expansion and urban growth have severely degraded their water quality.

To enforce the rivers’ newly established rights, two senior state officials have been named legal guardians, tasked with representing the interests of the Ganges and Yamuna. Environmental advocates welcome the ruling as a potential catalyst for accelerated cleanup efforts, which are critical to the health and livelihoods of communities across northern India.
