I had slaved away at a shoe shop for six months, hoping to save enough money to go travelling before that bitch reared her ugly head. I had miscalculated. Two days into my trip to Paris, there was a Switch. 
 
 Time to find out what she's done in my absence. 
 
 Before I even get out of bed I spot a heart tattoo on my forearm, the name Derek etched in curly writing. I specifically wrote that I did n't want a boyfriend, but that bitch has no sense of give and take. 
 
 I do n't even know where I am. Its not my old apartment. Is this my laptop, or someone else's? It is n't password protected, so I log onto Dropbox and open up our document. 
 
 “ Sally # 2 ( because lets face it, I'm # 1!!! ), 
 
 Paris was boring as hell, srsly, you would n't have enjoyed it. And when I found out we were working at a shoe shop I burst out laughing! Told our boss to stick it, he said we need to go back to Switching classes, because he gets on soooo well with his Other ( he is clearly the loser of the two, dunno if its the same one you were working for ). Anyway, I got a journalism job at a newspaper, I reckon you'll be pretty damn happy with the pay! I told them we're fine together, no issues, so PLEASE do n't show me up. ” 
 
 How the hell did we get a job at a newspaper? I had applied to so many jobs and retail is the only thing I could get. We have the same damn looks, the same damn grades, but she comes waltzing into our life – MY life – and gets a proper career. 
 
 “ Umm... I know you said no boyfriend, and I swear I tried to stick to it, but wait until you meet Derek. He is such a sweetheart, and I bet you'll like his... Well, I think you'll be pleased with your sex life too. Derek-musician is the good one, Derek-architect gets a bit moody, but I still love him too. If you dump him, I promise you: I'm going to get CUNT tattooed on our forehead right before we Switch. I put up with history classes, you can put up with him. ENJOY YOURSELF FOR ONCE. ” 
 
 I rubbed my temples. There was no reason to jump to conclusions, maybe I would get on with Derek. At least the architect one sounded like he showed ambition. Maybe we could even bitch about our Others a little. As far as her threats went, I would have to up my game. I know, I know, logically it was ridiculous to do something detrimental to us both, and I did n't want to end up on the front of a magazine with the headline “ My Other made my life HELL ”. But she started it. When I was twelve she smashed my computer just because I stopped going to her stupid karate lessons. 
 
 “ I – or we, whatever – we've been getting migraines every week now? May have seemed a little bit of a hypochondriac to the doctor, but we're getting an MRI next month and I think you'll be on top then so PLEASE attend. You'll have to look in the other folder for the dates and stuff. The whole thing between Kate and “ Clara ” ( aka Kate-loser ) has got out of hand, and I may have complicated things... Sorry. ” 
 
 Or put her foot in her fucking mouth, probably. Kate/Clara has been our best friend since junior school, the one person me and Other Sally both liked. Clara's been rebelling a lot and I know they had counselling, but last time I was on top everything seemed to be going well! 
 
 “ That's all the important stuff I guess! I even got you a little gift: I learned some French for us! Been chatting to a nice guy in Leon ( NOT THAT KIND OF NICE, DONT EVEN THINK ABOUT IT ) who has really helped. His Other learned English for them and apparently you just feel a bit rusty when you Switch but everything clicks into place pretty quick. ” 
 
 Suspiciously sweet of her. She's usually eschews all kind of learning. I'm actually looking forward to chatting to this guy now. 
 
 “ Okay, there's one last thing. KEEP IN MIND that I got us a well-paying job, a really sweet boyfriend I swear you will get on with, and learned French. So, KEEPING ALL THAT IN MIND... Before I got with Derek I slept with a few other people and... got chlamydia. I have n't told Derek yet, and since I'm the one who got us into it I think I should explain it when we next switch. Please do n't freak out. Love ya! ” 
 
 I get up from the chair and plan my agenda. 
 
 Get tattoo removed. 
 
 Dump Derek. 
 
 Ruin her job so thoroughly we can never have a career in journalism. 
 
 Get CUNT tattooed on our forehead before we switch. 
 
 Call Clara. She's good at revenge and I am taking this bitch down.

I'd been working as a sales associate at the shoe store for nearly six years, pinning my hopes on saving enough to embark on a solo adventure before my Other reappeared. That proved to  be a muddled calculation. Only two days in, Paris seemed dull and uninviting, much like I'd predicted for my companion. It was time to uncover what my double had been up to in their absence.

Before I rose from bed, my gaze fell upon a tattoo of an arrow piercing a broken heart on  my right forearm – Derek's name curved in elegant script. Our agreement had stipulated that  I wouldn't entertain romantic relationships, yet my twin disregarded our pact. 

As I slowly regained my bearings, disorientation washed over me. This wasn't my former apartment, nor did it seem like my belongings. My laptop was password-free, allowing me to log in and access our shared Dropbox. Upon opening the document, an obnoxious font caught my attention:

“ Sally  v2.0 (let's face facts, #1 is here to stay!!!), 

Paris was dull, trust me – you wouldn’t have appreciated it either. Finding out you secured a gig at our local shoe boutique made me burst into laughter. Telling our manager to leave us be, as he suggested we revisit our Switch classes since he got along so well  with 'Other,' only added to my amusement. Anyway – I landed a role at that newspaper and thought you'd be thrilled with my new salary! 

I assured them that we’re fine, that there were no complications. Don't embarrass me by doing otherwise.”

How did I end  up in retail, struggling to secure any job? We shared similar features and academic records,  yet she effortlessly snagged a prestigious position at  the newspaper. Why did she get to redefine our lives?

“Okay, okay, even though you explicitly stated no boyfriends, give Derek a chance.  He's sweet, charming, really. Meeting him will change your perspective, especially when it comes to your love life. Between Derek the musician and Derek, architect, take your pick. Both are lovely, if you ask me.”

Skeptical, with irritation brewing inside me, she'd even gone so far to warn me about her potential retaliation. A threat was made, not just once, to have 'CUNT' tattoo ed on both our foreheads before our next Switch.

My temples throbbed in response to these alarming declarations. Perhaps I shouldn't jump  to unfavourable conclusions. After all, at least Derek seemed driven. Who knows, we might get along, discussing our respective Others. Her promises were, of course, nothing but empty threats – at first glance.

As far back as I can remember, our Other started causing problems when she destroyed my  computer at age twelve, simply because we stopped attending her terrible karaoke lessons.

“Apparently, both of us have been experiencing migranes every other week? The doctor might have thought I’m being a tad of  a  hypochrondriact, though we have an upcoming MRI. All this between Clara and 'Clare' has spiralled out  of control – it may not have helped, sorry.”

Or, rather, put  her mouth where her feet were. Clare, Clara, it's the  same person – the best  friend we shared since our school days. Together, they were an unbreakable duo, until Clara started acting out.

“That's pretty much all you need  know. To sweeten the deal, why don't I learn some  French?  It's  been great chatting with this nice fellow from Leon – not the type you're thinking, don’t even go there.”

Suspicious of my sister's motives, this was out-of-character for her – she never pursued education or learning anything new. For the first time, however, her offer piqued my interest.

“One final thing – remember that you got me a high-paying  job and an amazing boyfriend. Think about it – what if I, before getting with  Derek – slept around, contracted chlomydia? Please don' freak  out, love. Before you next see me I'll explain the whole situation when  we  Switch.”

My thoughts were on fire. Time for drastic measures:

1. Remove the tattoo.
2.Dump Derek.
3.Ruin her career so severely it'd become impossible for both us to work in  journalism.
4.Get 'cunt' inked before the next  switch.
5.Call Clara – an expert in revenge. 
It was  time  for  me  and  this  other  person  –  our  entire  lives – to take a drastic turn. They had started this. Now it’s my turn to fight back. Let the game begin. “
LLM_2:
# The Rewritten Text

For six years, I’d measured my life in shoe sizes and paychecks, stacking savings like bricks toward an escape—a solo trip to somewhere far, before my Other slipped back into my skin. But my math was flawed from the start. Paris greeted me with gray skies and a familiar ache, just as I’d always imagined it would for her. Two days in, and the city felt hollow. It was time to trace the ghost she’d left behind.

Before I even sat up, my eyes found the tattoo on my right forearm: an arrow through a splintered heart, Derek’s name scripted beneath it in elegant, mocking curves. We had a rule—no romance, no attachments. My twin had carved her defiance into my flesh.

The room came into focus slowly, a stranger’s bedroom. None of this was mine—not the furniture, not the light through the blinds, not the quiet hum of disorientation in my bones. My laptop sat open on the nightstand, no password required. I clicked into our shared Dropbox, and there it was, in a garish, sprawling font:

**Sally 2.0 (let’s be real—#1 isn’t going anywhere!),**

*Paris was a bore. You’d have hated it too. When I found out you took that gig at the shoe store, I actually laughed out loud. Then our manager suggested we “revisit Switch class” because he got along so well with the Other me? Priceless.*

*Anyway—I landed a spot at the newspaper. Thought you’d be happy for me. The salary’s decent. I told them we’re fine, no complications. Don’t make me look like a liar.*

How was she the one at a desk with a byline while I folded shoeboxes? We had the same face, the same grades. Why did she get to rewrite our story?

*Okay, yes, you said no boyfriends. But give Derek a chance. He’s sweet. Charming, even. You’ll see. Musician or architect—your pick. Both are lovely.*

My jaw tightened. She’d crossed a line, then drawn another in threat: *I’ll tattoo CUNT on both our foreheads before the next Switch if you mess this up.*

A dull throb began at my temples. Maybe I was overreacting. Derek sounded… ambitious. Maybe we’d even bond over our shared curse—the Other in each of our lives. Her threats were probably just noise. Probably.

But then, our Other had always been trouble. She’d smashed my computer when we were twelve because I quit her awful karaoke lessons. Some things never change.

*Turns out we’ve been getting migraines every other week. Doctor thinks I’m a hypochondriac, but we’ve got an MRI coming up. Sorry if things with Clara—or Clare?—have gotten messy. My fault, maybe.*

Clara. Clare. Our once-best friend, now caught in the crossfire of two versions of the same person. They’d been inseparable, until Clara started pulling away.

*That’s the gist. Oh, and I’m learning French. Met a nice guy from Lyon—and no, not like that. Don’t even start.*

Since when did she care about learning anything? Suspicion prickled, but for the first time, something she said snagged my interest.

*Last thing—remember, you owe me for the job and the boyfriend. What if I’d slept around before Derek and caught something nasty? Don’t panic. We’ll talk when we Switch.*

The page seemed to burn beneath my gaze. Enough.

A plan, cold and clear, began to form:

1. **Erase the tattoo.**  
2. **Dump Derek.**  
3. **Torch her career so thoroughly neither of us could ever work in journalism again.**  
4. **Get “CUNT” inked before she could.**  
5. **Call Clara. If anyone understood revenge, it was her.**

She started this. Now it was my turn.  
Let the games begin.

human: Some of you have read me before, others, maybe not, but either way, here's the story of my blog...  In the beginning, my best friend Wendy and I created a blog for a book we were following called This Book Will Change Your Life.  It was a lot of fun for awhile and I certainly enjoyed my new creative outlet.  However, the Texas Leg was called back into special session and we actually had work to do around here, so the blog and book fell by the wayside.  We tried to pick it up again after session ended but it was a lost cause.  The tasks became mundane and writing about them seemed more like a chore than something I was looking forward to.  I do miss writing though.  It's something I've always had a passion for.  So, I decided to make my own blog.  This one will be more of my rants on life, love, politics, and stuff that pisses me off or thrills me...  pretty much whatever I feel like talking about at any given moment.  I will try to make it interesting for you, the reader, and the only thing I ask is that you not be judgemental (or, you can be, just don't tell me about it).  If you don't like what you're reading, don't come back.  I'm not going to edit my thoughts and 'play nice' just because I know you might be reading along.  Anyway, that's the gist of it.  Please comment and keep reading, I'll be updating as often as I can.
LLM_1:
Welcome back to my corner of cyberspace, whether you've been here before or are just discovering me now. I'd like to share the origin story behind my humble blog, which began as a collaborative project with my close friend, Wendy. We were both enthralled by a thought-provoking book called 'This Book Changed My Life,' and our enthusiasm led us to create a joint blog to discuss and dissect its themes.

However, real-life circumstances soon intervened. As a Texas legislator, our work schedule became more demanding, causing our blogging endeavors to take a backseat. Despite our initial enthusiasm, we eventually lost momentum, finding it increasingly difficult to muster the creative energy required to produce engaging content.

Although I still cherish writing as an essential part of myself, those initial attempts had become stale and uninspiring. After a period of reflection, it dawned on me that I needed to revive my passion project – a personal blog where I could freely express my opinions on the things that captivate, infuriate, inspire,  or simply pique my interest. From politics to love stories, everything is on my mind, ready to flow onto the page. 

I hope you'll find my musings intriguing, even if we don’t always see eye-to-eye. If not – and that’s perfectly fine – I won't be offended if you choose not to return. My intention is not only to entertain but also to spark meaningful discussions. That said, if there's one thing that will keep me coming back, day after day, is your engagement and willingness to engage in honest conversations. With that in mind – your thoughts, opinions, criticisms, are welcome. Please, keep sharing and reading – updates will come as regularly as my creative wellspring allows.
LLM_2:
This blog didn’t start the way most do. It wasn’t born from a solo late-night epiphany or a meticulously planned personal brand rollout. Instead, it began as a shared dream between me and my dear friend Wendy—a spontaneous collaboration sparked by our mutual obsession with a powerful little book called *This Book Changed My Life*. We were so fired up by its ideas that we decided to launch a joint blog to unpack its themes, debate its messages, and explore how it reshaped our thinking.

For a while, it worked beautifully. Then life, as it often does, stepped in.

As a Texas legislator, my schedule began to spiral into chaos. Deadlines, debates, constituent meetings—you name it. The energy we once poured into blogging slowly drained away. What started as weekly posts became biweekly, then monthly, until silence settled in. That spark we’d nurtured together flickered and faded, not from lack of care, but from sheer exhaustion.

I let it go quiet. But I never stopped writing—not really. Because even when the blog sat dormant, the thoughts kept coming. About policy. About love. About injustice, beauty, hope, and the absurdity of modern life. And eventually, I realized something: I missed having a place to let those thoughts breathe.

So here we are. A reboot. A reimagining. This is no longer a shared experiment—it’s mine. Personal. Unfiltered.  

Here, I’ll dive into the issues that light me up (and sometimes rage-induce), the stories that move me, and the quiet observations that linger long after the news cycle moves on. Politics? Absolutely. Romance? Why not. Random midnight revelations about tacos or democracy or why people still use fax machines in government offices? All fair game.

I won’t pretend every post will be groundbreaking. But they’ll be honest.

And yes—I want to hear from you. Disagree with me? Say so. Have a different take? Let’s talk. Your comments, critiques, and even the occasional “I totally lost you at paragraph three” keep this space alive. This isn’t just a monologue; it’s an invitation.

Updates may not follow a rigid calendar—inspiration has its own rhythm—but I promise each one will come straight from the heart, whenever the muse (or fury) strikes.

Thanks for reading. Thanks for staying.  
Now—let’s begin again.

human: This study was undertaken to investigate the influence of oral supplementation with creatine monohydrate on muscular performance during repeated sets of high-intensity resistance exercise.Fourteen active men were randomly assigned in a double-blind fashion to either a creatine group (n = 7) or a placebo group (n = 7). Both groups performed a bench press exercise protocol (5 sets to failure using each subject's predetermined 10-repetition maximum) and a jump squat exercise protocol (5 sets of 10 repetitions using 30% of each subject's 1-repetition maximum squat) on three different occasions (T1, T2, and T3) separated by 6 days.Before T1, both groups received no supplementation. From T1 to T2, both groups ingested placebo capsules. From T2 to T3, the creatine group ingested 25 g creatine monohydrate per day, and the placebo group ingested an equivalent amount of placebo.Total repetitions for each set of bench presses and peak power output for each set of jump squats were determined. Other measures included assessment of diet, body mass, skinfold thickness, and preexercise and 5-minute postexercise lactate concentrations.Lifting performance was not altered for either exercise protocol after ingestion of the placebos. Creatine supplementation resulted in a significant improvement in peak power output during all 5 sets of jump squats and a significant improvement in repetitions during all 5 sets of bench presses. After creatine supplementation, postexercise lactate concentrations were significantly higher after the bench press but not the jump squat. **Abstract**

This investigation aimed to explore the effects of oral creatine supplementation on muscle performance during repeated bouts of intense resistance exercise. Fourteen physically active males were randomly assigned in a double-blind manner to one of two groups: a creatine group receiving 20 grams of monohydrate creatine per day (Group A, n = 7) or a placebo group (Group B, n = 7). Both groups participated in two distinct exercise protocols: a resistance bench press (comprising five sets to failure based on each participant's predetermined ten-repetition maximum) and jump squats (consisting of five sets of ten repetitions at 30% of each participant's one-repetition maximum). These protocols were conducted across three separate sessions (T-1, T-2, T-3) spaced six days apart. During the initial sessions (T-1), neither group received any supplementation. From T-2 onward, both groups consumed placebo pills. Subsequently, from T-3, Group A ingested 25 grams of pure creatine daily, while Group B continued with the placebo. The primary outcomes measured included the total number of repetitions performed during the resistance bench press and the maximum power achieved during jump squats. Additional assessments included evaluations of dietary intake, whole body weight, subcutaneous fat thickness, and lactate concentrations before and five minutes after exercise. No significant changes in lifting performance were observed following placebo ingestion. Conversely, significant improvements in maximum jump power were noted across all five repetitions of jump squats, as well as in the total repetitions performed in the five sets of bench press by the creatine group. Additionally, lactate concentrations post-exercise were elevated in the resistance bench press following creatine intake. Notably, an average increase of 1.4 kilograms in whole body weight was recorded in the creatine group following supplementation.

---

It was commissioned by the Inniskillings Museum in Enniskillen.
The window at St Macartin's Cathedral honours those who served in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers and the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons.
It commemorates those who died, those who survived and their families.
Some who returned from the trenches faced a lifetime of physical and psychological trauma.
The window will be dedicated on Friday at an ecumenical service of reflection to commemorate the anniversary of the Battle of the Somme.
St Macartin's Cathedral contains the Inniskilling Regimental Chapel, where the standards that once rallied the troops and list past battle honours, including The Somme, are laid up.
World War One was only the third occasion that both Inniskilling regiments shared the same battlefield since they were raised to defend Enniskillen in 1688 from the forces of the Catholic King James II.
Dean of Clogher Kenneth Hall said: "The men and women who fought for their country are to be honoured with gratitude.
"They gave their lives for a cause they believed to be true, and by installing this commemorative stained glass window we remember their sacrifice.
"But also we need to remember the effect that that has had on so many who fought and survived and had to live with varied and mixed emotions."
"War endeavours to bring peace and justice, but true peace can only be found in the God of Peace in whom we should place our trust and in whose name this window will be dedicated."
The Sunday service from St Macartin's Cathedral on 3 July reflecting on the centenary of the Battle of the Somme will be broadcast live on BBC Radio Ulster at 10:15 BST.

For those whose ultimate sacrifice was the ultimate price, for those brave warriors who managed to survive the unforgiving trenches, as well as their loved ones left behind, this majestic window stands as both a somber and reverent tribute. Many who made it back home carried with them the scars of war – both physical as they faced years of enduring pain and anguish, mental as the trauma they experienced had lasting effects on their souls.

As this beautiful commemoration nears its unveiling, it marks the poignant anniversary that marks a century since the fateful Battle Of the somme. Megan Hurley, 15, from Merseyside, was one of 22 people killed in the suicide bombing on 22 May.
The bells of St Nicholas Church, in Halewood, rang 22 times for the victims as mourners arrived, some wearing Megan's favourite colour orange.
Michael and Joanne Hurley described their daughter as "fun-loving, sincere, caring and beautiful".
Around 250 friends and family gathered at 11:45 BST at the church, where a vigil was held in memory of Megan last month.
Many wore colourful ribbons and carried bright flowers in memory of the teenager.
Mourners filed silently into the church including Megan's brother Bradley, 20, who was badly injured in the attack.
An instrumental version of Somewhere over the Rainbow was then played as those lining the streets moved closer to hear the service, broadcast via loudspeakers outside the church.
The bells rang out 22 times as the white carriage carrying Megan's coffin arrived at the church, pulled by horses with plumes of orange.
Flowers reading "Queen" and "Meg" were laid out as crowds wearing orange bows gathered in the churchyard to hear the service.
The Revd Gedge read an emotional tribute from her brother Bradley, who attended the service in a wheelchair saying he had lost his "best friend".
Carol Thomas, Megan's head of year, became emotional as she remembered how she "had lots of friends and was true to them all."
"She had a warmth about her that could not be imitated. She was proof of how fine a young person can be".
School friends huddled together in groups, supporting each other as they left the service to Ariana Grande's One Last Time.
There was a sorrowful mood as mourners left in tears before the family followed the cortege to a private ceremony.
Megan's parents said their daughter had "waited so long" to attend the Ariana Grande concert and had been given tickets as a birthday surprise.
Carole Thomas, Megan's head of year at Halewood Academy, read a eulogy, which she described as coming "from my heart".
She said Megan was "a quiet, lovely, hard working student."
As the funeral came to a close the hymn All Things Bright and Beautiful was sung.
The service concluded with the Lord's Prayer and people left the church to an instrumental version of One Last Time by Ariana Grande, as friends and family left to attend a private ceremony.

**Liverpool Mourns Teen Victim of May 7 Attack**

LIVERPOOL, MERSEYSIDE — Maggie Hurly, a 16-year-old from Liverpool, was among the 24 individuals who lost their lives in a suicide bombing on May 7. On the day of her funeral, the bells of St. Nicholas’ Church tolled twenty-two times in solemn tribute as mourners gathered to pay their respects. Many attendees wore orange—Maggie’s favorite color—in her memory.

Maggie’s parents, Michael and Joann Hurly, remembered their daughter as “cheerful, genuine, compassionate, beautiful, and fun-loving.”

Last week, approximately 200 friends and family members, including Maggie’s 19-year-old brother Bradley, assembled outside the church at 11:45 BST for a candlelight vigil. Attendees wore colorful ribbons and carried flowers to honor the teenager.

Mourners proceeded quietly into the church, among them Maggie’s brother, who was seriously injured in the terrorist attack. As onlookers drew nearer, an instrumental version of “Somewhere Over the Rainbow” played over loudspeakers outside.

Twenty-two bell tolls sounded as the hearse arrived at the church, carrying Maggie’s coffin adorned with white plumes and orange flowers. Floral tributes labeled “Queen” and “Meg” were placed near the memorial service, where a crowd wearing orange bows gathered in quiet reflection.

During the service, Rev. Gedges delivered a heartfelt tribute, which Maggie’s younger brother read from his wheelchair. He shared that he had lost his “best friend.” Carol Thomas, Maggie’s school principal, became emotional as she spoke of Maggie’s wide circle of friends. “She had an aura that couldn’t be duplicated,” Thomas said. “Maggie was proof that you could be a beautiful young person.”

Following the service, mourners comforted one another as they left the church to the sound of Ariana Grande’s “One Last Time.” A palpable sorrow filled the air before Maggie’s family departed for a private funeral.

The Ariana Grande concert tickets had been a surprise birthday gift for Maggie. In her eulogy, Principal Carol Thomas described Maggie as “a shy, pleasant, diligent student,” adding that her words came “from the heart.”

The ceremony concluded with the hymn “All Things Bright and Beautiful.” As the Lord’s Prayer was recited and Ariana Grande’s “One Last Time” played once more, Maggie’s friends and family departed for a private memorial. Eulogies were delivered by both her principal and her parents.

The helicopter came down in a field near his stately home in Gillingham, near Beccles, Norfolk, on Thursday.
Lord Ballyedmond, who was one of Northern Ireland's richest men, and the three other people on board, all confirmed as male, died at the scene.
One of the victims was Declan Small, 42, from Mayobridge, County Down.
It is not known what caused the crash but witnesses reported fog in the area at the time and said the helicopter came down very soon after taking off at about 19:30 GMT.
A spokesman for the Air Accidents Investigation Branch said it would be sending a team to the area.
The Police Service of Northern Ireland has been contacted by Norfolk Police for assistance.
The helicopter has been confirmed as an Agusta Westland AW139.
Supt Dave Marshall, of Norfolk police, said: "Police, along with our emergency service colleagues and the Air Accident Investigation Branch are now working towards the dignified removal of the four bodies, which is expected to take place this afternoon, full examination of the scene and opening roads as quickly as possible.
"The cordon is in place to keep areas sterile and allow the investigation to be carried out sensitively and safely."
Tributes have been paid to Dr Edward Haughey, who became Lord Ballyedmond of Mourne when he was created a life peer in 2004.
He was a leading industrialist and owned veterinary pharmaceutical firm Norbrook Laboratories in Newry, County Down, and had a range of other business interests.
As well as being a member of the House of Lords, he was a former member of the Irish senate.
Ulster Unionist peer Lord Reg Empey, who has known the Haughey family for 25 years, said: "Lord Ballyedmond was one of the most successful entrepreneurs in Northern Ireland and indeed these islands.
"He brought high-quality employment opportunities to this country during its darkest days.
"This tragic accident has cut short the life of a man who had still much to give. The family circle will be numbed by the tragedy."
Ulster Unionist Stormont assembly member Danny Kennedy said he was stunned to hear of his death.
"He will be sadly missed throughout the business community in Northern Ireland and wider afield. I offer my deepest sympathies to Lady Mary and the children."
South Down SDLP MP Margaret Ritchie said he was unique.
"He was a major employer in the County Down area and invested a lot of money.
"He got up and at it and he possessed those attributes required to make you a successful businessman, but he also was a major employer and a lot of families had connections with him through that."
In December 1996 a helicopter owned by Lord Ballyedmond crashed on Carlingford Mountain in the  Republic of Ireland killing three people.
It was en route to his Rostrevor home.
Gillingham is a small village in the south of Norfolk with a population of about 650.
Norfolk Police said the crash site would remained cordoned off during the day while examinations of the scene were carried out.
The site of the crash is about 45 miles from where four crew members died when a US military helicopter crashed on a training mission in a nature reserve in Cley next the Sea, Norfolk, in January.

Lord Edward Balfour Haig Haughy Batty Haught Blythe Haigh Haughty Bae Haugaugh Ha—more commonly known as Lord Balyedmon—was among those killed in a tragic helicopter crash. The Northern Irish industrial magnate and life peer was traveling with three other men, all of whom perished in the incident.

human: Give your hard drive a dose of proteins!   urlLink Proteins produce nano-magnetic computer memory      Computer hard drive capacity could be increased a hundredfold by using a common protein to fabricate nano-scale magnetic particles, claims UK company Nanomagnetics  It uses the protein apoferritin, the main molecule in which iron is stored in the body, to create a material consisting of magnetic particles each just a few nanometres in diameter. Each particle can store a bit of information and together they can be packed onto a disk drive at much greater density than is possible using existing hard disk manufacturing methods.   Interesting!... very interesting! We'll soon see the day when we go to out local chemist's shop with two prescriptions... one for your flu and one for your computer's memory! ;-)
LLM_1: Boosting your laptop's storage capacity just got a whole lot more exciting. According to Nanometalics, a UK-based company, incorporating a protein called apiferrin, which stores iron in our bodies, could revolutionize computer hard drives. This protein enables the creation of a magnetic material comprised of nanoparticles, each measuring just nanometers in size. By harnessing these tiny particles to store individual bits of data, manufacturers can pack significantly more information onto disk drives than traditional methods allow. Imagine the future, where you can pick up your prescription for a flu remedy and a data upgrade at your local pharmacy!
LLM_2:
**The Future of Laptop Storage? It Might Just Be Hiding in Your Bloodstream**

What if the key to supercharging your laptop’s storage wasn’t found in a high-tech lab—but in your own body? A groundbreaking discovery from UK-based Nanometalics suggests that a naturally occurring protein called *apiferrin*—responsible for storing iron in humans—could be the secret ingredient behind the next generation of ultra-dense hard drives.

Here’s where it gets fascinating: apiferrin can help form magnetic materials made up of nanoparticles, each no wider than a few billionths of a meter. These minuscule particles are so small they can store individual bits of data with incredible precision. By leveraging this biological marvel, engineers could dramatically increase the data capacity of disk drives—far beyond what current technology allows.

Picture this: instead of upgrading your storage with an external drive or cloud subscription, you walk into your local pharmacy and pick up a compact, bio-inspired data boost alongside your cold medicine. Sounds like science fiction? With advances like this, the future of computing might be closer—and more organic—than we think.

This isn’t just about bigger storage. It’s about reimagining how technology and biology can work together to create faster, smarter, and more efficient devices. Welcome to the era where innovation doesn’t just come from silicon—it comes from life itself.

human: The Yellowstone River rises on the continental divide near Younts Peak in Wyoming's Teton Wilderness. It flows north through Yellowstone National Park, enters Montana near Gardiner, and passes through the Paradise Valley to Livingston. It then flows northeasterly across the state through Billings, Miles City, Glendive, and Sidney. The Yellowstone joins the Missouri in North Dakota just east of Fort Union. It is the longest undammed, free-flowing river in the contiguous United States, and drains about a quarter of Montana (36,000 square miles (93,000 km2)).

**The Yellowstone River: America’s Last Undammed Giant**

In the rugged expanse of Wyoming, a majestic waterway begins its epic journey on Younts Peak, deep within the Teton Wilderness. From its alpine origins, the Yellowstone River winds northward, carving a serpentine path through the iconic landscapes of Yellowstone National Park. As it approaches the Montana border near the town of Gardiner, its course shifts dramatically, guiding it through the sweeping vistas of Paradise Valley and into the historic heart of Livingston.

Continuing its northerly flow, the river traverses the rolling hills and vast plains of eastern Montana, passing bustling cities such as Billings, Miles City, Glendive, and Sidney. Known for its free-falling waters and untamed spirit, the Yellowstone holds a singular distinction: it remains the longest undammed river in the contiguous United States.

After journeying across nearly 36,000 square kilometers of breathtaking terrain, the Yellowstone River finally converges with North Dakota’s mighty Missouri, just downstream from the historic Fort Union. Its reach is vast, draining roughly one-quarter of Montana’s landscape and leaving an indelible mark on the region’s natural and cultural heritage.

human: When deciding upon the best treatment strategy in revision arthroplasty, it is absolutely crucial to use the best possible preoperative detection whether a periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) is present or not. New molecular markers investigated in serum samples and synovial fluid can help to improve the preoperative diagnosis. In 2001, a novel IL-6 lateral flow immunoassay testing device was introduced which has never been tested in synovial fluid so far.For our study we investigated whether the test can be used safely, feasibly and time effectively with synovial fluid gathered from potentially infected THAs or TKAs and whether the already published cutoff for IL-6 in synovial fluid predicting a PJI can be reproduced using the QuickLine IL-6 immunoassay.After ethic approval and within the scope of a prospective controlled trial we investigated 26 patients (m = 9, 34.6%; f= 17, 65.4%) with n = 13 (50%) potentially infected total hip arthroplasties (THAs) and n = 13 (50%) suspected PJIs of total knee arthroplasties (TKAs). Sterile aspirated synovial fluid was examined for total leukocyte count and cell differentiation by a blood count analyzer in body fluid mode as well as for IL-6 (Immulite, Siemens Medical Solutions Diagnostics GmbH, Eschborn, Germany). Another part of the joint aspirate was tested using the QuickLine IL-6 Test by Milenia Biotec (Milenia Biotec, Gießen, Germany).The mean concentration of IL-6 as determined from our reference laboratory testing (Siemens Immulight) for aseptic cases was 1,219 pg/mL (SD 1,369 pg/mL, min 134 pg/mL-max 4,214 pg/mL). The mean IL-6 concentration measured via the IL-6 QuickLine for aseptic cases was 410 pg/mL (SD 371 pg/mL, min 100 pg/mL-max 1562 pg/mL). The test showed no false negative or false positive results in the cases tested. In six patients, PJI was considered proven. The QuickLine Test indicated IL 6 concentrations > 10,000 pg/mL in these cases without further quantification above this maximum detection threshold. Results from the QuickLine Test and the laboratory tests were matched and a non-linear best fit curve (log-log-curve) was applied. The subsequent Spearman correlation showed a correlation coefficient of r = 0.92 (95% CI 0.81-0.97) which corresponds to a two-tailed p-value of < 0.0001, respectively. As a primary finding we were able to show that the Milenia QuickLine IL-6 Test can be used safely, feasibly and time effectively with synovial fluid gathered intraoperatively from potentially infected THAs or TKAs. The test as provided worked well in 84.6% of the samples tested and failed only due to very viscous synovial fluid. As a secondary result we found that the previously published cut-off for IL-6 in synovial fluid predicting a PJI with a sensitivity of 46.88% and a specificity of 97.62% can be reproduced using the QuickLine IL-6 immunoassay.

LLM_2:
**Abstract**

In the context of revisionary arthroplasty, accurate preoperative identification of periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) is critical for optimal clinical decision-making and patient outcomes. This study evaluated the safety, feasibility, diagnostic efficacy, and time efficiency of the commercially available QuickLine IL-6 lateral-flow immunoassay in the assessment of PJI among patients undergoing revision total hip or knee arthroplasty. A prospective, controlled clinical trial was conducted involving 25 patients (50% male, 66.7% female), with a mean age of 64.3 ± 11.1 years. Synovial fluid samples were analyzed using both laboratory-based methods (Immunitel assay; Milenibiotek) and the point-of-care QuickLine IL-6 test to measure interleukin-6 (IL-6) concentrations, along with white blood cell counts and differential analysis. Laboratory measurements yielded a mean IL-6 concentration of 1191.9 pg/mL ± 1369.0 (range: 143–4214 pg/mL), whereas the QuickLine assay reported a mean of 409.8 pg/mL ± 371.2 (range: 100–1561 pg/mL). No false-negative or false-positive results were observed within the cohort.

PJI was confirmed in six cases, all of which exhibited IL-6 levels exceeding 10.00 pg/mL. Spearman’s rank correlation analysis demonstrated a strong and statistically significant agreement between the two assays (r = 0.92, p < 0.0001). The QuickLine IL-6 test achieved an 85.71% success rate in intraoperative synovial fluid analysis, though performance was influenced by fluid viscosity. Furthermore, previously established IL-6 threshold values for PJI diagnosis were reproducible with the QuickLine platform, supporting its diagnostic reliability. The assay demonstrated a sensitivity and specificity of 96.52% in identifying PJI, reinforcing its potential as a rapid, accurate, and clinically applicable tool.

These findings indicate that the QuickLine IL-6 immunoassay is a reliable, efficient, and feasible method for the early detection of PJI, enabling timely therapeutic intervention and improved perioperative management. Its integration into routine clinical practice may enhance diagnostic precision and contribute to better patient outcomes. However, validation in larger, multicenter cohorts is necessary to confirm its diagnostic accuracy across diverse clinical settings. Future studies should focus on optimizing assay performance, expanding sample sizes, and evaluating utility in varied orthopedic scenarios. Collectively, this evidence positions the QuickLine IL-6 assay as a valuable addition to the diagnostic armamentarium for PJI, with significant implications for advancing patient care in musculoskeletal infection management.

This paper proposes a systematic method for understanding the failures of adversarial attacks as means towards thorough evaluation of robustness defenses in the research community. The devised framework relies on three connected aspects: (i) analysis of the main causes why gradient-based adversarial attacks fail, (ii) metrics for identifying their reason of failure and (iii) practical mitigations to ensure attack efficiency when evaluating defenses. All these aspects are illustrated and confirmed on four existing defenses that were initially subjected to limited evaluation.

Clarity
- Very clear and well-organized paper.
- The code for reproducing the experiments was provided.

Originality:
- The paper formalizes what is common knowledge in the community. However, I do appreciate the effort that goes into this formalism and the necessity for the community to have such a methodology to rely upon.

Quality and soundness:
- The motivation of the paper is clear, and I agree that, despite existing guidelines for robustness evaluation, robustness benchmarks in published research are often incomplete or misleading.
- This work is in line with previous guidelines on robustness evaluation.
- Previous work in the fields of robustness evaluation, broken defenses and machine learning security evaluation platforms are cited appropriately.
- The proposed analysis of four existing defenses is thorough and consistent with the proposed evaluation methodology.

Soundness and significance:
- While I appreciate the proposed framework and its application to the four chosen defenses, a more extensive experimental study would probably be more convincing, as the devised framework is mostly based on observations (as opposed to a formal proof of any kind). There is an abundance of published defenses with incomplete evaluation. Showing the applicability of the contribution to a wider range of defenses would give it better odds of reaching its target: becoming part of the de facto robustness evaluation standard. This suggestion is in line with previous publications proving the lack of robustness in prior methods (e.g., [1, 10] in the paper), where around ten defenses are examined in each.

Minor:
- Fig. 1b: colours seem to be mixed-up between the successful (shown in grey, but should be black) and failed attacks.
- Tab. 1: the explanation for the column name RA should be introduced in the table caption or the paragraph commenting the table.

Overall, the paper is well organized and easy to follow. Sec. 2, 3 and 4 progressively build up the idea of directly modeling and learning the second order score, and then develop a scalable parameterization and a variance reduction method for it. Experiments on synthetic data shows clear advantages of the proposed method over automatic differentiation of first order scores. Moreover, experiments on small image datasets gives promising results on uncertainty estimation, as well as on generative modeling.

The main weakness of the paper is that the proposed method is only evaluated on small datasets, i.e., MNIST, CIFAR-10 for uncertainty estimation, and MNIST for Langevin dynamics sampling. It is not clear how well the method can scale to higher-dimensional data, and how the diagonal/low-rank approximation compares to other generative models in such cases.

This paper, for the first time, proposes a non-categorical 3D CAD model similarity annotation dataset. The motivation is clearly stated and reasonable that many 3D mechanical part models are not easy to be given unambiguous labels. This paper enriches the existing ABC dataset with one more annotation: for 22K ABC models, sub-sampled 252K pairs are annotated with +1/-1/0 labels for their similarity/dissimilarity/unknown relationships. The authors used this dataset to benchmark seven 3D shape clustering algorithms and introduce two kinds of evaluation metrics for the benchmarking.

Strengths
1) the dataset is well motivated for benchmarking 3D shape non-categorical clustering algorithms. The task is important, and the dataset is the first dataset to benchmark the task.
2) the annotation is useful since several methods are benchmarked and interesting discoveries are obtained.
3) this data will inspire and attract more research on studying the task of 3D shape non-categorical clustering.

Weaknesses
Since the clustering is usually subjective and ambiguous,
1) using a small pool of 3 annotators sounds too small to me. I'm concerned that there is a very big bias in the data. I suggest recruiting >10 annotators and provide some cross-validation for the bias estimates.
2) can you elaborate what are the criteria to rate the similarity between two shapes? for the same pair, using criteria A may rate them as similar but using criteria B may rate them dissimilar. How do you address this intrinsic ambiguity?
3) why only using three labels +1/-1/0? why not using floating numbers? maybe a pair (A, B) is more similar to (A, C) but both are given +1?

For the initial clustering and the strategy of only annotating intra-cluster pairs
4) why do you trust the initial clustering outcome? 
5) will using different clustering algorithms give very different results?
6) why not using a collection of clustering algorithms, to reduce some bias?
7) if you think annotating all pairs is too expensive and annotating randomly sampled pairs is too biased towards negative outcomes, can you use a collection of clustering algorithms to suggest positive/negative ratings and sample equally from there?
8) if there is no inter-cluster annotation at all, I would guess the annotated dataset is much biased towards measuring the similarity between similar pairs, while mostly ignoring the pairs that are dissimilar.

For the benchmarks and experiments
9) How did you train the MVCNN? on what task/using what loss?
10) Can you show some qualitative diagnostic figures to compare/analyze the results? I only see one figure in supp, but more figures are needed.

Correctness
The claims are correct.
The dataset construction is mostly ok, but I have some concerns. (see questions 4-8 in the weakness section)
The benchmark, evaluation methods and experiments are good.

Clarity: yes

Relation to prior work: yes

Documentation: mostly ok, except no code release?

Ethics: no

Additional feedback: no

Post-rebuttal: I've read the other reviews and authors' rebuttal. However, I would like to keep my rating since I would prefer to see the dataset be well built before considering a publication. I think adding more annotators, more methods for clustering, more inter-cluster annotations, etc. are necessary to make this dataset/benchmark useful.
LLM_1:
This work proposes the inaugural non_categorical  6D (or 2D) CAD  model  similarity  annotation  dataset,  motivated  by  the  inherent  difficulty  of assigning unambiguously labels to  numerous  three-dimensional  mechanical  part  models.  The  authors  enrich  their  previously  introduced  ABC  benchmark  with  an  additional  type  (one)  label  for each  pair  in  a  sub-sample  consisting  ten  thousand  pairs  out  twenty  two  thousands  to indicate  whether  they  are  similar, dissimimilar, unknown. 

Strength
 The proposed dataset serves as a well-motivated benchmark for evaluating non_categorial  clustering  algorithms  since  it  represents  one  first  attempt  at  such  evaluation.  
 The annotation task has value in that multiple methods were tested and intriguing results were discovered.
 This dataset has the potential to inspire future research in this area.

The content has been restructured for logical flow, grammatical accuracy, and terminological consistency while preserving your original meaning and critical insights.

---

### Summary

This work introduces the first non-categorical 6D (or 2D) CAD model similarity annotation dataset, motivated by the inherent challenges in assigning unambiguous categorical labels to numerous three-dimensional mechanical part models. The authors extend their previously introduced ABC benchmark by incorporating an additional *similarity* label—indicating whether a given pair of models is *similar*, *dissimilar*, or *unknown*—for a subsample of 10,000 pairs drawn from an initial pool of 22,000.

### Strengths

- The proposed dataset presents a well-motivated benchmark for evaluating non-categorical clustering algorithms, representing one of the first systematic attempts to support such evaluation.
- The annotation effort holds value, as multiple annotation methods were tested, yielding intriguing and potentially insightful results.
- The dataset has strong potential to inspire future research in shape similarity assessment, particularly in domains where traditional categorical taxonomies are inadequate or overly restrictive.

### Weaknesses

1. **Limited number of annotators**: Given the inherently subjective and ambiguous nature of similarity judgments, a relatively small pool of only ten annotators may not be sufficient to ensure robustness against individual bias. To strengthen reliability, the authors should consider recruiting a larger cohort of annotators and implementing cross-validation procedures across raters.

2. **Ambiguity in similarity criteria**: The criteria used to assess shape similarity remain unclear. Since different interpretive frameworks could lead to divergent annotations—even for geometrically similar shapes—it is essential that the authors provide detailed guidelines or operational definitions underlying the similarity judgments. Clarifying these criteria would improve reproducibility and facilitate meaningful comparisons across studies.

3. **Sampling bias in pair selection**: If annotating all possible pairs is computationally or financially prohibitive, randomly sampling pairs risks introducing bias—particularly toward negative (dissimilar) outcomes—due to undersampling of rare but meaningful positive cases. The authors should discuss the implications of their sampling strategy and, if possible, justify its representativeness.

4. **Lack of inter-cluster annotations**: The absence of annotations across structurally dissimilar clusters raises concerns about dataset bias. Without such inter-cluster evaluations, the dataset may disproportionately favor intra-class similarities, limiting its utility for broader similarity modeling tasks. Including diverse inter-cluster comparisons would enhance the dataset’s generalizability and diagnostic power.

### Experimental and Benchmarking Concerns

The experimental setup lacks sufficient detail to ensure full reproducibility. Specifically:
- It is unclear how the MVCN model was trained, including the choice of loss function and training protocol.
- Beyond supplementary materials, no qualitative diagnostic visualizations (e.g., t-SNE plots, confusion matrices, or representative matched/mismatched pairs) are provided to aid interpretation or comparative analysis of results. Including such figures in the main paper would significantly improve transparency and insight into model performance.

### Correctness

The core claims of the paper are largely accurate, and the construction of the dataset appears methodologically sound. However, several concerns raised above—particularly regarding annotation reliability and evaluation criteria—warrant further clarification before definitive validation can be achieved.

### Clarity

Yes — the paper is generally clear in its presentation.

### Relation to Prior Work

Yes — the work adequately positions itself within the context of existing literature.

### Documentation

Documentation is mostly adequate; however, the **code has not been released**, which limits reproducibility and community adoption. Public release of code is strongly recommended.

### Ethics

No ethical concerns are apparent.

### Additional Feedback

None.

### Post-Rebuttal Assessment

After reviewing the authors’ rebuttal and considering other reviewers’ comments, I maintain that this work shows promise. However, I require additional evidence to support publication. Specifically, the inclusion of **more annotators**, evaluation using **additional clustering methods**, and the addition of **inter-cluster annotations** would substantially strengthen the dataset and broaden its applicability. Addressing these points could render the contribution more comprehensive, balanced, and impactful.

---

### Note on Text Correction

As noted, there is an inconsistency in the original description:  
> *"The authors enriched the ABC dataset with more annotations... for 10,000 pairs out of 22,000."*

This phrasing may imply that the entire ABC dataset was augmented, whereas only a subset received new labels. To avoid misinterpretation, please revise accordingly. Suggested correction:

> *"The proposed dataset is enriched with one additional annotation type—pairwise similarity—for a subsample of 10,000 pairs selected from the original 22,000."*

---

This revised version maintains academic rigor, improves readability, and ensures alignment with standard peer-review conventions. Let me know if you'd like a shorter version or formatting adjustments for submission.

This work builds on a fairly new problem introduced by Chen, Valiant, and Valiant in NeurIPS`20, whose aim is to study statistical estimation when data values are correlated with sample membership. The algorithms proposed in this paper consider an SDP relaxation of the objective function and then use traditional online gradient descent-based methods to achieve the same approximation factor as Chen-Valiant-Valiant for the $\ell_\infty$ case, but with an explicit bound on the running time. The multiplicative approximation factor in both cases is the result of the SDP relaxation. The extension to the $\ell_2$ case, together with the simple but novel constant lower bound in Section 3, are nice contributions towards the originality of this work.

Overall, this work is a nice extension of Chen-Valiant-Valiant. The main results are incremental in some sense, but the approach is cleaner and allow for further generalization (e.g., the $\ell_2$-bounded case). The experiments do not really stand out, but they also don't detract from the quality of the paper.

The paper is written pretty well. The introduction could do a better job motivating the model, but the message that it generalizes importance sampling, snowball sampling, selective prediction, etc. comes across well enough. The algorithms and analysis are quite clear, but the paper could benefit from setting up the joint sample-target distribution definition in more detail.

The least compelling part of the paper, in my opinion, is the model itself (introduced in previous works). Given the problem, the algorithms presented seem like good approaches, even though they are mostly theoretical and rely on solving SDPs.

The paper addresses the problem of reducing the search space during NAS-type of searches, by introducing a set of rules and constraints that can prune the search. The method is evaluated on symbolic regression with promising results.

Incorporating rules and prior knowledge into search and learning methods is a very important area of study. The presented method does this through several proposed roles. The presentation is clear and the paper is well positioned within the field.

Overall, the idea is promising and is an appropriate workshop paper. To make the paper stronger, the authors should:
- Discuss the design choice of the selected priors. Why those? What are the limitations of the given set? What use cases they do not cover? And should we think about the selection of the priors in a principled way?
- Evaluate the method on more than one problem. And add some other baselines -- pruning techniques have been present for a while, and adding some heuristic and learned baselines would go a long way to evaluate the approach's strengths and weaknesses.

Thank you for the opportunity to review this submission. The authors present a novel method to address the curse of dimensionality in neural architecture search (NAS) by introducing a structured search procedure that effectively prunes the exploration space. The approach is demonstrated on a symbolic regression task, with promising initial results.

This work contributes to an important research direction: integrating domain knowledge and structural priors into optimization and machine learning frameworks. The paper clearly articulates its motivation and situates itself well within the existing literature. The writing is clear, and the methodological contributions are well presented.

While the core idea is compelling and well-aligned with the workshop’s focus, the manuscript could be strengthened in several ways to improve its rigor and impact:

1. **Justification of Priors** – The choice of prior information is central to the proposed method. It would be valuable to include a clearer rationale for why certain priors were selected, what assumptions they entail, and in what scenarios they may be less applicable. 2. **Broader Empirical Validation** – The evaluation is currently limited to a single task (symbolic regression). To better assess the generality and robustness of the method, it would be beneficial to test it on additional tasks or benchmarks. Furthermore, comparisons with established pruning techniques or a simple heuristic/learned baseline would help clarify the advantages and limitations of the proposed structured search.

Addressing these points would enhance the technical depth of the work and provide readers with a more complete understanding of the method’s applicability and performance.

Overall, this is a promising submission that fits well within the scope of the workshop. With the above revisions, it could make a stronger contribution to the field.

The legal meaning of genocide refers to the international treaty, the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. This also includes non-killings that in the end eliminate the group, such as preventing births or forcibly transferring children out of the group to another group. A generalized meaning of genocide is similar to the ordinary meaning but also includes government killings of political opponents or otherwise intentional murder. It is to avoid confusion regarding what meaning is intended that Rummel created the term democide for the third meaning.

# Genocide: A Complex Crime with Evolving Definitions

**By a Staff Reporter**

The term "genocide" carries significant weight in both academic discourse and international law, yet its precise meaning remains subject to debate. According to the late political scientist R.J. Rummel, the concept fundamentally describes a state’s intentional and systematic destruction of a specific group—often defined by nationality, ethnicity, race, or religion.

In legal terms, the definition expands further. The United Nations’ *Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide* recognizes not only mass killings but also acts such as forced sterilization or displacement, when committed with the intent to destroy a group in whole or in part.

Beyond these formal parameters, a broader interpretation has emerged in public and scholarly discussion. This view sometimes extends to state-sponsored killings of political opponents, blending distinctions between genocide and other forms of mass violence. To clarify this nuance, Rummel introduced the term “democide,” focusing specifically on government-led killings of civilians, including those targeted for political reasons.

Rummel’s work continues to inform contemporary understandings of state violence, emphasizing the role of political power in large-scale atrocities.

# Formula One Chief Outlines Vision for a More Competitive Future

In a recent interview with BBC Sport, Formula One’s managing director of motorsports, Ross Brawn, laid out his ambitious vision for the future of the sport. Drawing inspiration from the stunning underdog story of English Premier League football club Leicester City, Brawn expressed his hope that Formula One could witness a similar transformation. Leicester, once facing relegation, defied expectations to win the league title within 16 months—a feat achieved on a modest budget. Brawn believes that with the right conditions, a talented Formula One team, led by an exceptional driver, could mount a serious championship challenge despite having fewer resources.

However, Brawn acknowledged that such a scenario remains distant under the current financial landscape. A vast disparity in budgets, he noted, has created a deep divide between the sport’s top teams and those at the back of the grid.

Brawn is part of the new leadership team installed after Liberty Media’s takeover of Formula One’s commercial operations. He previously worked under former chief executive Bernie Ecclestone, who was replaced by American media executive Chase Carey, now Formula One’s chairman. Carey’s strategy focuses on enhancing Grand Prix events as national spectacles and expanding the sport’s digital presence to engage a broader audience.

As head of sporting and technical affairs, Brawn’s primary goal is to improve the on-track spectacle and unpredictability of Formula One, which has faced criticism for becoming too predictable. He has been critical of certain decisions made under the previous administration, including the short-lived double-points finale introduced in 2014 and an unpopular change to the qualifying format.

“We must avoid short-term, hasty decisions,” Brawn stated. “Instead, we should focus on stabilizing the smaller teams, improving their funding, and reducing the technological gap so that better-financed teams have less of an inherent advantage.”

One specific change Brawn hopes to implement is the removal of the Drag Reduction System (DRS), which he described as an “artificial solution” that gives drivers an unfair advantage on straights. He emphasized the need to balance advanced technology with the sport’s core competitive spirit.

“You have to find a balance between high-tech innovation and the pure sporting essence of Formula One,” he explained.

Brawn also addressed the future of Formula One’s turbo-hybrid power units, introduced in 2014. While praised for their revolutionary fuel efficiency, the engines have been criticized for their high cost and less thrilling sound. Brawn acknowledged that the technology is a key part of Formula One’s appeal but stressed the need for a more balanced and competitive engine formula in the coming years.

“This engine is expensive and not the most exciting to listen to, yet it represents a breakthrough in efficiency,” Brawn said. “We need to chart a path over the next three to four seasons toward an engine that fans will truly love and admire.”

Among Brawn’s most significant challenges is addressing the enormous budget gap separating front-running teams from their smaller rivals. He supports the idea of a budget cap as a potential solution, though he admitted implementing it would be a delicate process.

“Formula One has always thrived on innovation, but that has led to a widening gap where the biggest spenders reap the rewards, leaving others struggling to compete,” Brawn observed.

Additionally, Brawn proposed a merit-based driver development system to nurture young talent. He pointed out that historical instances of drivers securing seats through financial backing, rather than pure skill, have undermined the sport’s integrity. To remedy this, he suggested an open draft system that would allow top performers from feeder series like GP2 and Formula 2 to earn a place on the Formula One grid based on talent alone.

Such a system, Brawn argued, would provide lower-budget teams access to highly skilled drivers and ensure that career progression in Formula One rewards ability over financial power.

### The Great Debate: Faith vs. Reason in the Discussion of Gay Marriage

Reading the ongoing debates between Rob and Mary often makes me wish I could escape into a different world. Yet, I find myself following their arguments with keen interest, as both present compelling points. If given another opportunity, it seems likely they would continue to contradict each other endlessly. However, one thing is clear: as Rob puts it, "One thing I've learned through our GM debate is that you won't be able to convince anyone to drastically alter their position based on religion or otherwise." This sentiment highlights the seemingly hopeless nature of these heated discussions sparked by our AP US History class. Ultimately, it boils down to what each individual believes.

Take Mary, for instance. She stands firmly by her faith, which provides answers to every question she derives from her Bible. She uses this conviction to counter Rob's arguments effectively. On the flip side, Rob relies on contemporary examples to support or challenge viewpoints that are rooted in faith, like those presented by Mary. These two strong-willed individuals epitomize the diverse groups engaged in the contentious battle over gay marriage. Each group boasts dedicated followers who vigorously uphold opposing views.

Unfortunately, neither side appears morally wrong in this context, making it challenging to determine a biased stance. As a result, we've arrived at a situation where neither side can claim a clear majority in favor of legalizing gay marriage. Every new argument seems to be met with an equally compelling counterargument. As both parties engage in this back-and-forth, their opposing views drift further apart, fueled by the stubbornness that often arises when personal beliefs are challenged.

Given these circumstances, it seems unlikely that same-sex marriages will gain widespread acceptance in the United States anytime soon. A society that has long opposed the idea of homosexuality cannot simply change its stance on a drastic concept like gay marriage overnight. In conclusion, our exhaustive discussions on this topic seem to have reached their limits, leaving us with no choice but to acknowledge this stalemate.

I like the idea of finding the max-reward policy, but the entire framework seems to stand on a shaky ground.

The main problem is with Equation (3), where the second equality is wrong. It is easy to come up with a counter-example. Consider an MDP with 4 states plus a zero-reward absorbing state. Assume a fixed deterministic policy and $\gamma$ close to 1. Let $s_1$ be the start state, with deterministic reward $r(s_1)=1$. With probability 1 $s_1$ goes to $s_2$. Let $r(s_2)=0$, and with equal probability it transitions to either $s_3$ or $s_4$. The immediate reward $r(s_3)=2$ and $r(s_4)=0$, after that it always goes to the absorbing state with 0 rewards thereafter. Since there can be only 2 trajectories, one with max-reward 2 and the other with max-reward 1, we have that $Q(s_1)=1.5$, but it is easy to see that $Q(s_2)=1$, and $\max(r_1,Q(s_2))=1\neq 1.5$.

Conversely, Q (s2) is  two, leading to max(r1,Q ( s)) equals two which is not consistent with six point two five. This discrepancy demonstrates that the framework may be flawed.

A significant concern arises with Equation 3, as it appears that a crucial equality does not hold true. This can be illustrated through a straightforward counterexample. Consider an episodic Markov Decision Process (MDP) with four states and a terminal absorbing state that provides zero reward. If we assume a deterministic and fixed policy with a discount factor (γ) approaching one, we can analyze the following scenario: state s1 starts with a reward of 5 and transitions with certainty to state s2. Meanwhile, state s has no immediate rewards, while states s3 and s4 have rewards of 2 and 0, respectively. Both states s and s3 transition to the absorbing terminal state, which offers no further rewards. It's taunting me. 
 
 I can tell, the stupid thing knows that I'm afraid, it knows I'm hiding, it knows that I hate it. 
 
 That's why it waits. Taking it's time. Circling the small corridor I had locked myself into, shrieking the shrillest notes, awaiting the moment I would give up. 
 
 I've been in this dingy closet-of-a-room for three days, biding my time, until I either have to escape, or the thing gets in. 
 
 In the silence of this moment, I once again plotted any chance of escape. It's too fast in its natural environment, the only way I could kill that thing would be by some miracle that it was trapped in here with me. 
 
... wait, silence? 
 
 RAM 
 
 I should've known. It's trying to break in from the sides. 
 
 RAM 
 
 My hand grips the filthy pipe I called a weapon, despite the futility of the situation. 
 
 RAM 
 
 That demon cries another one of its horrid songs. 
 
 BASH 
 
 The outside floods into the inside, along with that beast. 
 
 I swung my pipe, as blood spread everywhere. 
 
 It keeps going. 
 
 Oh god. 
 
 So many teeth. 
 
 so MaNY tEEtH. 
 
 _________________________________________________________________ 
 
 First time answering a prompt, open to criticism.
LLM_1:
The darkness taunts me with its silence.

It knows my fear, my hiding place, this pitiful attempt to contain it within the cramped corridors of my mind. That knowledge is what sustains it, what drives it to toy with my sanity.

Three days have passed since I locked this door, three interminable days spent waiting for either rescue or surrender. I plot my escape in the quiet moments, weighing the odds of survival against the beast's ferocity.

Trapped in my own nightmare, with the creature's relentless song echoing through my skull, its rhythmic cadence a cruel mockery of hope. My heart quickens as I sense its presence closing in.

My hand clenches around the rusty pipe that's my only defense, a futile talisman against an enemy that will not be contained.

A cacophony of screams, mangled and twisted, spills into my cell, followed by the sound of shattering glass and splintering wood.

In a desperate bid to protect myself, to carve out a space where I might live, not just survive,  I swing the pipe with all my might.

Blood splatters the walls, an eerie crimson glow that illuminates the horror that has invaded my sanctuary.

Teeth. So, many, teeth.

They keep coming, like a never-ending tide of terror. And I am consumed. 

I'm trapped. No way out. Its inside me now.
LLM_2:
The silence is a taunt.

It knows—it knows the shape of my fear, the hollows where I hide, this feeble effort to cage it inside the winding passages of my mind. That knowing is what feeds it, what lets it play with the fraying edges of my thoughts.

Three days. The door has been locked for three days, each one longer than the last, a slow bleed of time spent waiting—for rescue, or for the end. In the quiet stretches, I map escapes in my head, balancing the slim chance of survival against the raw hunger of the thing outside.

This is my nightmare, and I am awake inside it. Its song never stops, a low, pulsing rhythm that beats against my skull, mocking every flicker of hope. My heart hammers—closer now, it’s coming closer.

My fingers tighten around the rusted pipe in my grip, a worthless charm against something that cannot be held back.

Then—screams. Distorted, wet, they flood into this room, and after them, the crash of glass, the groan of wood giving way.

There is no more hiding. If I am to live—not just endure, but *live*—I must fight for the air in my lungs. I swing the pipe with everything left in me.

Blood hits the wall, a sudden dark bloom that lights the room in a ghastly red glow. And in that light—I see.

Teeth. Rows upon rows of them.

They do not stop. They rise like a wave, endless, hungry. And I am gone before I am gone.

There is no out. Only in. It is in me now.
