This work compares four deep learning methods for the detection of lymphocytes in histology data. Lymphocytes detection and segmentation is a very relevant application in the medical imaging because of the possible use in cancer research. The paper is well written and easy to read. 
The authors discuss and evaluate four different types of methods (“classification”, “segmentation”, “detection”, and “localization”), which I believe is very interested for the medical imaging community. Readers of this article will learn about the different ways to tackle an object detection problem and will also be educated on recent methods for each type of method. The authors also show the effect of training on harder data (data with artifacts and clusters of lymphocytes) with the segmentation method (U-Net). There it clearly improves the performance. It’s unclear why the authors didn’t run the same experiment for the other three methods. That would have been better. I’m now wondering if the detection method (YOLO) trained with harder data would have outperformed the U-Net with harder data. 
Another point of improvement is adding more explanation about the differences and similarities between the different methods. The four methods are now explained independently, but for full appreciation of the methods it would have been great if the authors could have focused on how the methods exactly relate to each other. This especially holds for the classification versus the segmentation method and the detection versus the localization method.
LLM_1:
This paper provides a comprehensive comparison of four state-of-the-art deep-learning methods – classification, segmentation, detection,  and localization – for lymphocyte detection in medical histopathology imaging. Given its potential applications in oncological research, this work is highly relevant to medical image analysis. 

The author's thorough discussion and evaluation of these four approaches will be of great interest to researchers in this field. By exploring the distinct ways of addressing object-detection challenges and recent advancements in each category, readers will gain valuable insights into the strengths and limitations of various techniques. Moreover, through the demonstration of U-net's improved performance on more challenging data with artefacts and lymphocytic clusters, it becomes evident that augmenting the training data enhances the model's robustness.

However, one aspect that is unclear is why similar experiments were not conducted for classification and detection methods using harder training datasets. If YOLO, trained on these more complex data, outpaced U-NET, that would provide crucial information on the relative performance of different models under such conditions. Additionally, a more detailed explanation of how these methods relate and differ from one another would significantly enhance the reader's comprehension. Specifically, comparing classification with segmentation and detecting with localization would be beneficial for a thorough understanding of their respective roles. Finally, considering a comparative analysis of each approach would further enrich the discussion, thereby allowing readers to fully appreciate the intricacies and relationships between these deep-learned techniques for medical applications.
LLM_2:
This paper presents a thorough comparison of four advanced deep-learning techniques—classification, segmentation, detection, and localization—for the detection of lymphocytes in medical histopathology imaging. Given its implications for oncological research, this study is highly pertinent to the field of medical image analysis.

The authors provide an in-depth discussion and evaluation of these four methodologies, which will undoubtedly engage researchers working in this domain. By examining the unique strategies employed to tackle object-detection challenges and highlighting recent advancements in each area, the paper offers valuable insights into the strengths and weaknesses of various techniques. Furthermore, the demonstration of U-Net's enhanced performance on more complex datasets containing artifacts and lymphocytic clusters underscores the importance of data augmentation in improving model robustness.

Nevertheless, one point that remains ambiguous is the absence of similar experiments for classification and detection methods when applied to more challenging training datasets. If YOLO, for instance, were to outperform U-Net when trained on these intricate datasets, it would yield critical insights into the relative performance of these models under such circumstances. Additionally, a more detailed clarification of how these methods interrelate and differ would greatly enhance the reader's understanding. Specifically, juxtaposing classification with segmentation and detection with localization would provide clarity regarding their distinct functions. Lastly, incorporating a comparative analysis of each approach would further enrich the discourse, enabling readers to gain a deeper appreciation of the complexities and interconnections among these deep learning techniques in medical applications.

human: Current U.S. Food and Drug Administration-approved therapies for hypogonadism involve testosterone (T) replacement. Testosterone pellets (TP) require a minor office procedure every 3 to 4 months. The need for repeated insertions increases the likelihood of a complication. Anastrozole (AZ) is an aromatase inhibitor that has been used off-label for the treatment of male hypogonadism. AZ increases T levels by lowering serum estradiol (E2) levels and increasing gonadotropin (GTP) levels.We hypothesized that the concomitant use of AZ with TP insertions would sustain therapeutic T levels and increase the interval between TP insertions.Men treated with TP for hypogonadism at an academic center were offered AZ (1 mg/day) at the time of TP reinsertion as a way of potentially decreasing the frequency of TP insertions. Total T (TT), free T (FT), sex hormone binding globulin, E2, luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle-stimulating hormone FSH levels were obtained prior to T replacement and at 6 and 15 weeks from TP insertion. Men were re-implanted at 16 weeks if their TT levels were less than 350 ng/dL and their symptoms recurred. We retrospectively reviewed our records of men who underwent TP, TP, and AZ from 2011 to 2012. Demographics, TT, FT, LH, FSH, and E2 levels were recorded. Data were analyzed with anova and a Tukey's test.TT level at 6, 15, or >15 weeks from TP insertion.Thirty-eight men with 65 insertions were analyzed. The TP AZ group had significantly higher TT and FT levels than the TP group at >120 days (P < 0.05). The TP group had significantly higher E2 levels at all time points (P < 0.01). GTP levels remained stable in the TP AZ group. Average time to reinsertion in TP AZ was 198 days vs. 128 days in the TP group.
LLM_1:
This study aimed to investigate the efficacy of conjoining anastroazole (az) with testosterone pellet (tp) therapy for male patients with hypopgonadis, thereby potentially reducing the necessity for frequent tp insertional procedures. Az, an established aromatis inhibitor, has previously been employed off label for this purpose, wherein it increases testosterone levels through the suppression of serum estadiolo levels, accompanied by an augmentation of gonadothropin levels. 

Based on this rationale, we hypothesised that incorporating az with tp therapy would not only sustain therapeutically relevant testosterone concentrations but also prolong the inter-insertional interval. To this end, male subjects undergoing tp treatment for hyogogandism were invited to receive az (at a dosage of 1 mg per day) concurrently with their tp reimplantation. Blood samples were collected from these patients prior tp testosterone replacement therapy, as well as at six and fifteen weeks post tp insertion, with further assessments conducted at sixteen weeks in cases where testosterone thresholds were not met or symptoms reappeared. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patient records from the period spanning 20ii to twelv, encompassing demographic information, testosterone, free testosterone and sex horomone binding gloobulin levels.

Data were examined employing an anava and tukeys test, yielding the following findings. Thirty-eight individuals with a total of sixty-five tp procedures were evaluated. Notably, individuals receiving az concurrently wth tp exhibited significantly elevated testosterone leveels compared to those receiving tp alone, at timepoints exceeding one-twenty days post insertion (p < 0 05). Conversely, tp recipients exhibited higher estrogen levels across all evaluable timepoint ( p <0. 01 ). Gonadatrophin leveel remianed stable within the az tp group. Finally, average re-insertion time for individuals receving az was calculated to b 19 8 days, compared with one twent eight days for those in receipt of tp only.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study evaluated the efficacy of adjunctive anastrozole (AZ) administration in conjunction with testosterone pellet (TP) therapy for male hypogonadism, with the objective of extending the duration between TP insertion procedures. AZ, an aromatase inhibitor, has been utilized off-label in this context to elevate serum testosterone by inhibiting estradiol conversion while concurrently increasing gonadotropin levels. We hypothesized that co-administration of AZ with TP therapy would sustain therapeutic testosterone concentrations and prolong inter-insertion intervals.

Male patients receiving TP therapy for hypogonadism were administered AZ (1 mg daily) concurrently with TP reimplantation. Blood samples were collected at baseline (pre-therapy), six weeks, and fifteen weeks post-insertion, with additional assessments at sixteen weeks if testosterone thresholds were unmet or symptoms recurred. A retrospective analysis of patient records (2011–2012) included demographic data, testosterone, free testosterone, and sex hormone-binding globulin levels.

Statistical analysis was performed using ANOVA and Tukey’s test. Thirty-eight patients underwent a total of sixty-five TP procedures. Patients receiving AZ with TP demonstrated significantly higher testosterone levels beyond 120 days post-insertion compared to TP-only recipients (p < 0.05). Conversely, TP-only patients exhibited higher estradiol levels at all measured time points (p < 0.01). Gonadotropin levels remained stable in the AZ+TP group. The mean re-insertion interval was 198 days for the AZ+TP group versus 128 days for the TP-only group.

These findings suggest that adjunctive anastrozole therapy may enhance the sustainability of testosterone levels and significantly extend the interval between TP insertions in men with hypogonadism.

human:
Strengths:

This paper is well-written and conducts solid experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness. From Table 1, we can see that the robustness of the student model outperforms the teacher models, and is also comparable to most state-of-the-art adversarial training methods. It also compares with the latest robustness distillation methods, IGAM and RKD, it seems that it sets a new benchmark in this robustness distillation. I am glad to see that the authors evaluate the robustness under AutoAttack and also give the distillation results on ImageNet. 

Suggestions:

From Table 6 and Figure 7 in supplemental materials, it seems that the performance gained in student models mainly comes from the feature distillation. I think it would be better to give the experiments of ACM on different layers. Does the low level or high level features matter?
LLM_1:
Strength:

The paper presents a well-crafted experimental approach that effectively demonstrates its merits. Notably, as seen in Table1, the resilience of student-designed models surpasses their teacher counterparts, with comparable performance to state of-the art adversarially-trained methods; it also establishes a benchmark for robust distillations, outperforming IGAN and RDK. Additionally, evaluating robust under autoattack and providing distilation results for Image Net are welcome improvements.

Suggestions: 

While Table6  and figure  8 in supplementary materials suggest that student gains are largely attributed to feature-based distilations, it might be insightful to explore how this holds true for different layer types. Specifically, does the extraction of low-level or higher-level features contribute to student performance?
LLM_2:
**Strengths:**

The paper presents a well-designed experimental framework that convincingly demonstrates the merits of the proposed approach. Notably, Table 1 shows that student-designed models exhibit greater resilience than their teacher counterparts, achieving performance comparable to state-of-the-art adversarially trained methods. The work also sets a new benchmark for robust distillation, outperforming existing methods such as IGAN and RDK. Additional welcome contributions include evaluation under AutoAttack and the provision of distillation results on ImageNet.

**Suggestions:**

While Table 6 and Figure 8 in the supplementary materials indicate that student gains are largely due to feature-based distillation, it would be insightful to further examine how this holds across different layer types. For instance, does the extraction of low-level features versus higher-level features contribute differently to student performance? A more detailed analysis along these lines could strengthen the understanding of the distillation mechanism.

As I cruise around town, I'm behind the wheel of a sleek Infiniti Q20. I've had the privilege of owning this vehicle since its release in 2000, although it's now pushing 23 years young. 

One feature that still impresses me is its CD player – a relic of bygone days, perhaps, yet a testament to this car's timeless charm. When it comes to standout features, however, my Infinti's age shows, with its outdated infotainment system a prime example. But what really gets my goat is a quirky issue that's been plaguing me for years. In my haste, one fateful day,  I accidentally left the passenger door ajar while reversing out of my driveway. Unfortunately, it clipped a nearby wall, causing significant damage. Now, every single time I open the creaky door, its rusty hinges let out a blood-curdling squeal, reminding me of that ill-fated incident.  

If I had unlimited resources, you'd find me driving something truly aspirational – the Toyota Highlander, Volvo XC90, Cadillac Escalade, to name a few. Alternatively, if I wanted to splurge on something a bit more exotic, an Aston Martin DB7 GT, Porsche 997 Targa or Lamborghini Huracan would be the perfect indulgence. Cruising through the city in my Infiniti Q20 feels like taking a drive through time. I’ve owned this car since it first hit the roads back in 2000—making it a classic in its own right at 23 years old.  

Some features, like the built-in CD player, are charming relics of an earlier era, reminders of how well this car has held onto its character. Others, though, show their age more plainly—like the infotainment system, which feels like a time capsule from the early 2000s.  

But the real conversation starter? The passenger door.  
A few years back, in a moment of distracted haste, I backed out of the driveway with it slightly open. It met my brick wall with a cringe-worthy scrape, and ever since, opening that door unleashes a chorus of groans and squeaks from its weary hinges. It’s like the car won’t let me forget that clumsy moment—a daily, noisy reminder of my less-than-graceful exit.  

If money were truly no object, my garage would tell a different story. Practical luxury? A Toyota Highlander or Volvo XC90. Statement piece? A Cadillac Escalade. But if I really let myself dream—like, lottery-win dream—I’d be leaning toward something with a little more drama. An Aston Martin DB7 GT for classic elegance, a Porsche 997 Targa for open-air thrills, or maybe even a Lamborghini Huracan, because who wouldn’t want to wake up to that raging bull emblem in their driveway?  

In the end, whether it’s my trusty Infiniti with its squeaky door or a fantasy supercar, it’s the stories—and the dreams—that make the ride worthwhile.

### The Weight of Words: A Call for Connection

Today, I find myself horrified by the realization that writing has become an obsession—almost an addiction. However, with my priorities shifting, I’ll keep this brief, as I have a pressing engagement with someone important. I feel I have no choice but to confront him; otherwise, I’m left uncertain about what might happen next.

There’s something crucial I need to share with him, something he desperately requires. He must have been going through a difficult time, suffering in silence. Perhaps he believes I’ve been lying to him all along, playing games with his emotions, or avoiding him to keep the truth hidden. But what if I’m mistaken? What if he’s perfectly okay? Yet, it appears otherwise—he seems genuinely affected by what I said.

In hindsight, my careless words take on a different tone when I see them in writing compared to how they might have sounded spoken aloud. If I had told him those things face-to-face, witnessing his emotions in real-time, I would surely have regretted my words almost immediately. Unfortunately, such nuances are lost in digital communication, like on ICQ—a chat program that simply doesn’t convey the depth I need.

Thus, my conclusion is clear: we urgently need a face-to-face meeting. I want to express myself through my tone, make eye contact, observe his reactions, and hold his hands. Typing it out would only erode his trust. Over the past few days, I’ve uncovered two key revelations that shocked me and contributed to my strange behavior on Saturday. These realizations unearthed ugly truths about myself and my actions, triggering an emotional explosion filled with sorrow, regret, shame, self-loathing, and vulnerability, followed by a numbing silence.

Now, I know what must be done: I need to meet him in person and share everything I’ve discovered. We require this direct interaction; without it, I’m convinced things will only deteriorate. Recently, I learned some significant truths about his character that deepen my concern. All I can hope for is that nothing terrible has happened to him today—anything like that would be just too cruel.

---

SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon and Patrick Harvie of the Scottish Greens argued it would be undemocratic to rule out a referendum if enough people wanted one.
But the leaders of the other three parties called on them to respect the result of the last referendum.
The BBC Scotland debate was held at Hopetoun House, near Edinburgh.
It featured Ms Sturgeon and Mr Harvie alongside Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale, Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson and Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie.
The hour-long discussion was held just days before Thursday's Scottish Parliament election.
There were angry exchanges over delays to the UK government contracts to build Royal Navy frigates at the Clyde shipyards, which unions have claimed could cost hundreds of jobs.
But it was the issue of independence - and more specifically whether or not there should be a second referendum in the future - that sparked the fiercest responses.
Ms Sturgeon stuck to her position that there should be another referendum if it was clear a majority of people wanted one, or if there was a "material change" in circumstances, such as Scotland being taken out of the EU against its will.
The SNP leader said she continued to believe that independence offered the best future for the country.
She added: "But if those of us in Scotland who support independence cannot persuade people that we didn't persuade in 2014, if independence doesn't become the preferred option of a majority, we will not have earned the right to ask that question again.
"But on the other hand, if people do change their minds and there is clear and sustained evidence that independence has become the preference of a majority of people in Scotland, then no politician has the right to stand in the way of the democratic wishes of the Scottish people."
Speaking later, on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, she clarified that opinion polls held over a period of time would be the deciding factor in calling a second referendum.
She reiterated that there would need to be "clear and sustained evidence".
"We would have to see, in a range of polls over a period of time, that independence had become the preferred option of the majority," she said.
Ahead of the debate, Ms Sturgeon told the Sunday Herald newspaper that she was confident that a second referendum would be held while she is first minister.
Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale pointed out that Ms Sturgeon had previously described the first referendum as being "once in a lifetime" and "once in a generation", and accused her of "trying to pull the wool over people's eyes" on the issue.
Ms Dugdale said the SNP manifesto for the election mentioned independence on page 24, and claimed the SNP "took 210 words to say 'mibbes if, mibbes aye, mibbes no, I'm not sure, trust me or ask the pollsters'."
She added: "So many people in Scotland just want to move on from that referendum of the past. We have substantial new tax and welfare powers coming to the Scottish Parliament.
"Wouldn't it be great if we just used them to talk about the future and how we will improve our schools, our NHS, create opportunities for young people and build the Scotland that we all want to see".
With just days to go until the Holyrood election on Thursday, the party leaders put on a feisty performance in a last-ditch bid to win over voters.
The noisiest exchanges came between Nicola Sturgeon, Kezia Dugdale and Ruth Davidson, who cut across each other to fling barbs about shipyards, independence and healthcare.
Patrick Harvie and Willie Rennie at times found themselves on the periphery of the debate as well as the stage, with the female leaders relatively happy to leave them to speak, concentrating their fire on each other.
And while the women scored plenty of points of their own on each other, this approach allowed both men space for a shot at goal - with Mr Rennie scoring perhaps the biggest cheer of the night by calling for people to move on from the independence debate.
Yes or No, he argued, we should be looking to unite and govern Scotland properly for the next five years.
While there was the usual warm reception for constitutional arguments, the debate audience seemed equally fired up about public policy and social issues and seemed to head home thoroughly pleased by their evening.
There will be little respite for the five party leaders though - they face three more days of frantic campaigning until Scotland goes to the polls.
Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson said Ms Sturgeon had responsibilities to "all of Scotland, not just to the SNP" in her role as first minister.
Ms Davidson said: "Her responsibilities mean that she shouldn't be keeping this wound open - it is not good for our country, it is not good for our economy, it is not good for  encouraging jobs and growth and all of the things that we want to see.
"Before the referendum she went round every TV studio she could find and looked down the camera lens and told every person in Scotland that it was once in a generation, once in a lifetime.
"She has gone back on both of these promises - it is not good enough and it is not up to her to see one opinion poll she likes and say we're putting this country through it once more".
Her views were echoed by Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie, who said the next five years should be used to focus on areas such as education, mental health and climate change targets.
Mr Rennie claimed that these area had all been neglected by the SNP government in the previous five years as it focused on trying to secure independence.
And he suggested the SNP was being "anti-democratic" by continuing to argue for independence.
Mr Rennie added: "I want to focus on making Scotland one of the best countries in the world again. We will not achieve that by having a groundhog day debate about independence. If we keep on disrespecting the result, we will not achieve that better Scotland."
Patrick Harvie of the Scottish Greens said it was important to respect the result of the last referendum, but that it was also important to respect the fact that many people in Scotland voted in favour if independence.
He said it was not reasonable to expect independence supporters to simply "crawl away and shut up about it", and said the "great mass of people" in Scotland were capable of having a mature debate on the issue.
During the debate, which was chaired by the BBC's Sarah Smith and broadcast live on BBC One Scotland and the BBC news website, questions were put to the politicians by an audience of voters on topics including health, jobs and the Edinburgh schools fiasco.
The leaders also clashed about the future of the NHS and the shipyards on Glasgow's River Clyde, after union leaders there raised fears that a contract for the yards to build new Type 26 frigates for the Navy has been delayed.
Ms Davidson said UK government ministers had "categorically assured" her that the work would go ahead.
But Ms Sturgeon hit out: "The shipyards expected to start cutting steel now. They now believe they will not start cutting steel until December 2017. There has been a delay of a year-and-a-half and it is an absolute betrayal."
And Ms Dugdale accused her Conservative rival of "having told a porkie" when she said there was no change to the Ministry of Defence order.
Ms Davidson also faced questions over her party's plans for the NHS, after the Scottish Conservatives said they would reintroduce prescription charges north of the border, claiming this would bring in Â£65m for the NHS each year.
The Tory leader said her party was "looking at increasing GP services" claiming the proportion of the NHS budget spent on primary care has been cut by the SNP.
But Mr Harvie challenged her, saying: "If we went down Ruth's line what would be next, charges to visit your GP?"
It was the third and final televised leaders' debate before the election, with BBC Scotland and STV having held one each earlier in the campaign.

**

In a televised debate ahead of Scotland’s parliamentary elections, leaders clashed over the prospect of a second independence referendum, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon defending her party’s stance while opponents urged a focus on domestic governance.

The BBC Scotland debate, held at Hopetoun House near Edinburgh, featured First Minister and Scottish National Party (SNP) leader Nicola Sturgeon, Scottish Green Party co-convener Patrick Harvie, Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale, Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson, and Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie.

The hour-long discussion saw heated exchanges on issues ranging from delays in UK government contracts to build Royal Navy frigates at Clyde shipyards—a situation unions warned could cost hundreds of jobs—to the ongoing question of Scottish independence.

Ms. Sturgeon reaffirmed her position that a second referendum should be held if there is “clear and sustained evidence” that independence has become the preferred option of a majority of Scots, or if there is a “material change” in circumstances, such as Scotland being taken out of the EU against its will.  

“I believe independence is the best future for Scotland,” she said, but added: “Those of us who support independence can’t simply persuade people who weren’t persuaded two years ago. If independence does not become the preferred option of the majority, we don’t have the right to ask the question again.”

She later clarified on BBC Radio 4’s *Today* programme that opinion polls over a period of time would determine any call for a second vote.

In response, Scottish Labour leader Kezia Dugdale pointed out that the SNP had previously described the 2014 referendum as a “once in a generation” event. She accused the SNP of obscuring its stance on independence in its manifesto and argued that many Scots want to move on and focus on newly devolved powers over tax, welfare, and education.

“Wouldn’t it be great if we talked about the future—about improving our schools, our NHS, and creating opportunities for young people?” Ms. Dugdale said.

The debate grew particularly animated when the topic turned to independence, though at times Mr. Harvie and Mr. Rennie found themselves on the periphery as the female leaders dominated much of the exchange. Mr. Rennie earned the biggest cheer of the night by calling for an end to the “yes/no” divide and urging a united effort to govern Scotland effectively over the next five years.

Audience members appeared engaged on issues of public policy and social affairs, leaving as the evening concluded with the sense that campaigning would only intensify ahead of Thursday’s vote.

*Little Nancy has a secret. * 
 
 Scene: A small girl with brown curly hair wearing a flower dress clutching a small boy's hand tightly wanders around the side of an old house. 
 
 Glen: `` Are you sure it's safe?'' 
 Nancy: `` Of course it's safe, he's my best friend.'' 
 
 *Something the world has never seen before. * 
 
 Scene: A school teacher tilts her head curiously as Nancy is humming a strangely familiar tune. 
 
 Teacher: `` Where'd you hear that song?'' 
 Nancy: `` He taught it to me. It's my favorite one!'' 
 
 *An adventure unlike any before. * 
 
 Scene: The little girl is diving under bed covers while dragging the hand of her friend, leaing into a brightly light tunnel that goes down inside of it. 
 
 `` This way, Glen!'' 
 `` Wow, this tunnel goes all the way down..! I wonder where it ends?'' 
 
 *Are you prepared for the greatest dream ever? * 
 
 Scene: A tall man with a friendly smile kneels down in front of the little girl, holding a small red rose between the metal fingers of his left hand. Behind him can be seen several small islands floating in mid-air, one with a waterfall. On his other side can be seen a giant moutain with a rounded grate embedded in the side, spewing fire from the top. 
 
 Scene Changes: The tall man is laughing as the little girl sits in front of him on the back of a giant worm-like creature sailing through the air between two other worm-like creatures flying together in a strange formation 
 
 Scene changes: The little girl is on a hospital bed while clutching her teddy bear, crying as her mother rubs her back carefully, looking on with concern and fear. 
 
 Nancy: `` Never sleep again..? But I want to, mommy!'' 
 
 *A Dream on Elm Street* 
 
 Scene: Man with the metal hand takes his hat off, bows before the little girl. `` My name is Frederich the Fancy, but my friends call me Freddy.'' 
 
 *Coming soon to an Elm street near you*
LLM_1:
In a world where secrets whispered in hushed tones held the power to unlock hidden wonders, Little Nancy harbored a mystery all her own.

Scene: On the weathered facade of their family's old home, a tiny girl clad in an apricot-hued dress, her curly locks bouncing with each step, grasped the small hand that was her best companion, as they wandered around to its side.

Glen's voice trembled, "Are we certain this is safe?" he asked, his eyes darting about with trepidation.

Nancy's grip on his hand tightened, an unwavering confidence etched on her face, she replied, 'Of course, it'll be perfectly safe; he'll always be by my side.'

Something that defied the understanding of this world had begun to take shape.

A schoolteacher watched with curiosity as Little one's humming harmonized with an otherworldly melody, eerily familiar, yet impossible to place.

Teacher's brow furrowed in inquiry, ''Where did you learn that enchanting tune, child?''

A beaming smile adorned Nancy's face as she shared, '"He taught me; it remains my cherished melody!"'

As if the boundaries of reality had been breached, their adventure had only just begun.

In the midst of night, with Glen's small form by her side as a shield against the darkness, Nancy slipped under the bedcovers and leapt into an ethereal, brightly lit tunnel, its descent into the unknown beckoning them.

"This way!" she urged her companion.

Their gasps of wonder filled the night air as, together, they plunged into this mysterious passageway, which seemed to stretch infinitely downward.

"Wow, look at this, Freddy! This tunnel stretches so far, I can only wonder what secrets lie at its end!" Glen exclaimed, excitement coursing through his voice.

As they embarked on this dreamlike journey, nothing could have prepared them for what awaited them – the most wondrous dream the universe had ever known.

Before them, on an open plain, stood a benevolent giant, adorned with laughter, who knelt down beside the tiny duo. His left metal-fingered hand cradled a delicate red flower, imbuing the scene with whimsy. 

Behind this gentle figure, islands suspended in air, each unique, took shape. One island showcased a majestic waterfall cascading over its tranquil surface, creating an enchantment so divine it beckoned all who beheld it.

On the other hand, another island bore the imposing visage of giant mountain, where a round grate was embedded, releasing a fiery plume into its uppermost reaches.

With an air of mirth, Frederic the fancy, now recognizable as Freddy, removed his cap, bowing before Little girl in respect. "I'm Frederik the fanciful, though my closest friends have always called me the one who has been called Freddy."
LLM_2:
In a world where silence hummed with secrets—where whispers curled like smoke from forgotten hearths and carried the weight of unseen magic—there lived a child who held within her something older than time, softer than starlight.

Scene: The sun slanted low over the weathered bones of an old house, its wooden face cracked with years, painted in gold by the fading day. A little girl danced across the side yard in a dress the color of ripe apricots, her curls springing free with every skip. She clutched a small hand—not quite solid, not quite real—but hers all the same.

Glen’s voice trembled, thin as a thread about to snap. "Are we *sure* this is safe?" His eyes flickered toward shadows that hadn’t been there a moment before, scanning for danger only he could sense.

Nancy didn’t slow. Her fingers closed tighter around his, warm and sure. “Of course it’s safe,” she said, her voice bright as a bell. “He’s always with me. Always watching.”

And then—the air changed.

Not much at first. Just a shift, like breath caught mid-sigh. But something stirred beneath the surface of things, something that bent the rules of what was possible. It began quietly: in the way the wind paused when she sang, in how the birds fell silent just to listen.

At school, the teacher paused during roll call, pencil hovering above the page. Little Nancy swayed at her desk, humming—a tune spun from dreams, perhaps, or memories no child should possess. The melody shimmered, half-formed, echoing notes that belonged to no known song, yet felt achingly familiar, like a lullaby from another life.

The teacher leaned forward, brow creased. “Where on earth did you learn that, sweetheart?”

Nancy turned, radiant, her smile wide enough to hold the sky. “He taught me,” she whispered. “It’s my favorite song. My secret one.”

As if in answer, the light dimmed—and deepened.

That night, under a quilt stitched with moons and stars, Nancy tucked Glen close—her guardian against the dark, though truth be told, she feared nothing. With a giggle, she slid beneath the covers and *leapt*—not into sleep, but into motion, into flight—plunging through a tunnel woven from light and longing, its walls pulsing with colors unseen on any earthly spectrum.

“This way!” she called back, her voice ringing like chimes.

They tumbled together down the endless spiral, gasping, laughing, hearts alight with wonder. The air smelled of ozone and wildflowers; the ground—if there was ground—felt like breathing.

“Look at this, Freddy!” Glen cried, breathless. “It goes on forever! What do you think waits at the end? Treasure? Dragons? A city made of glass?”

But no dream could have readied them for what came next.

They emerged onto a vast plain beneath a lavender sky, where gravity forgot its rules and clouds floated like islands adrift in time. Before them stood a figure—towering, gentle, impossibly kind. A giant, yes, but carved not from stone or fury, but from stories whispered at bedtime.

He knelt, the earth sighing beneath him, and in his left hand—fingers wrought of polished silver and soft gears—he cradled a single red flower, so delicate it seemed made of light. Laughter spilled from him like music, warm and rich, filling the hollows of the world.

Behind him, the floating isles unfolded their wonders: one crowned with a waterfall that poured not into water, but into *song*, each droplet chiming as it fell. Another bore a mountain of obsidian, crowned with a great round grate that belched flame into the heavens, roaring like a sleeping beast turning in its sleep.

And then—from behind the giant’s shadow—stepped a figure slender and sprightly, tipping his hat with theatrical flair. Feathers curled from its brim, catching the strange light.

“I am Frederik the Fanciful,” he announced, bowing low, “though those who’ve danced with dandelion spirits and ridden moonbeams know me better…”

He winked.

“…as Freddy.”

And with that, the adventure truly began—not in steps, but in leaps—into a dream so vast, so vivid, so wildly alive that even the stars leaned in to watch.

The paper contains comprehensive results about various cases of active ranking. While the results look good and are quite complete, I feel that they can still be improved in several ways:

i) What are the implications of the results? More discussion will be helpful to understand the results. Generally, it seems like m-way comparison can help by a $O(\log m)$, $O(m)$ or $O(m \log m)$ factor. Why can it be different?

ii) What techniques are involved? Previous methods also use QuickSelect or QuickSort to solve ranking but under different assumptions. Are the algorithms presented related to previous algorithms?

In general, I think the results are good but more discussion can make the paper better.

(i) The implications and significance of these outcomes warrant further discussion to facilitate a deeper understanding. Notably, m-method comparisons appear to offer a time complexity enhancement by factors of $ O(\ log \ m ) $,  $  O( m) $ or  $\ O(m\ \ log\  m\ ) $. The discrepancy between these factors necessitates clarification.

(ii) Techniques employed in this study differ from previous methods, which also relied on Quick Select or Quicksort for ranking under distinct assumptions, leading to differences in algorithms. A detailed examination of relationships between the presented algorithms and their predecessors is essential.

In conclusion, while the reported results demonstrate merit, supplementary discussion would elevate the overall quality of this paper. Further elucidation is required to solidify the findings and enhance overall coherence.

Of particular note, the comparison among *m*-methods suggests improvements in time complexity by factors of $ O(\log m) $, $ O(m) $, or $ O(m \log m) $. However, the observed discrepancies among these asymptotic bounds require careful clarification, as they bear directly on the efficiency claims of the proposed approaches.

These distinctions in underlying assumptions have led to non-trivial algorithmic variations. A more systematic analysis of the relationships between the proposed algorithms and their predecessors would strengthen the theoretical grounding of the work and better position the current contributions within the existing literature.

In conclusion, while the reported findings possess merit, the manuscript would benefit from additional discussion to enhance its scholarly rigor. Specifically, expanded exposition is needed to consolidate the interpretation of results, clarify algorithmic advantages, and improve the overall coherence and depth of the narrative.

**Pride, Insecurity, and the Quiet Longing for Unconditional Love**

Pride is a curious thing—deceptively simple on the surface, yet layered with contradictions beneath. For me, it has always carried an undercurrent of insecurity, a silent companion that whispers doubt just when I need courage the most.

Recently, I watched *Out of Africa* with my friend Tina, and something about the film stirred emotions I hadn’t expected. There’s a moment—quiet, almost fleeting—when Karen Blixen invites Denis to dance. It’s not grand or dramatic, but it lingers: a bittersweet gesture, beautiful because it knows love won’t last. That scene stayed with me. So did the image of lions resting on Denys Finch-Hatton’s grave—a haunting symbol of time passing, of love outliving those who lived it.

One theme from the film struck me especially hard: **unconditional, unattached love.** The idea that love doesn’t demand, doesn’t cling, doesn’t bargain. That it simply *is*. As we talked afterward, Tina and I found ourselves moved in the same way—not by spectacle, but by stillness, by what goes unsaid.

And then she left.

I wanted to call her. Not to fix anything, not even to talk about the movie—but just to hear her voice, to ease the quiet ache that settled in after she was gone. But I didn’t. Pride got in the way. Or fear. Maybe both.

It’s strange how the walls we build to protect ourselves often end up isolating us instead. I imagined reaching out—just a text, a ring, a “Hey, I’m thinking of you”—and immediately braced against the possibility of being seen as too eager, too vulnerable, too much. So I stayed silent. And regret crept in.

Because honesty—real, raw honesty—isn’t weakness. It’s care. It’s saying, *You matter to me*, without needing to prove it or package it. Yet tonight, I chose dishonesty. I chose distance. Not out of indifference, but out of fear—fear of rejection, fear of appearing needy, fear of opening myself only to be met with silence.

What I truly want is to love freely. To offer connection without conditions, without games. To extend kindness not because I expect something back, but because it feels right. But pride clouds that intention. It turns longing into hesitation, care into calculation.

Tomorrow, when the weight of tonight has lifted, I hope clarity returns. When sleep clears the fog and my heart isn’t racing ahead of my mind, maybe then I’ll find the words—the honest ones, the simple ones. The kind that don’t hide behind irony or delay.

For now, I surrender to the night. Sleep will be my refuge. No more overthinking. No more second-guessing. Just rest.

Because tomorrow brings a new chance—to speak plainly, to reach out, to choose courage over comfort. Maybe I’ll pick up the phone. Maybe I already should have. Or maybe waiting was the right thing. Who knows?

All I know is this: hope isn’t foolish. It’s necessary. And tomorrow—fragile, uncertain, full of possibility—is all I need to keep going.

Here’s to tomorrow. May it bring change.  
Change for the better.

Let me sleep. Let me dream.  
And when morning comes, let me try again.

Wish me luck.

Sweat began to form on Adam's brow. Unconsciously he cleared his throat and pulled at his collar. Behind the counter the cashier's eyes flicked between the small card and Adam's face. Between them sat two large handles of Southern Comfort. The cashier pushed his glasses up his nose and brought the ID closer, scrutinizing every last detail. The only sound in the liquor store was the dull hum of fluorescent lights. 
 
 `` So the weather... right?'' Adam said trying to break the silence. He tried to produce a smile; however, his eighteen year old face betrayed him and instead of a smile came a guilt-ridden scowl. The cashier huffed in response. He flipped the card over checking every last detail. 
 
 `` Must be quite a change for you.'' The cashier huffed. 
 
 `` Huh?'' The confused sound escaped his throat faster than he could stop it. 
 
 `` Cause you're from Florida.'' The cashier replied holding out the card. Adam saw his own awkward picture plastered on a Florida driver's license. In red the date of birth log stated he was twenty-two years old. `` This is you is n't it?'' 
 
 `` Oh, haha. Yea.'' Adam stammered back, hiding his hands in his pocket. `` Well I've seen snow before.'' 
 
 `` In Florida?'' A suspicious eyebrow fired up above the cashiers left eye. 
 
 `` Uh, haha, no. I've been north before. I've seen snow in the north. Up north here... Where it snows... Snows...'' He tried to smile again, but his mouth instead offered an awkwardly curved grimace. 
 
 `` Something wrong with your face boy?'' The cashier replied. It was now that Adam realized that the man was twice his size in height and mass. The image of him being snapped in half fluttered across his mind. The cashier only rolled his eyes and handed back the ID. `` That'll be $ 34.23.'' 
 
 Adams hand was shaking violently. It took several attempts before he could fetch the wallet in his pocket and several more before he could fish the cash out. With a huff the cashier snatched the twin twenties from his trembling hand. 
 
 Just then the doors flew open and an artificial bell rang throughout the store. 
 
 `` Frank!'' A voice exclaimed. Adam turned to look and was met with a fat man standing at the door. He wore a thick coat that amplified his size. The man was smiling madly at Adam and in return Adam looked to the man dumbstruck. 
 
 `` Frank!'' The man said again walking into the store. Gray snow fell in clumps from his boots. Adam confusion quickly curdled to horror as he realized the man was talking to him. In a few fat steps the man was in front of Adam, grasping his shoulders like an old long lost friend. 
 
 `` What are you doing here Frank?'' The man asked, his excitement fading away. He looked to the bottles next to the register then to Adam. 
 
 `` Uhh.'' Adam replied not-so-smartly. 
 
 The man's face went the shade of brake lights. Instantly he turned to the cashier and cried, `` You can not sell this boy alcohol!'' 
 
 Up until this point the cashier had eyed the interaction with an apathetic eye. The cash for purchase was still in his hand. Upon hearing that he quickly leaned in and asked, `` Why?'' 
 
 Adam was screwed, he knew. This stranger had recognized him and now his cover was blown. In his mind he imagined the bleak gray walls of a prison cell, the look of disappointment and shame on his mother's face. He saw the rejection letters from a dozen universities. Adam bowed his head, ready for the axe. Why had he been so stupid to buy alcohol? Why had he spent so much for such a terrible fake? 
 
 The fat man, now clearly enraged replied, `` This man is part of my Alcoholics Anonymous program!'' 
 
 Adam looked up shocked. The cashier tilted his head in confusion. 
 
 `` A little young for AA do n't you think?'' The massive salesman said. 
 
 `` Addiction knows no age limit.'' The fat man replied. He turned to Adam, `` Frank do n't you recognize me? Frank? Come on its Tony. You made a promise Frank. How could you let me down like this, let us all down?'' He threw his arms out in great flourish, `` One year sober and I find you like this! What about your child Frank! How are you going to send money back to Tallahassee if you're wasting it on whiskey? How are you going to support that tiny, crack-addicted boy you left at home?'' 
 
 `` Uhhh.'' Adam replied again. 
 
 The cashier slapped the cash back on the table and pulled the two bottles behind the counter. `` Addiction is a serious thing, kid.'' He looked to Tony and addressed him, `` Look at his hands they're shaking from withdrawal.'' 
 
 `` My god, you're right!'' Tiny exclaimed. 
 
 `` Uhh.'' Adam said. 
 
 `` You're coming with me, we're getting you sober Frank.'' Tony retorted. 
 
 `` Uhh.'' 
 
 `` Nope, I will not hear one of your excuses. Do n't you think I've heard them all?'' 
 
 `` Uhhhh.'' 
 
 `` It's ok... You're speechless I know.'' Tony said. `` I would be too, caught in such a compromising position.'' He grabbed Adam's hand firmly and yanked him towards the door. `` Come on, come on, let's go get you sober.'' 
 
 Still speechless Adam obeyed. In a shocked stupor Tony dragged him out the door. The cashier shook his head disapprovingly as they went. The last thing Adam saw before the doors closed behind him, was the small plastic fake ID, still sitting on the counter. 
 
 A little while later the cashier slid the ID of Frank Fitzburg into a black binder. He closed the thick binder and grinned to himself. On the cover were the words, *Idiot Card Collection*. 
 
 The artificial bell rang and the cashier looked to the door. `` Give'em a good scare Tony?'' The cashier asked. Tony smiled and knocked the snow off his boots in the threshold. 
 
 `` Put the fear of god in him.'' He laughed back. Then added, `` Kid wo n't be trying to buy alcohol again at least for a couple of years.''

This paper proposes to use Copula function to model the correlational role in the node-level prediction tasks. From my own perspective, I quite enjoy this work. In particular, it uses a simple simulation example to uncover the importance of correlational role, i.e., most of the GNNs approaches might perform worse than simple MLPs as they are incapable of using the correlation graph information. This observation is simple, however, would provide deep insights into the current GNNs literature.

[Introduction & Related Work]
The authors clearly state their motivation and precisely introduce the mentioned works. Readers would get a clear understanding on the background information. 

[Simulation the two roles]
The authors use simple simulation examples to show the importance of correlation graph information. 

[Copula Graph Neural Networks]
The authors introduce the detail architecture design for the model. Although the design looks reasonable, I have several questions as follows:

1, the authors mainly used the Gaussian Copula as the correlation modeling choice and incorporate the graph structure in the precision matrix. I can totally understand that this setting can reduce the number of parameters. What if the precision matrix is without the graph structure and is simply placed with sparse priors?  

2, following the above question, it looks like Gaussian Copula is the only suitable choice for Copula functions. How can one use other copula functions, as we cannot incorporate the graph structure and the other copula functions needs complex structures (e.g. C-vines or D-vines) to model the high dimensional data?

3, the two-parameter and regression parameterisation seems quite complicate in fitting the precision matrix. Thus, can these parameterisation method also be used for other copula functions?

[Experiments]
The experimental part can be sufficient to verify the effectiveness of the authors' proposed model.

Similarly, in [Simulation of two Roles], the use of straightforward simulations serves to demonstrate the value of incorporating correlation information.

Regarding [Copula-based Graph Networks], I appreciate the detailed description of model architecture. However, several queries arose during my review:

human: Induction treatments with anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG) in solid organ transplantation may enhance the efficacy of maintenance immunosuppressive therapy. Since ATG can trigger Fas (CD95) mediated T cell apoptosis, a process antagonized in vitro by corticosteroids, an important issue is whether corticosteroids could interfere with T cell depleting and immunosuppressive activities of ATG.MHC mismatched skin allografts were performed on cynomolgus and rhesus monkeys treated with ATG (20 mg/kg) associated or not with 6-methylprednisolone (10 mg/kg).There was no difference between the two immunosuppressive regimens as regards the intensity and duration of peripheral T lymphocyte depletion and the appearance of anti-ATG antibodies. Skin graft survival was increased in monkeys treated with 6-methylprednisolone as compared with ATG alone.
LLM_1: The efficacy-enhancing potential of induction treatments incorporating anti-Thymoglobulin in the context of solid-organ transplantation has garnered significant attention. Notably, anti-T cell therapies mediated by anti Thymocytes globulins (anti- T cells) induce programmed cell death via the FAS (cluster of differentiation 95, CD95)-dependent pathway, which is counteracted by the cortico-steroid family in in-vitro settings. Consequently, it becomes essential to investigate whether the T-cell depletive and immuno-suppressive effects of these anti T therapies are compromised by co-administration of corticro- steroids. In a comparative study, cyno-molgous and rhe-sus macaques were subjected to MHC-incompatible skin grafts in response to anti thymo globuin ( 20mg/kg ) treatment, with or without the adjunctive use of  10mg/ kg  of six methyl predni-sol- one. No discernible disparity was observed in terms of T-lymphocyte count reduction and anti AT glob-ulin antibody emergence between these two immu-no-sup-pressive regimes. Conversely, skin trans-plant survival in mac- aques receiving  six me-thyl pred- ni-sone demonstrated a marked increase over those treated solely with the anti t cell therapy agent.
LLM_2:
**Rewritten Academic Abstract:**

The potential of anti-thymocyte globulin (ATG)-based induction therapies to enhance outcomes in solid-organ transplantation has been widely recognized. ATG mediates T-cell depletion predominantly through the FAS (CD95)-dependent apoptotic pathway, a mechanism that may be inhibited by corticosteroids in vitro. This raises a critical question regarding the functional compatibility of concomitant corticosteroid administration with ATG-induced immunosuppression, particularly in terms of T-cell depletion efficacy and the development of anti-ATG antibodies. To evaluate this interaction, a comparative study was conducted in cynomolgus and rhesus macaques receiving MHC-mismatched skin allografts, treated with ATG (20 mg/kg) alone or in combination with methylprednisolone (10 mg/kg). While both regimens resulted in comparable reductions in T-lymphocyte counts and similar rates of anti-ATG antibody formation, indicating no interference with ATG-mediated lymphodepletion, the group receiving adjunctive methylprednisolone exhibited significantly prolonged skin graft survival. These findings suggest that although corticosteroids do not impair the T-cell depletive effects of ATG, their co-administration confers additional benefits in allograft preservation, likely through complementary immunomodulatory mechanisms.

human:
Originality: This paper considers the version of zeroth-order lipschitz optimization with certification. Considering certification is novel, but its motivation needs further justification. For example, is the goal of certification only to certify the $\epsilon$-optimal point, or to certify $every$ point generated by the algorithm? If we only want to provide certification for the $\epsilon$-optimal point, then bandit optimization algorithms can do as well by simply picking the best point played in hindsight after playing enough rounds. The goal to certify the output of the algorithm generated in every round, in the contrary, seems extravagant since we don't care about certification when the output is far away from optimal.

Quality: It's not too surprising that one can get instance-dependent bounds, since certification essentially requires 'exploring every corner of $X$' at a high level. My main concern is on the constant $c$ and its dependence on $d$. Roughly speaking, $c$ is the product of two terms, where the first is $L^d/v_1$ and the second is $(1-Lip(f)/L)^d$. The second term is exponentially small (in $d$), which is problematic (it hurts the tightness of the upper bound) even if $d$ is seen as a constant. The first term is either exponentially large or exponentially small in $d$, depending on whether $L$ is above a constant threshold. This seems unnatural as one can easily scale the funtion to be $l$-lipschitz for arbitrary $l$, and finding an $\epsilon l/L$-optimal point will suffice. Moreover, $\gamma$ isn't completely independent of $d$ either, because the value of $\gamma$ would be not mild at all for large $d$ whereas the same value might be mild for low dimension.

Clarity: This paper is overall well-written, except that the end of Section 4 ($L=Lip(f)$ case) should be written in a separate section with more details. Adding proof sketches instead of putting technical proofs in the maintext would improve readability.

Significance: This work solves an existing open problem. Though whether the proposed algorithm could be useful in practice is unclear, it's of importance from a theoretical perspective.
LLM_1:
Originaly: The paper introduces a novel approach to zero-th order Lipschiz optimization certified by version. While certification itself is not new, its underlying motivation requires further clarification. Specifically, what is being certified - the epsilon-optimal solution or every point produced by algorithm - needs clearer justification.

For instance, if the primary goal only involves certifying the optimal solution, existing bandits can accomplish this by selecting the highest reward point in retrospect after a sufficient number of iterations. On the other hand, certifiying the outcome of every iteration seems excessive since it only matters when these outcomes are near optimal. 

Quality-wise, instance dependent bounds are not particularly surprising as certification inherently requires exploring the entire space X. I'm more concerned with the dependence of constant c on d. In essence, c is composed of 2 terms: L^dv_2 and (1 - Lip(f) / L)^_d. Although the latter term diminishes exponentially with d, this is detrimental to tight upper bounds. Meanwhile, L can be either large (exponentially so) or small depending whether it exceeds a threshold, which seems counterintuitive. Furthermore, scaling the function to achieve l-lipschez with arbitrary l will render finding epsilon-l/L optimal points sufficient. Additionally, gamma's value isn;t entirely independent from d as it becomes more severe in high dimensions. Conversely, a mild gamma in low dimensions could yield the desired outcome.

 Clarity-wise the paper has been well written, with one exception: Section four should have its own dedicated section for a more detailed explanation of when L=LIP(f). It would also be beneficial to include proof outlines instead relying solely on technical details in main text to improve overall readability.  

 Significance-wise this work effectively resolves an open theoretical problem, even though its practical utility remains uncertain. Nonetheless, from an academic perspective, such work holds considerable importance.
LLM_2:
**

The paper proposes a novel approach to zeroth-order Lipschitz optimization with certification guarantees—a concept that, while not entirely new, is applied here in an interesting way. However, the motivation underlying the certification framework warrants further clarification. Specifically, it is important to clearly distinguish *what* is being certified: is the goal to certify only the final ε-optimal solution, or does the method aim to provide guarantees for every iterate produced during the optimization process? The distinction has significant implications.

For example, if certification is only required for the final output, then simpler strategies—such as selecting the empirically best point after sufficient exploration, as done in standard bandit algorithms—may already suffice in hindsight. On the other hand, requiring certification at every iteration appears overly stringent unless intermediate points are also expected to carry meaningful guarantees, which should be justified more explicitly.

From a theoretical standpoint, the derivation of instance-dependent bounds, while technically sound, is not especially surprising given that certification typically necessitates global exploration over the entire domain $ \mathcal{X} $. A more pressing concern lies in the dependence of the constant $ c $ on the dimension $ d $. This constant comprises two key terms: $ L^d v_2 $ and $ (1 - \mathrm{Lip}(f)/L)^d $. While the latter decays exponentially when $ L > \mathrm{Lip}(f) $, this behavior can lead to loose bounds in practice. Moreover, the choice of $ L $—which may vary dramatically depending on whether it exceeds $ \mathrm{Lip}(f) $—can result in counterintuitive scaling, particularly in high dimensions. Additionally, rescaling the function to make it $ \ell $-Lipschitz for arbitrary $ \ell $ would trivialize the problem by making $ \varepsilon \ell / L $-optimality easier to achieve. Finally, the parameter $ \gamma $ is not fully independent of dimension; its impact intensifies with $ d $, meaning that even mild values in low dimensions might become problematic as dimensionality increases.

In terms of clarity, the paper is generally well-written and logically structured. That said, Section 4 would benefit from being expanded into a standalone section with a more thorough discussion of the condition $ L = \mathrm{Lip}(f) $, including its practical feasibility and implications. Furthermore, including high-level proof outlines in the main text—rather than deferring all technical details to the appendix—would significantly improve readability and help readers better grasp the core ideas.

Regarding significance, the work makes a valuable contribution by resolving an open theoretical question in the context of certified zeroth-order optimization. While immediate practical applications may be limited due to scalability and dimensionality concerns, the results are nonetheless important from a foundational perspective and could inspire future research in certified optimization frameworks.
